PETITION.TITLE: Television Transmission, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed cuts in funding to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will have serious effects on the viability of many family chemists, leading to increased charges and reduction in services and availability of medicines to the community.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to reject the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and maintain the level of funding existing prior to the Tribunal's findings.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Romania, whose Human Rights Record had been worse than that of South Africa's even before she embarked on a diabolic village destruction program, deservedly attracts worldwide condemnation. The systematic cultural genocide of the peoples affected must be prevented.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. the Australian Parliament establish whether or not Romania has satisfied fully her obligations under the Treaty of Trianon (1920) and the Peace Treaty of Paris (1947),
2. if found that Romania violates these agreements, the signatures representing Australia jointly or singularly be withdrawn from the thus invalidated documents,
3. Australia table her findings at the appropriate forums of the United Nations.
And our petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average of $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS' DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence over all other business to the Notice of Motion given this day relating to the establishment of a select committee.

I wish to speak briefly to the motion although I understand that it will be carried by the Senate. On 3 October I gave notice of a similar motion-a somewhat shorter motion-to establish a select committee which would examine matters relating to airline safety during the current dispute. Two days later some documents appeared in the press-they were also provided to the Opposition and were tabled in the Senate and I think in the other place-which indicated that, within the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), senior officers have very deep concerns about the administration of safety requirements during the currency of this dispute. The statements that were made in those reports were pretty stark and included comments such as:
We had a basic duty to our employer, the public, to maintain standards and this area I believe we have been totally inadequate.

I indicated to the Government that it was the Opposition's intention to seek to bring on the motion. Indeed, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) publicly indicated that he would like some time to consider the matter and that he would not oppose the matter being brought on for debate on the following Friday. Pursuant to his intervention, Senator MacGibbon and I met with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Willis) and him to discuss the Opposition's proposal for a select committee. During the course of those discussions it was clear that Minister Willis was very strongly opposed to a committee. But we had what I thought appeared to be a more rational and reasonable response from Senator Ray who made the suggestion that, rather than proceed to a select committee, the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications and the Civil Aviation Authority should be resubmitted to Estimates Committee B so that there could be some parliamentary examination of the issues which have been raised. One of the reasons which were put forward for making that alternative suggestion was that this would be less likely to cause alarm and concern.

I think, in a broad sense, that would be a fair description of the discussion we had. As a result, the Opposition agreed to stand back from its original proposal to enable the Estimates Committee to be reconvened and for officials to be questioned about the matters which had been raised, in particular the very specific concerns raised by the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority itself. But I stress that a series of other matters had also come through the press and other sources relating to concerns about operational standards and safety.
When I inquired last week of the senators participating in the Estimates Committee as to how that had proceeded, I was given a very negative response. It was suggested to me--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are pretty negative people.
—You must have been eating mushrooms, Fred.
—I am glad to hear the noisy sparrows opposite who actually rorted the Estimates Committee. Senator Schacht was the lesser partner to his colleague Senator Collins--
—Go and read the Hansard record if you want to talk about rorting. Go and read the lot of it.
—I read the Hansard of the Estimates Committee between 11 p.m. and 1 o'clock this morning. I have never read a more appalling abuse of the parliamentary procedures than is described in that record.
—You can't read many Hansards.

—The bellowing of Senator Ray is very different from what I thought was the very rational and sensible approach that he adopted in the meeting that we held. When I said I was going to bring this matter on he responded by way of interjection, `You got done like a dinner on the Committee'. Let us just pause at that point. We are dealing with a matter of airline safety and the Opposition's concerns about the standards which have been produced. The Government is treating this as some sort of bovver boy contest. Senator Collins came in with his bovver boots and proceeded to intimidate the Committee and the witnesses and generally carried on like a larrikin and a lout. That was the response of Government senators to what I understood to be a proper attempt to examine the concerns which have been raised. I will be very happy to expand on my concerns when I move the motion that I gave notice of this morning. Suffice it to say that I do not believe that anybody--
—They ran out of questions.

—I get interjections such as, `They ran out of questions'. Anyone who carefully reads the Hansard will find that Senator Bolkus continually drew up questioners, as though he were in the chair, on the basis that matters had already been canvassed. They had been canvassed by dint of Senator Collins and, to a lesser extent Senator Schacht, giving evidence to the Committee. It was the most absurd demonstration of senators acting not as inquirers but as givers of evidence. I will read some of the Hansard into the record because here we have the agent for the airlines and the agent for the Civil Aviation Authority, Senator Collins, not seeking the public interest and seeking to establish whether there are concerns to be allayed, but acting as an advocate and a witness. There are serious matters which touch on the question of airline safety. The Estimates Committee was a gross abuse of parliamentary procedures and a total stepping back from the basis on which the Opposition agreed to follow this procedure rather than have a select committee.
—Demonstrate it.

—I will be happy to demonstrate it. The difficulty is that this Hansard is so riddled with the improprieties of Senator Collins and Senator Schacht that it would be impossible to analyse it all in the space of one speech. It is the shabbiest exercise on the part of the Australian Labor Party which I have seen in the whole of the time that I have been here. Interjections from people like Senator Collins, after his performance last week, are immaterial.

SPEECH.PARA: The serious issue which has been raised is whether there has been a reduction in the safety standards which are applied to the aviation industry, whether there has been a shortening or a change of procedures under the pressure of this dispute. That is a matter which we are determined to see examined. We are also happy to have a number of the other issues which arise in this dispute examined. We are happy to have the nature, extent and legality of the compensation arrangements examined by a committee. We have very serious doubts about the legality of what the Government is doing as well as its propriety. We are happy to have the economic implications of this dispute examined. I suspect that some of Senator Collins's constituents are bleeding rather more than Senator Collins at this stage from the prolongation of this dispute and the incapacity of the airlines to deliver the services required to the people of Australia. I commend this suspension motion. I believe that we should carry it quickly and move to debate the issue of substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take any longer than Senator Chaney in expressing my opposition to the suspension of Standing Orders. The first thing to be said about this particular matter is that it is a no confidence motion in the Senate committee system. This is a quite different motion from the motion which Senator Chaney moved on another occasion, which was more inclined towards the select committee route than the standing committee route. This is a more comprehensive inquiry. We have a standing committee, yet we cannot refer these broad terms of reference to a standing committee. One has to ask why. It could be a vote of no confidence in standing committees. I guess that from time to time we have all shared sentiments that a standing committee does not necessarily provide the best possible route to get an answer to an inquiry, but it does raise the question: Why have all these standing committees covering these areas? We have the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure covering this area. It has a cast of thousands because it has got an extra inquiry. Something we should consider in the suspension of Standing Orders is that we are not going the standing committee route and, therefore, there must be something wrong with the standing committees. It must be remembered that we have 76 senators and something like 30-odd Senate committees running at the moment when we include Estimates committees, standing committees and select committees. We are adding an extra committee every two or three months. I do not know where that leaves the Independents. They cannot possible cover all these committees that may be of interest to them, although I know how hard some of them try. So the first thing is that it is a no confidence motion in the standing committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, and at least I appreciate that Senator Chaney did not allege that we went the Estimates committee route to deliberately obstruct-I should put on the record why I supported going the Estimates committee route. It was not simply that there would be a lot of publicity attached to a select committee. I made the point-and I think it was a fair one-that one of the problems with the committee system, whether a standing committee or a select committee, is that all the allegations are made up front. One tends to get all the witnesses in with a gripe or an allegation. They are all made up front, and they are made under immense publicity. When the defence comes two or three weeks later, that does not get coverage. The advantage I saw in the Estimates committee approach is that each allegation could be answered as we went along.

I do not think I made any secret of the fact that this was not going to be a normally reconvened Estimates committee where the Opposition has 13 hours of questioning all by itself like it normally does, that it was not going to be Little Big Horn all over again at the Estimates Committee. We also saw on our side of politics a necessity for close questioning on some of these issues, especially as leaked allegations had been made by certain officers of that department-not necessarily by those who had written the documents. It was always going to be a fairly robust affair.

We also had someone-someone not present here-strutting around the day before saying that his fax machine was overloaded with allegations. It was not as big a beat-up as Senator Tambling gave for the original Estimates Committee considering the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, but there was a bit of strutting on his side of the stage about all having these allegations. They were related not just to the two documents but to all the other questions that had been asked at Question Time. Basically the Opposition's side of politics, having peddled those at Question Time, having pushed them time and time again, could not substantiate them at the Estimates Committee.

What we have now is not just an inquiry into air safety-because if Senator Chaney had put that up today, I suspect it would have been defeated in this chamber. Senator Chaney-I think it is a clever move-has picked up Senator Sanders's notice of motion from two or three weeks ago. He has not picked it up word for word because that would be a dent to his pride, but he has picked up the basic tenets of that motion to incorporate it all into one motion. That is why we have this motion to suspend Standing Orders.

The biggest joke about this motion is found at the very start. It says, `. . . report, not later than the last sitting day of November 1989'. We have heard the great promises of the world-`The cheque's in the mail', `I will respect you tomorrow morning', `Private polls in our marginal seats show . . .'-but this has to be one of the biggest promises in history. Does--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever heard of extensions of time, Senator?

—I was coming to that. Does Senator Chaney realistically expect this committee to report by the end of November? It suggests that he is going to have a quick cheapie inquiry with virtually no advertising for witnesses, remembering that everyone will be stuck here all bar two weeks of November and maybe a couple of days this week. Senator Chaney should be saying to us today that he also intends the Committee to sit during sitting hours, because I do not see how on earth he can possible get an inquiry done without sitting during sitting hours. Or is it going to sit for only a couple of days in November and write up a quick report? Senator Chaney, by way of interjection, asks whether I have heard of extensions. I might as well acknowledge now that we will support an extension to the end of January-because that is how long it is going to take.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney indicated that the numbers are here to carry the suspension of Standing Orders. I oppose it basically because it is politically motivated. Throughout this whole pilots dispute the coalition has never known where it stood. Occasionally it likes to oppose a trade union movement, unless their gross income is less than $50,000 a year, and then some magic moment occurs: If it is the doctors, the pharmacists or the pilots, suddenly it has to get in and support them. Senator Chaney said that the behaviour of Labor Party members at the Estimates Committee was disgraceful. It was nowhere near as disgraceful as some of the cheap questions that have been asked in this chamber, which were never checked or verified-`chuck the allegation out and let it have a run'. When the Opposition had a chance to test it at the Estimates Committee-99 per cent of its claims could have been tested in the Estimates Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they were not.

—We might hear about which ones were not tested. I do not know where Senator Newman has been in the last few weeks. We have heard a whole series of allegations which were not related to those two leaked documents relating to air safety. What happened to all those allegations? Did Senator Newman test them personally?
—We did not get the opportunity. We tried and tried.
—Now we have the answer as to why it did not work. The poor pathetic defenceless wimps put on the Committee could not press their point at all.
—I was not on the Committee.

—It is a pity Senator Walters is not here. We at least could have put her on because she is a good tough battler. She would have got her questions in; there is no doubt about that. If we had not allowed the questions in we would have been punished forever. I will not break my promise not to speak longer than Senator Chaney did. We oppose the suspension of Standing Orders and regard this motion as politically motivated. I acknowledge that it is a broader motion and involves more than just air safety now and, as such, it is cleverly politically designed. We will not seek to divide on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

—Order! The question before the Chair relates to the suspension of Standing Orders. I have allowed the mover and responder some latitude but other speakers will have to confine themselves to the question of whether Standing Orders should or should not be suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that ruling, Mr Deputy President. I will be very brief. The Australian Democrats support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders for the reason that we are trying to see a resolution of the pilots dispute. We would like to see the aeroplanes flying. We feel that a Senate select committee with the broadened references suggested in the motion could be a forum which could be of some help to restore aviation to its rightful place in the transportation pattern of this country. That is why we support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and that is why we will support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, a select committee be appointed, to be known as the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, to inquire into and report, not later than the last sitting day of November 1989, on:

(a) the nature, extent and legality of all changes to training, licensing, administration, employment and other organisational and operational practices during the pilots' dispute relevant to the operation of airline services in Australia;
(b) the extent to which air safety may have been affected by any such changes;
(c) the nature, extent and legality of the compensation arrangements entered into by the Government and the airlines;
(d) the economic implications of the dispute.
(2) That the provisions relating to the powers and membership of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

I have already outlined the history of this matter and the fact that on 3 October we gave notice of a motion seeking the establishment of a select committee which was solely concerned with the issue of airline safety. Some time later, on 6 October, Senator Sanders gave notice of a motion which related to the events and issues which led to the airlines dispute and the most appropriate actions in the best interests of the country to bring the dispute to a just and speedy conclusion. In light of the comments made by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) about the change of form of the new motion we are putting forward today-which encompasses the issues of safety, compensation and the economic implications of the dispute-let me say that the Opposition's concern about the Australian Democrats' original proposal was that we believed we should not establish a Senate committee which in effect was a mini-industrial relations commission. I discussed that matter with Senator McLean of the Democrats and subsequently with Senator Sanders. We now have a motion which I think has the support of both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It picks up the vital issue of safety, some of the broader economic questions and the legality of the extraordinary arrangements which the Government has entered into with respect to compensation.

In moving for the suspension of Standing Orders I canvassed the concession which was offered by the Opposition with respect to this proposal when we said that the matter could be considered by the Estimates Committee. We saw that as a reasonable response to the concerns that were expressed by Senator Ray that this matter should not be dealt with in what I might term a flamboyant way which might cause alarm. We went along with that and the Estimates Committee sat last Wednesday.

The object of an Estimates committee is to enable Ministers to appear before a Senate committee to be questioned and to call upon public servants to make available information and evidence to the Parliament. That procedure has been developed over a period of 15 to 20 years. It is a valuable variation on the general parliamentary committee system and permits evidence to be given by public servants to assist the Parliament to do its job. It is a different sort of procedure from the operation of a normal select committee where witnesses come forward, give their evidence and are subsequently questioned. In the case of an Estimates committee the evidence is given, effectively, by the Minister or such public servants as he designates. That is one part of the concern that the Opposition has about this Estimates Committee hearing-that the limitations of that process were used by the Minister to limit questioning of relevant public servants on issues which had been raised, including those raised by those public servants themselves.

Let me take the Senate through parts of this record. One of the most notable and extraordinary features of this record is that the principal witness before the Senate Estimates Committee was Senator Collins. Senator Collins adopted a role which was quite extraordinary, when he was supposed to be there as a senator inquiring into this matter. I invite honourable senators to look at the opening pages of the record of what happened at the Estimates Committee. When questions were being asked of a Dr Lee about incident reports and accident notifications, we find Senator Collins breaking in and saying this:

Fine. I noted Senator Panizza's claims that Royal Brunei crews had, in fact, exceeded their approved operational times and out of a healthy degree of self-interest, as a regular passenger on Royal Brunei Airline, I spoke to a number of Royal Brunei crews myself. I also spoke to the senior operations officer within Ansett-

I interpolate to say that throughout this inquiry it was clear where Senator Collins was getting his information, advice and, for all I know, instructions from, because he was always coming back to the Committee and telling it what he had been told. Let me go with what Senator Collins said. The report continues as follows:

I also spoke to the senior operations officer within Ansett responsible for scheduling and supervising the Royal Brunei operations. The story I got from both sources was absolutely consistent even though I spoke to them independently.

The senior Royal Brunei pilot I spoke to was British to his bootstraps, an ex-RAF Harrier pilot et cetera-just one of these horribly unqualified pilots flying in our air space at the moment, according to the Federation. He was absolutely stiff upper lip, plum in the mouth Oxford accent, the whole bit. He told me he was horrified at such a suggestion because-and perhaps you can confirm this information-Royal Brunei operates under British regulations and the equivalent of the CAA in Great Britain and they have a very strict company procedure.
This was confirmed by the Ansett manager . . .

I could go on reading the evidence of Senator Collins because when he was challenged later by Senator Brownhill-when he finally got a question in-who said that Senator Collins had been talking for two hours, Senator Collins said, `No, only for 45 minutes'.

The fact of the matter is that if one reads this Hansard one finds that Senator Collins, who likes to come into this Senate and accuse the Opposition of being the agents of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, has made it patently clear that he spent his time obtaining evidence and then choosing to make whatever evidence he thought suited him available to this Committee. What an absurd way to suggest that a parliamentary committee should proceed. All we have had is Senator Collins as a witness. He reminds me of my first experience of a public servant. Was Senator Collins ever a public servant?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I thank the honourable senator. He reminds me of the public servant who appeared in the first case I did for an Aboriginal defendant. He walked into court, stood at the bar table as a would-be prosecutor of this unfortunate woman and proceeded to read from his file the facts which, he said, justified taking her children from her. As I read this account I was reminded of the habits of that public servant and of how ridiculous it is to inquire into a matter when the evidence is given by a member of the Committee itself. It was a farce. For hour after hour during the sittings of this Committee Senator Collins and Senator Schacht were not seeking evidence, not asking questions and making inquiries, but giving evidence to the Committee and seeking to overbear and override the Committee.
—I don't apologise.

—There is no apology from Senator Collins, and I would not expect it. I regard what Senator Collins and Senator Schacht did as a shabby exercise. They were trying to prevent the proper examination of allegations about safety arising from the pilots dispute. On the face of this record it is quite clear that there was a concerted and planned action to abort the procedures which were suggested by the Government to avoid the select committee procedure which was originally suggested by the Opposition. What happened in this Committee has all the appearance of a conspiracy. I do not know how widely Senator Schacht and Senator Collins conspired with the Minister and with the airlines.
—Not at all.

—Well, all that I can say is that on the face of this record it is quite clear that Senator Collins spent all of his time getting his instructions from the airlines. The Opposition says that this is a totally unsatisfactory procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which made this procedure totally unsatisfactory was the abuse of the sub judice rule. The record shows that all of a sudden Senator Collins explained to the Committee that legal proceedings have been commenced, perhaps have been commenced or perhaps will be commenced. If one wants an indication of the linkages between Senator Collins and those we are seeking to examine, one need only note that he came into the Committee and told us that legal proceedings are probably to be commenced. From that point on we find a limitation in the capacity of the Senate Committee to inquire into these facts. The idea that the mere threat of legal proceedings should restrict the capacity of the Parliament to examine the problems of airline safety is absolutely preposterous. It is patently absurd to suggest that it is in the public interest to prevent in the name of sub judice the relevant public servants being asked questions about the operational and safety procedures that they have challenged.

The fact is-and we find it on the face of this record-that a most restrictive approach was adopted. Senator Collins is guilty of the most appalling inconsistency. He insisted that the sub judice rule be applied. But after he had been outside the Committee for a while, he came back and proceeded to ask a whole series of questions in total contravention of the view that he had previously put. So there was the selective use of the sub judice rule by the Labor members of this Committee to prevent proper inquiries into a matter of public interest.

The fact is that it has never been a parliamentary rule of this chamber, any more than it has been a rule of public debate for the newspapers, that the mere existence of legal proceedings is enough in itself to prevent questioning. There are ample Senate rulings which show that a judgment has to be made on the facts of the individual case. In any event, the mere threatened issue of a writ cannot give rise to the rule. The Clerk of the Senate offered his oral advice to the Chairman of the Committee, which was ignored by him. The Clerk of the Senate offered his written advice, which is part of the record of this Committee. Again, it was ignored by the majority of this Committee. I would simply say that it was the most absurd attempt to stifle inquiry into matters which are of vital public interest. If one asks any citizen whether an inquiry into airline safety standards should be aborted by the issue of stop writs, the answer would be a resounding no. Yet these bovver boys, these bully boys, used that rule to their advantage to cut off questioning which they did not approve of by Opposition senators and totally ignored the rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Senator Collins says, `Rubbish'. The face of the record is clear: Senator Collins played a pathetic, bullying role as an agent for the airlines and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). He should be condemned for his part in this whole exercise. It was a pathetic failure by him to live up to his public responsibilities. It is quite clear that in this case the sub judice rule was abused to prevent a proper examination of those officials except when it suited Senator Collins who, having raised the sub judice rule, then turned around and ignored that same provision when he wished to question the officers at the table.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a clear admission from the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) about the pressures which were being put upon people because of the issue of writs. I quote from what Senator Bolkus said during the inquiry:

The reason I went up to Mr Segan was in recognition of the fact that we were skating on very thin ice at that moment and I wanted to let him know that if at any stage he was concerned about his legal rights he could just ask for a short adjournment. I am very sensitive to the fact that we have before us a rather intimidating situation, whether you people realise it or not.

The man who is being intimidated is Mr Segan, one of the public servants who have said that there is a serious problem with safety standards as they are being administered by the Civil Aviation Authority. We find in the Senate record, brought out by Senator Brownhill in his questioning, another allegation of intimidation. Senator Brownhill referred to a public claim by a Captain Grady that he had been offered a job but had said that he had not flown for 20 years and would need almost a month of training to become proficient again, but was told that he would be flying in two days and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you hear the reply from CAA?
—I heard the reply from CAA, but not as to the point which I am making. Senator Brownhill went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to that, apparently he received a threat of being charged with defamation from the solicitors of this particular company.

The simple point the Opposition would wish to make is that in a circumstance where senior officials have raised serious allegations about safety-and in this inquiry they still say they have concerns about the safety standards which have been imposed-it is openly admitted by Government senators and the Minister at the table that those people are being intimidated.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?

—By those who are threatening them with writs and who are suing them for defamation. In a matter which should not be subject to the argy-bargying which is going on in the chamber now and which was subject to the same argy-bargying in the Senate Estimates Committee, when there should be a clear public interest concern on all sides of the chamber for a proper examination of the facts, there has been a highly partisan approach by Government senators and an attempt to suppress the facts. That, I think, is the only interpretation that can be placed upon this record of the Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins expresses great dismay and boredom-a whole range of emotions-as I make these comments. I do not believe that at any previous time in the history of the Senate a government senator would have engaged in the conduct in which Senator Collins engaged before the Committee. He has appeared as a partial advocate for particular interests. He has given evidence rather than been a person who has examined the available evidence. He has chosen to act as a conduit for evidence from other areas. Senator Collins will now be able to ensure that evidence can be given directly to the Senate instead of this abuse of procedures at last Wednesday's hearing of which, I suspect from his interjections, he was the principal architect. The Opposition believes that this is a serious matter which is of concern to many Australians, particularly those who have to use the airlines to travel, or those who are able to do so. In those circumstances we believe that the only proper course is for a Senate select committee to be established.

Before a Senate select committee, witnesses will have an opportunity of coming forward and giving their evidence without interference from Senator Collins or Senator Schacht, or indeed a Minister at the table or a chairman. They will have a chance to make their submissions and then be questioned properly. In putting forward the proposal for a select committee, I accuse the Government of having engaged in a systematic rorting of the Senate Estimates Committee in an attempt to intimidate people and to prevent facts from being examined. The Opposition will not tolerate that. It will therefore participate in the proposed committee and ensure that it gets to the truth as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion. We do so because, as I stated earlier in our response to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, we would like to see a resolution of the pilots dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all agree that--
—All we need is a change of Prime Minister; that is all.

—That may or may not be true. The fact is that we have had no truly viable commercial airline services-I am referring to the larger airlines-in this country for 10 weeks. It is crippling the country. We have to do something about it. As senators, we must make every effort to use our offices, whatever they are, to resolve this dispute. Whatever we can do we should be doing. The Senate committee system is a possible forum for resolutions of disputes. Certainly, the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare acted for years as a clearing house for information, as an agency which could hear all points of view, which could give the protection of parliamentary privilege to all points of view. That Committee and others-it is that Committee I am familiar with-arrived at a consensus amongst all participants on a workable solution. That is what I think a committee of well intentioned people could do in the case of the airline pilots dispute. I know I am naive, but I would like to see such a committee operate in an honest and a non-political way. I think we are adult enough in this place to do this and I would like to do it. What I do not want is a witch-hunt or the appearance of a witch-hunt.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems we have had in this entire dispute-and we have it constantly-is the way the media interprets what we are saying, what we are doing or what the situation is. I think that a Senate select committee on the airline pilots dispute-and honourable senators will note that the proposed committee is to inquire into certain aspects of the dispute, not aviation safety-could focus the media's attention on the real issues so that they do not go haring off after sensational issues to the jeopardy of the real, basic issues which we need to cover.

I have a commitment to aviation. I have been in the aviation industry for 40 years. I have been a commercial pilot and a flight instructor. I believe in what aviation can do for the country. At the moment it is crippled. Air safety is just one consideration. There are many others. That is why we wanted this reference broadened, to include the economic implications of the dispute on everyone: on the tourist industry, on the rest of the workers in the airline industry, on all the companies and businesses that depend on rapid air transport around this country, and on the airline pilots themselves. Certainly they are suffering. Many are making agonising decisions about their futures. What seems to be happening now is that Sir Peter Abeles has moved into this dispute, seeing a grand opportunity presented to him by the pilots to streamline his organisation in preparation for deregulation and to get a generally more compliant staff, a group of pilots who will do what Sir Peter Abeles wants. This is one thing I think we should look at. Sir Peter Abeles is a very capable businessman but he is ending up in a position of tremendous power in our transport industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the Prime Minister!

—Perhaps a committee such as this could look into some of those aspects. I think it is time that we looked at these aspects. There are many more issues involved here than simply air transport, such as the very fast train and road transport. Those things are, of course, separate.
—If you are so keen, why not put this to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport and Infrastructure?

—That is a good point. The Senate Standing Committee on Transport and Infrastructure is already overloaded. The honourable senator knows it and I know it. If we referred this matter to that Committee what would it do to the rest of the Committee's references? It would not be able to operate. That is why we need a Senate select committee. I do not accept the argument that simply because a committee exists with that name it can take on this reference. It cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: Air safety is one consideration which has been pretty well answered. As a professional pilot, I see the arguments. I have heard the response to the arguments. I am satisfied in my own mind that, while some incidents deserve looking at, in the overall sense airline safety has not been degraded in this dispute. I think the system is safe, as it always has been, and it has not been very degraded. Certainly there have been some instances of foreign pilots not understanding the language. I have that difficulty myself sometimes, I must admit, and some people have trouble understanding me, but it works out. An inherent buffer system is built into all of this. We in the aviation business are very safety conscious, and rightly so, but there is still room for some flexibility.

This brings me to another point which is of great concern to me: the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)-it has been called a number of other things in the past-is undergoing a period of great change during which the old rules and regulations which so stifled aviation in this country are being rewritten. It is actually introducing a ray of sunshine, a ray of commonsense, into its operations. If there is a great concentration on safety issues, many of which are very sensational and get a lot of press coverage, it gives the hard- liners in the CAA the opportunity to stick to their rule books and say that they will not make any changes whatsoever but will simply work to rules and therefore cover themselves. This would be a very retrograde step in Australia, which depends so much on air transport and which has been so hampered by bureaucratic red tape in the past. It is my worry that these discussions will give ammunition to the hardliners in the CAA who do not want to make changes. That is something we have to look out for and I think we can. In a Senate select committee we can make sure that the issues which are brought up are real issues and not merely propaganda. Senator Collins agrees with me and I am glad that he does.

The cooperation between us and the Opposition is a beneficial one. We can hear all aspects of this airline pilots dispute and hopefully furnish a forum for all parties, including the airline pilots, to have a say unfettered by the fear of writs. At the moment the writs are flying fast and every time anybody, including any CAA official or pilot, says something, a writ flies. That has a chilling effect and it means that some people who have a point of view simply cannot express it. I think in a democracy that is reprehensible. Anything we can do to make this situation more democratic, we should do. Therefore, we support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —With every passing day it is becoming more and more obvious that a personal trait in which the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) revels and which is constantly commented upon by honourable senators on this side of the House is his sanctimony. One of the more disturbing things about the Leader of the Opposition is just how bitter and twisted he is getting these days. We all understand that that is the result of his suffering an extraordinary sense of political frustration from being in the Senate, but he should appreciate that he will not have to suffer it much longer. He will soon be in the little green room, so perhaps he could spare us a little of his bile. I make those points because everything that was said by the Leader of the Opposition this morning must have related to that bile because it certainly did not relate to what happened at the Estimates Committee. That is why I also add that despite the opportunity--
—Who are you trying to kid?

—That makes about as much sense as the gibbering the honourable senate engaged in all day at the Estimates Committee B meeting which did her Party no credit. We decided early in the day that Senator Alston would have been far more useful to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of things about that Estimates Committee hearing need to be said in relation to the motion this morning. It is recorded in the Hansard transcript that very early in the proceedings it was decided that in fairness to the gravity of the issue being discussed, that is, air safety, the Estimates Committee could not be conducted strictly according to the rules of Estimates committees because, were it to be conducted on those grounds, the Opposition would have been prevented from asking a single question related to the issues of air safety because the Chairman could have ruled and the Minister certainly would have ruled, as Ministers have ruled in Estimates committees, that because questions did not relate to Estimates they were out of order. I do not know how long it has been since Senator Chaney sat on an Estimates committee, but certainly in my hearing Ministers have so ruled. To nail this particular furphy to the wall, very early in the proceedings-and it is recorded in Hansard-the proposal that some degree of latitude would need to be applied was canvassed. On behalf of Opposition members, who were incapable of making any points for themselves, I made the point that, were the strict rules to be applied, the Opposition would be effectively gagged in terms of the extent to which it could canvass the issues raised in the two leaked documents, which it was slaving to do.

Because the matters were related to air safety and because the Opposition had been running the most appalling and contemptible scaremongering campaign, which has been brought to earth every time it has run it, it was relevant to the Estimates Committee that some of those stories put about by members of the Opposition be nailed when the opportunity was there to have the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) there to nail them. That is precisely the reason that I raised that outrageous piece of nonsense perpetrated by Senator Panizza who alleged that Royal Brunei crews, who I would say would be some of the more professional of the overseas crews currently flying in Australia, were breaching regulations. The reality is different, as is the case with all the other furphies run by the Opposition. They were not breaching the regulations, and we have not since heard from Senator Panizza.

Much has been made of the debate on sub judice. Senator Chaney took a flying leap into space and said that I had raised the question of sub judice because the fact that writs had been issued or were likely to be issued had been leaked to me. It was leaked to me by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation national news because that is where I heard it. I said that at the Committee hearing and it can be found in the Hansard transcript. I do not need to read selectively from the Hansard transcript between 11 p.m. and 1 a.m. I was at the meeting and I recall every word spoken during the entire 13 hours in which Opposition members failed to land a blow. I was there for the whole 13 hours watching as one by one the outrageous and nonsensical claims peddled by the Opposition were nailed to the ground. The result was that the members of the press-our show was the only show in Parliament House that day-were there for the entire proceedings. That is the reason we have this motion before us today. I did not realise until Senator Chaney obliged me this morning by retailing it that that was a view put in private this morning by Senator Robert Ray. Senator Ray, as usual, was spot on because the Opposition spent 13 hours trying to beat up the storm on air safety to the point where its behaviour became so outrageous-this will also be recorded in Hansard-that Senator Sanders turned around and with considerable anger said to Senator MacGibbon and Senator Newman that they would not get the support of the Australian Democrats for their select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why have we now? What have you done?

—That point has already been covered by Senator Ray. The Opposition has not got the select committee it wanted established. Senator Sanders is quite right. He would not support it and he has not. The Australian Democrats have supported this Select Committee, as Senator Ray said, because of a very clever amendment to the original select committee proposal to accord with a select committee into the broader issues that Senator Sanders was prepared to run.
—And which the Liberals said they would never support.

—And which the Liberal Party said it would never support. The one other personal reflection that I commented on to Senator Schacht later in the day was why in hell members of the Opposition had ever been possessed of the idea to put Senator Newman on the front bench. I imagine that, should they ever get into government, being a pretend shadow Minister is a position she will not enjoy shortly after they win, should they ever win.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the sub judice rule-and I am happy to stand my record of parliamentary propriety alongside Senator Chaney's any day of the week, and I know which one will come out best-I happen to have a strong view that parliaments should not be cowards' castles and that parliamentary privilege should not be abused by having grossly defamatory statements-and in my non-legal opinion they are grossly defamatory statements-made about individuals canvassed before a committee of the Parliament without giving an individual the opportunity to defend himself.

My particular concern, to get down to specifics-no doubt it will be canvassed before the select committee and I will be happy under those circumstances to see it canvassed before that select committee-is that Mr Lewino's paper does make some very nasty personal aspersions about an individual. I am concerned about the sub judice rule, and I do not apologise for it. I will be quite honest. I did not want to see Mr Segan or Mr Lewino called to give evidence before the committee, not because I did not want the issues of air safety tested, but because of two things: firstly, the statements made about Captain Smith by Mr Lewino in his paper, whether they are true or false, are highly damaging to Captain Smith; secondly, the extent of the personal distress caused to both Mr Segan and Mr Lewino was clear. The papers that had been written for internal use inside the CAA have been used disgracefully by members of the Opposition who have no scruples at all in terms of smearing individuals in the Senate.

It is a matter of fact that, with the exception of Captain Smith, that was the only issue contained in either of the papers by Mr Segan and Mr Lewino that was not canvassed. I am grateful that it was not. The difficulty is that we sat for 13 hours that day. We canvassed every substantive issue that was raised by those papers. The issues were categorically refuted again and again by the senior executives of the CAA. That is important because an extremely perceptive and key question was asked of Mr Segan during those proceedings by Senator Sanders-very deliberately asked, I might add-and the answer was very revealing. The question to Mr Segan was: Do you have any problems with the regulatory changes that are being made inside the CAA and have been made since February this year-that is, well before the pilots dispute started-as a result of the review processes that have been conducted inside the CAA? Mr Segan replied-and he is entitled to reply-`Yes, I do'. I am paraphrasing him, but it is a fairly accurate account of what he said. He went on to say, `I am known as one of the more conservative officers of the Civil Aviation Authority and I do have deep concerns about the changes that are being made to streamline the regulations'. In other words-and it was a perceptive question by Senator Sanders and it is a particular interest of his--

TALK.START.PARA: —And which Senator MacGibbon has been crying out for.

—As Senator Schacht quite rightly says, Senator MacGibbon has been crying out for years to achieve that inside the CAA. That is all documented in Hansard, too; in fact, I quoted some of that, to Senator MacGibbon's discomfiture, and he was extremely uncomfortable that day.
—Were you a witness, or were you asking questions?

—I will be glad to get back to that interjection, which I thought I had already covered. We were there to discuss a grave issue. Senator Chaney keeps saying that it is a grave issue, but he does not want it canvassed. We were there to discuss the question of air safety in front of the nation's media. I have no hesitation in saying that when allegations are made of breaches of air safety-in my view, criminally made by members of the Opposition, one after the other, including the leader-when the officers of the CAA are present at a committee meeting and people want these issues canvassed, they should be. Members of the Opposition were not going to canvass these issues because it would be embarrassing to have their nonsense laid to rest, so somebody had to, and I was happy to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney made an extraordinary point this morning in debate because I took the trouble that the Opposition has not bothered to take to go to the source of the information inside an airline to get authoritative information on the record-and I did say to the officer that the conversation was on the record-about Ansett schedules for Royal Brunei. Who else does Senator Chaney suggest that I go to except the officer in Ansett responsible for scheduling the airline operations of Royal Brunei? I had never spoken to that officer before in my life until I spoke to him on the telephone. I also spoke to Royal Brunei pilots. As a responsible member of parliament with a very keen personal interest in air safety that overrides any partisan allegiances I might have-I consider my own safety and the safety of fellow Australians a more important-I have done what the Opposition has consistently not bothered to do; that is, check the facts instead of running the fiction that is peddled to it by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

If I ring an officer in Ansett Airlines of Australia who is specifically responsible for scheduling the hours that Royal Brunei pilots fly in Australia and I tell him that the conversation is a matter of record and that it is not a private conversation, that I am seeking information that I will put on the public record, it is not unreasonable to think that that officer will give me an accurate answer. I do not apologise for wanting to seek the truth. Senator Chaney, of course, is frightened of it and does not want it sought out. If that is called a leak from an airline, I suggest to Senator Chaney, with great respect, that he is drawing a very long bow indeed.

I also say to Senator Chaney that I did not stop there. I tried to contact officers such as Mr Scaife from the CAA, and I failed, I regret to say. I rang the CAA office in Perth where he works, was referred to Canberra; rang the office in Canberra and was referred to Melbourne; rang Melbourne and was referred back to Canberra. When I spoke to officers in Canberra, they referred me back to Melbourne and the officers there said that Mr Scaife had gone off sick. I tried to contact Mr Scaife to inform myself about these issues. Why did I do so? Because Mr Scaife was mentioned in Mr Lewino's document as having made serious allegations about a particular pilot in terms of repeated breaches of the rules and I wanted to ask Mr Scaife whether that particular matter contained in the papers would stand up.

I do not apologise for trying to seek information. I think it is incumbent on responsible members of this Parliament that they do so and that they deal with the facts instead of the fiction, which is what the Opposition has been dealing with. I did make a number of statements to the Committee on information that I possessed which, clearly, no other member of the Committee possessed. In terms of the debate on air safety it was useful to have those matters aired publicly. But the issue that I raised that has upset the Opposition and really got Senator MacGibbon and Senator Newman going was the question of breaches of CAA regulations by the President of the Air Pilots Federation, Mr Brian McCarthy. That was absolutely relevant. When I raised that matter the Opposition members went into an absolute fit and almost bit their legs off trying to stop me canvassing it. I think one of the most amusing outbursts all day was when Senator MacGibbon got on his high horse and said how outrageous it was that I was obviously retailing this information from leaked documents. He said it: it is in the Hansard. It killed us on the Government side, considering the fact that he has been running on nothing but leaked documents from the Federation for the last eight weeks of this dispute.

On the question of sub judice, in terms of canvassing the views of the Clerk, which are views I take into account whenever they come my way, I pointed out-it also happens to be a little hobbyhorse of mine, too-that the chairmen of committees make rulings and not the Clerk of the Senate, as erudite as his advice must be. The Chair makes the rulings. In fact, it really annoys me that constant air time is given in this chamber-it was always ruled out of order in the chamber that I came from in the Northern Territory-when the views of the Clerks at the table are canvassed at length as being reasons why the Senate should do this, that or the other. Usually, their advice is supposed to be provided in confidence. Senator MacGibbon went so far as to say-this is also recorded in the Hansard-that our esteemed Clerk of the Senate was a member of the Senate. The comment I made to Chris Schacht was that that would probably have caused Harry Evans to break out in a cold sweat had he heard it. Apart from anything else, it would probably have confirmed all his worst nightmares.

The fact is that my concerns about sub judice were related very much to two officers of the CAA being questioned about papers, containing highly personal reflections on individuals, that neither of the officers clearly intended to see the light of day; I have no difficulty in accepting the assurances they gave on those points. They were clearly embarrassed at having those papers canvassed because of the highly personal remarks contained certainly in one of them. The relevance of raising the matter, and it is a serious matter, of the President of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, the Ayatollah McCarthy, was that he gives interviews to the press every day-he has done it again this morning-on safety issues. He has run a stream of allegations publicly about breaches of air safety regulations in Australia, and the Federation has peddled a bucket load of nonsense to members of the Opposition, which they have run in here without question. Yet, with impunity, Brian McCarthy seems to think that the CAA regulations do not apply to him.

Indeed, the ire of the Opposition was raised, not by the comments I made earlier in the day about sub judice or anything else, but by the information that I had no hesitation in placing before the Committee about breaches of CAA regulations that had been committed by Brian McCarthy. If honourable senators do not think that flying an aircraft which you are not endorsed to fly is a substantive breach of air safety regulations, I do not know what is. In fact, the pilot, Mr Vuillerman, who took the heat off Brian McCarthy-it was very brave of him, I must say-was a former senior pilot with Australian Airlines. He lost his licence for a fortnight as a result not just of this one breach but half a dozen breaches of CAA regulations. That upset the Opposition dreadfully.
Having canvassed all of that, the reality is that we sat that day for 13 hours, with the sole exception--

TALK.START.PARA: —And listened to you for 12 of them.

—In response to that interjection, the fact is that I consider Senator Brownhill to be one of the more reasonable and civilised members of the Opposition and, because he conducted himself with some degree of propriety, I was happy to sit and listen, without making a single interjection, to him put at the Committee hearing every single question that he wanted to put, one after the other. We sat for 13 hours and every single question that Opposition members of that Committee wanted asked was asked. We adjourned at 11 o'clock. It will be borne out by reference to the Chairman of the Committee, the Minister at the table, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), or to any other Government member of the Committee that, had it been necessary to have done so to accommodate the Opposition, we would have sat for the entire night. We would have had no problems with that. To sit for 36 hours straight is no problem for me. We have done it in here plenty of times. When it is necessary, we will do it. The last 10 or 12 pages of Hansard will show, and I recall clearly, that the Opposition had absolutely run out of puff at that hour of the day. The press gallery had departed hours before because most of the substantive issues had been canvassed early in the day and the press realised there was nothing in them.

SPEECH.PARA: We sat and listened to the allegations from Senator MacGibbon about the outrageous episode concerning the British Aerospace (BAe) check captains checking out international pilots on 146 aircraft. Those allegations were knocked to earth. We listened once again to the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon ran in here about airliners colliding over the city of Sydney because of alleged breaches of air safety regulations by French pilots. That allegation was nailed to the ground not just by the CAA but also by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation officers who confirmed that the pilots had committed no breaches, had flown perfectly, had lodged a flight plan that had been approved and had stuck to it. If any errors were made, they were made elsewhere-not by the pilots. But we sat and listened to all of that.

I questioned the other officer from the CAA, Mr Segan, about an opening statement he had made in his paper to the effect that the CAA's supervision of air safety in Australia was `totally inadequate'. Mr Segan said on the public record that that was a piece of journalistic licence. I did not say it was journalistic licence; Mr Segan did. As anyone who was present at the hearings will attest, both Mr Lewino and Mr Segan, despite the fact that they were clearly uncomfortable about internal documents containing many personal aspersions about individuals being canvassed publicly, acquitted themselves very capably before the Committee. What was the result? How did the press report Mr Segan's comments in his paper about the CAA's adherence to air safety being totally inadequate? How did they treat his comments about the BAe check captains? That should be briefly canvassed. As I said to Mr Segan at the table, he was very good at sweeping statements in that paper. He had asserted that there was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Segan stood by the substance of his paper, and you know it.

—Senator Newman was obviously at some other committee hearing. Mr Segan said that his remarks about the totally inadequate supervision of air safety were journalistic licence. In addition, Mr Segan said that there was `absolutely no evidence whatever that the BAe check captains knew anything about the company's operations manuals'. When Mr Segan was confronted with the information that not only did they know about them but they had participated in writing them, his response was, `That information was not available to me when I wrote my paper'. On four occasions four very substantive and serious allegations made by Mr Segan in that paper were qualified by him totally in evidence before the Committee and Mr Segan went on to say that he had considerable problems with the overhauling of regulations inside the CAA.

SPEECH.PARA: I have another concern about the way Mr Segan and Mr Lewino were dragged before the Estimates Committee by the Opposition. If there is one organisation in Australia that needs a healthy degree of internal dissent and internal questioning, it has to be the CAA. Who raised questions of witch-hunting? Was there even the slightest suggestion of it on the part of the CAA? Was there ever a suggestion of it by members of the Government? No. But who canvassed it again and again at the Estimates Committee in front of the officers concerned? Senator Newman and Senator MacGibbon did. They made disgraceful remarks in front of those officers about the potential for witch-hunting and for the officers' heads to roll as a result of their appearing before the Estimates Committee. The whole issue of witch-hunting was a creation of the Opposition. Those Opposition senators displayed disgraceful behaviour.

I make the point that I hope that, of all the authorities in Australia, the CAA and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation will continue to have a very healthy degree of internal questioning, whether by memos, orally or in any other way, about what they do and how they operate. What was obvious that day was that the outrageous statements by the Opposition about head-hunting and having internal documents leaked from the CAA are absolutely inimical to that process of internal questioning continuing. I would like to hear Opposition senators defend leaks. I would like to hear them say that leaking is a good and supportable thing. If I had to think of one pre-eminent organisation where leaks of sensitive internal documents would damage the effectiveness of that organisation more than any other, it would have to be the CAA. What officers of the CAA who have genuine, serious and heartfelt concerns-as is obvious from the papers-about disagreements they are having with the central office about air safety, which is what it is all about, would want to run the risk of being hauled before a Senate committee and being asked stupid questions by Senator Newman and Senator MacGibbon for 13 hours and of having their internal documents paraded before the media and the public? I suggest not very many. Inevitably, when officers put pen to paper in the future to express their legitimate concerns about what is going on in the CAA, they will qualify them to the extent that they will be drafting those papers as though they were public documents, which means that the value of those papers will be almost totally destroyed. That is a classic example of the great damage, to Senator Newman's delight, that leaked documents handed from-and let us trace the route again-the Victorian and Tasmanian offices of the CAA to the Air Pilots Federation and then to the Opposition and the Press Gallery can cause to the proper operation of air safety in Australia. If Opposition members were fair dinkum about air safety, they would be the first in the front line to say that those leaked documents should not see the light of day, provided that the issues that are canvassed in those documents are properly debated.

I make an important point in closing. Firstly, the Estimates Committee canvassed all issues that were pertinent to air safety during those 13 hours of hearing. Secondly, the Opposition asked every single question it had to ask-which is why we adjourned the Estimates Committee. It was for no other reason; the Opposition had finished. If because of their absolute inadequacy and stupidity, Opposition members who were running the debate could not nail their points, more fool them. Another relevant matter is that when the Select Committee is established and canvasses the issues that have to be canvassed--

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be giving evidence, will you? You will be a witness.

—If it is pertinent and relevant, I will give information to the Committee as I would give information to any committee. If I had wanted to take a vow of silence, I would have become a Trappist monk, not a politician. The reality is that Opposition members failed to land a blow. Every single one of the furphies they ran was shot down and brought to earth. The media quite accurately determined that, and they did not publish a bad headline. They did not get full page scaremongering stories in the press about airline disasters over Sydney. In fact, they got no press about disasters at all. That is why we are here today. That is why we are debating this motion; there is no other reason. I hope that when the Select Committee starts its work it will do so being very conscious of the fact that whatever it does has a direct bearing on air safety in Australia and that whatever it does should not prejudice that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Australian Democrats for their support of the--
—Have you had a chance to read the transcript properly now, Fred?

—I can hear the caterwauling little corner boy. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support of the motion to establish a select committee. I suppose I should thank Senator Collins, since if anybody has brought this about it is him by his performance last week. I do not think there is any doubt that there was an opportunity for these matters to be explored in a reasonable and sensible way, and that opportunity was destroyed by the behaviour of Senator Collins. If one examines the transcript-and I have had a chance to re-read some of it since I read it last night during this debate-it will become quite clear that numerous ways were used by Senator Collins and his colleagues to prevent questions being asked. There are examples of direct intervention by Senator Collins in the middle of a line of questioning from Senator Newman. There are examples of Senator Bolkus saying that certain questions had already been answered and of his refusing to have them further explored. All in all, it was a charade last Wednesday. There was no proper examination of the concerns. There was simply an attempt by the bovver boys of the Australian Labor Party to ensure that did not occur. We had the misuse of the sub judice rule and the most extraordinarily inconsistent attitude was expressed to that rule, particularly, again, by Senator Collins.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think this debate needs to be prolonged. I simply affirm that in the view of the Opposition there is an obligation on the Parliament to ensure that the concerns, which have been raised not just by officials of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, as Senator Collins would have us believe, but from within the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), are properly examined. The Committee will have the jurisdiction to look at some of the wider questions which arise with respect to this dispute. I remind the Senate that the original proposition which was put forward by the Opposition was for a Senate inquiry which would examine the implications for Australia's outstanding record of aviation safety of any changes to procedures or regulations introduced since the commencement of the pilots dispute, and also reports of mistakes or breaches of normal operational standards. The motion which has been moved today is totally consistent with that. We are seeking an inquiry into, firstly, the nature, extent and legality of all changes to training, licensing, administration, employment and other organisational and operational practices during the pilots dispute relevant to the operation of airline services in Australia and, secondly, the extent to which air safety may have been affected by any such changes.

The Australian Democrats originally sought an inquiry into the events and issues which led to the dispute. That, of course, has been dropped from the proposal. The Australian Democrats were suggesting an inquiry into `the most appropriate actions, in the best interests of the country, to bring the dispute to a just and speedy conclusion'. I make it clear again that the Opposition does not regard a Senate committee as a substitute for an arbitration commission, nor does it see Senate committees as normally having a place in the settling of industrial disputes. I note what was said by Senator Sanders in his support of the motion, and his hope that this Committee might assist in the resolution of the dispute. If it ensures that the activities of the Government and the Authority are subject to proper scrutiny, it may well contribute to that outcome. I commend the motion, and I look forward to bringing into the Senate a motion relating to the powers and membership of the Committee which I will seek to move, if possible, later today.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 72, after clause 190, insert the following new clause in Part 4:
Telephone access to ATSIC offices

``190a. The Commission shall make provision for the development of a service which will enable a person to make a telephone call to the nearest regional office of the Commission at no greater cost than the cost of a local telephone call.''.

This amendment relates to the provision of a 008 number for people wishing to contact any of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) offices. The original amendment, as circulated, would have enabled people to make a call to the General Manager. This would have involved making a call from anywhere in Australia, presumably to Canberra, where the General Manager would be sited. That amendment has now been modified to provide that a 008 call can be made only to the nearest regional office.

This general matter of the provision of 008 numbers for government offices has been debated at some length on several previous occasions. I simply make the point here that, in relation to ATSIC, we are dealing with some of the most disadvantaged people in the Australian community. If any government department or instrumentality should provide this sort of service for potential clients and inquirers the ATSIC mechanism should.

On a number of occasions Government and Opposition senators have indicated in their speeches that the involvement of Aboriginal people with ATSIC from its inception will, to a large extent, determine its success or otherwise. In a previous speech in this committee stage, I pointed out that if a small number of Aboriginal people begin to be involved with ATSIC it is quite likely that the bulk of Aboriginal people will see ATSIC as irrelevant to their needs and the number of people involved will fall. On the other hand, if a large number of people begin to be involved with ATSIC, are involved in the election processes and so on, the number of people will increase as the Aboriginal people will then see ATSIC as highly relevant to their needs, and ATSIC will be the considerable success which we all hope it will be.
