The Minister has indicated in private discussion that this may be an extremely expensive operation. I venture to suggest that as it is to the nearest regional office-and we now have 60 regional councils around Australia-most of these calls are not going to be long distance calls or particularly expensive calls. For the reasons indicated, this amendment should receive the support of both the Government and the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter, would you be kind enough to read your amendment out again? I have a slightly different wording on my copy.
—Yes. The variation in wording was actually suggested by the Government advisers. The wording is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission shall make provision for the development of a service which will enable a person to make a telephone call to the nearest regional office of the Commission at no greater cost than the cost of a local telephone call.

If you are looking at a different version, Mr Chairman, the words `is to direct the General Manager to' are deleted and the word `shall' is put in, and words `that is under the general control of the General Manager' are deleted and the words `of the Commission' are inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this particular amendment. I can see the point behind it. I do not know that it is a very satisfactory process for the Parliament to insert a mandatory requirement that a body such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) should provide a particular service with certain budgetary implications which are indeterminate. It could be a quarter of a million dollars or half a million dollars, which is a considerable sum. I do not think Senator Coulter can say how much it will cost and I cannot say. In my submission, it is a matter which would probably be best dealt with in the ordinary Estimates process where competing bids for the provision of services by ATSIC could be looked at. This particular proposal would then be set alongside other competing proposals, and no doubt the wishes of local communities would be taken into account in deciding where the priority was.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is a satisfactory process for the Parliament to be mandatorily insisting that this service be provided. I would have much preferred to have given an undertaking-which I would have given but I understand the Opposition is supporting Senator Coulter-for the Minister to write to the Commission, enclosing a copy of the proposal and Senator Coulter's comments in the Hansard, asking it to consider the matter in relation to the preparation of estimates. I think that would have been a way to go. It would have been more satisfactory in parliamentary and Budget preparation terms than the inclusion of this particular clause. I am not even sure of its constitutionality, but that is another matter. I have not had time to think about whether Parliament can insert a clause which requires expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you considered the fact that it doesn't actually appropriate any money?

—I know. Nevertheless, it does involve a requirement of expenditure some time in the next year. I would have preferred it to have been done in the normal way through the Estimates processes, but I understand that the provision is going to be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendment of the Australian Democrats. I think it is an important principle. Senator Sheil has raised this matter on a number of previous occasions in debate. I think we need to recognise that there are a number of Commonwealth agencies and government departments that, as a matter of practice, offer this facility now, particularly in areas that relate to welfare. The provision of a 008 number provides a great deal of accessibility for people within the local areas or regions that apply.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, it is important to recognise that the people who will be most dependent upon the services are Aboriginal people in many isolated and remote communities in Australia. They will have need to call on the regions and zones and the Commission itself on a number of occasions. I believe that the initiative has merit. It will provide a benefit that is appropriate, and it is consistent with the other proposals which, as I have said, Senator Sheil has raised on a number of occasions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The procedure that we are now embarked upon requires some careful explanation so that senators are clear just where we are going. The intention is to separate the preamble from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill and, therefore, in dealing with the preamble as part of the Bill, not to support the passage of the preamble therein but to take the words of the preamble and incorporate them into a separate motion which the chamber would debate cognately at this stage.
—Cognately with what, Senator?

—With the debate on the remaining part of the committee stage. In other words, we would debate the removal of the preamble from the Bill and the words of the preamble, which is a separate motion, cognately. The other point I make briefly at this stage is that the wording of the conclusion to the motion is different from the wording of the conclusion in the preamble attached to the Bill. Quite correctly, the preamble attached to the Bill concludes with the words `Be it therefore enacted by the Queen . . .'. It links the preamble to the Bill whereas as a separate motion the words would have to be changed and would read `The Senate declares that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be negotiated by the Australian Government'. I believe that the proposed words of the preamble as a separate motion have been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee-
(a) notes that:

the Australian people voted overwhelmingly to amend the Australian Constitution to provide the Parliament of the Commonwealth with power to make laws for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples,
(ii)
the people whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land,
(iii)
they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights over land yet recognised by the Courts, other than those granted or recognised by the Crown,
(iv)
dispossession occurred without compensation and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land,
as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have become, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society,
(vi)

it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification, by measures referred to in legislation and such measures as are agreed by Parliament from time to time, of the consequences of past injustices and to ensure for all time that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples receive that full recognition and status within the Australian nation to which history, their prior ownership and occupation of the land, and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire,
(vii)
it is also the wish of the people of Australia that there be reached with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples a real and lasting reconciliation of these matters,
(viii)

it is the firm objective of the people of Australia that policies and programs be maintained and developed by the Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, that will overcome the economic and social disadvantages of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, entitle them to the enjoyment of their culture and recognition of their traditional laws wherever practicable, and enable them, with pride and dignity, to achieve full recognition and status within the Australian nation,
(ix)

it is appropriate to establish measures for the furtherance of the aforementioned objective that are consistent with the aims of self-determination and self-management for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples within the Australian nation, and

the Australian Government has given effect to its long-standing commitment to protect the rights of all of its citizens, and in particular its indigenous peoples, by recognising international standards for the protection of universal human rights and fundamental freedoms through the ratification of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and other standard-setting instruments such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenants on Economic Social and Cultural Rights and on Civil and Political Rights; and
(b) declares that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government.

We are now debating these words as a separate motion. I wish to defend the passage of this separate motion. The Government has made it absolutely clear that the preamble in the Bill has no force in law. It has no force in law for two quite separate reasons. Firstly, for a preamble to have some force in law I understand that it is necessary for the words in the preamble in some way or other to relate to clauses in the Bill such that, in seeking clarification of a particular clause or clauses should a matter come before a court of law, the court can turn to the preamble for an explanation. In other words, there must be some nexus between the words in the preamble and a clause or clauses in the Bill. As this preamble does not contain any clauses which relate to particular clauses of the Bill the preamble has no force in law.

Secondly, it is a fact that in seeking an explanation of clauses in a Bill if a matter does come before the courts the court can turn to the second reading speech of the Minister in introducing the Bill. On both occasions when this Bill and the revoked Bill that it replaces were introduced the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) made it absolutely clear that the preamble had no force in law. As the preamble has no force in law, it seems to the Democrats that it is quite misleading, immoral and deceptive for the Government to put those words into a Bill, as part of a piece of legislation. I make the point that in months or years to come Aboriginal people and others might well pick up this Bill and, looking at those words in the preamble, be misled into believing that, because those words are very noble, significant and important, they have some force in law. For that reason it is wrong to place those words in a position where they can be misleading.

For both those reasons, firstly, that it has no force in law because it has no real connection with the Bill-let us remember that we are dealing with a matter that has no legal connection with this Bill; that has been made quite clear by the Minister-and, secondly, that it may be misleading to leave it in the Bill, it is appropriate that this preamble be separated from the legislation.

My understanding of the Government's approach to the general question of the passage of some instrument of understanding, as I have called it in this motion, is that this procedure was envisaged by the Government in three stages: Firstly, the passage of a motion through both Houses of Parliament was the first matter to be dealt with in this new Parliament House when we first sat. That motion passed through both the Senate and the House of Representatives and contained words in some respect similar in intent to what we find in the preamble. The second stage which I understand that Government envisaged was the preamble to the ATSIC legislation, the matter that we are now dealing with. The Government saw that this would then lead to the third stage, which was the conclusion of a treaty, a makarrata, an instrument of understanding-it was known by a number of separate names-which would conclude a trilogy of actions leading to reconciliation and proper recognition of prior Aboriginal occupation and possession of Australia and the dispossession of Aboriginal and Islander people by European and subsequent other settlers in this country.

It is for that reason that the words that I have chosen to put into proposed paragraph (b) of the modified preamble, which is now a separate motion, are that the Senate `declares that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government'. In other words, rather than leaving the preamble simply hanging in space as a nice form of words which has no force in law and which does not give any indication as to where the Government is going in this three- part approach to reconciliation, the form of words in this motion clearly presages the next stage and hopefully ties the Government into some commitment to that stage. I express the hope that this motion will also be taken up by the House of Representatives and be passed by it in complementary form, in which case paragraph (b) would read `the House of Representatives declares that an instrument . . .'. It would give to this form of words a much greater impact than they have as attached to this legislation.

I therefore put to my fellow senators a strong plea-that they recognise that this form of words, with the different concluding clause, has considerable merit over the similar form of words attached as a preamble to the Bill. I ask the Committee to support this motion. I understand that the Opposition is opposed, possibly for similar reasons but also for some other reasons, to the inclusion of the preamble in the Bill. I suspect that the motion to remove the preamble from the Bill will be supported by the Opposition, so it is very likely that the Bill will stand without a preamble. We are now debating the words of the preamble as a separate motion, and I appeal particularly to the Government to support this motion. If that does not occur the words of the preamble disappear entirely from the business of this debate. I believe the Opposition will support the removal of the preamble but not the words of the preamble as a separate motion, whereas the Government will not support the separation of the preamble but will support the words of the preamble as a separate motion. At this stage I make a plea to the Government to support the words contained in the motion, with their different conclusions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees with Senator Coulter's proposal to remove the so-called preamble from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. He is correct in saying that the preamble has no force in law. Similarly, the passage of a resolution does not have any force in law, whether it be this proposed resolution or the precedent set by the earlier Bonner resolution passed in the Senate making a declaration of Aboriginal prior ownership. A resolution is simply an expression of the view of the Parliament. My understanding is that it has no statutory effect and has no force in law, although undoubtedly judicial authorities, when they cast their eyes over extraneous material, may or may not choose to take it into account.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that Senator Coulter has indicated the basic reasons for the removal of the preamble from the legislation he will have the support of the Opposition. We believe that the way in which the preamble has been handled by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is an act of gross and malevolent tokenism and we are certainly not prepared to lend any degree of support to that. Equally I should make it clear that the Opposition opposes the passage of the proposed resolution in the form in which it is now before the Senate-that is, basically a recast version of the preamble, to which Senator Coulter has added an additional clause dealing with what he calls an instrument of understanding and reconciliation, something which has previously been referred to as makarrata, a treaty or a compact. It has been through all sorts of manifestations and we have opposed it in all of them.

I want to look at the precise words of the preamble and the motion and to indicate why we find both unacceptable. I shall refer to the words in the preamble rather than those in the proposed resolution. First, I refer to the opening statement:

WHEREAS the Australian people voted overwhelmingly to amend the Australian Constitution to provide the Parliament of the Commonwealth with power to make laws for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples . . .

That is only half the truth. As a result of the referendum certain words were deleted from the old section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution which prevented the Commonwealth from making laws for people of the Aboriginal race. The old section of the Constitution said:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to . . .
It continued with the subclause:
. . . The people of any race, other than the aboriginal race in any State, for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.

That prohibition was removed by the 1967 referendum. If one looks at the document prepared as part of the Yes case, which was circulated to all Australian electors on that occasion, one will see that it starts-and I quote:

The purposes of these proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Constitution are to remove any ground for the belief that, as at present worded, the Constitution discriminates in some ways against people of the Aboriginal race . . .

It goes on to make the point that, by passage of this amendment, the Commonwealth would be empowered to make laws for the people of the Aboriginal race and Torres Strait Islanders. But it was primarily a device to remove a discriminatory part of the Constitution. Of course, the other part of the 1967 referendum repealed the old section 127 of the Constitution which included the prohibition on counting `Aboriginal natives', as the Constitution described them, in reckoning the numbers of the people of the Commonwealth or of a State or other part of the Commonwealth. In other words, the very first statement in the preamble is only half true. It does not reflect in its entirety the historical reality or the truth of what was done in 1967 or reflect accurately the motives which caused the Parliament to enact the legislation which was subsequently put to referendum. I object very strongly indeed to that sort of historical half-truth and misstatement. The preamble goes on:
AND WHEREAS the people whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land . . .

We come to the question of prior occupation and prior ownership. I object with particular force-not as a politician and member of an Opposition party but as a person whose professional qualifications are as an historian-to the misstatement of history. It says `the prior occupiers'. This is not the time for a lengthy anthropological debate about the findings at Kow Swamp or Mungo 1 but there is genuine historical doubt as to who were the prior occupiers, the original occupiers, of this land. On 1 August 1988 the Sydney Morning Herald published an article by Dr Rhys Jones, one of the most significant anthropologists and historians in Australia. In the article entitled `Exploring landscapes of the past' Dr Rhys Jones deals with the question of the fossils found at Kow Swamp, Mungo 1 and the Willandra Lakes area. He indicates that we are dealing with human remains of people who were very distant ancestors of modern Australian Aborigines. He says in part:

Doubtless their descendants include many of the indigenous people who now constitute the various island States and colonies of the Pacific. A great depth of time separates modern Aboriginal people from those who left the earliest traces I have described.

There is a real historical question here about the original occupiers and whether the people who constitute the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of today are the first rather than the second or third wave of prior occupiers of this land.

We then come to the question of original owners of this land. That concept is European. To my understanding, the concept is quite alien to the way in which most Aboriginal people themselves genuinely perceive the question of ownership. Later I will come to some of the evidence laid before the courts in the Milirrpum case, the original Gove land rights decision, but let me quote from a more recent example in terms of the question of ownership. I refer to an article written by Charles Perkins and entitled `Land rights, Uluru and the MCG'. In his speech in January 1984 Mr Perkins said in part:
Aboriginal people are of a vastly different culture to non-Aboriginal culture. Traditional Aboriginal culture is governed by a deep, spiritual affinity with the land.
Land to Aboriginal people is part of their being. It is not, as it is to non-Aboriginal people, a saleable commodity.

The whole concept of ownership is entirely alien to the way in which it is described in the preamble to the Bill we are discussing. It is an important core concept which is a central concept for Aboriginal people but it is not the same as our concept of ownership. That was the point made in the Milirrpum case. It does not imply the same consequences that the definition of the term `ownership' would for non-Aboriginal people. The introduction of that terminology in this case is totally misleading. The motion goes on as follows:
they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation . . .

That is neither factual nor correct in relation to the Torres Strait Islander people. Where were the Torres Strait Islander people dispossessed by subsequent European occupation? They were not. This is another misstatement of the historical truth. It continues:
and have no recognised rights over land yet recognised by the Courts, other than those granted or recognised by the Crown . . .

Nobody has those rights. The right of the ownership of land is ownership granted by the Crown. The Aboriginal people are in no sense different in that respect from Senator Tate, Senator Coulter, or recent migrants like me or whoever it happens to be. Under our system of law ownership of the land resides with the Crown. The extent to which this part of the motion is an attempt to say that some people should have rights of ownership recognised independent of the Crown, and the rest of the Australian population should have their rights of ownership recognised only as a consequence of the grant by the Crown, is, I believe, an absolute denial of the very principles of equal treatment and equal recognition that ought to apply as far as dealing with the rights of people in Australia is concerned.

The very term `occupation' is deliberately pejorative. The motion does not say `dispossessed by subsequent European settlement'. No, it says, `occupation', with all the implications of violence. Nobody denies that violence occurred, but the overwhelming majority of people who came, and who have come, to this country did not come here with the concept of being occupiers. They came here with the concept of being settlers-of improving their lives and contributing to this country. My family and I did not migrate here with the concept of being occupiers of this country. I object most vigorously, on behalf of all of those who have chosen to make this country their home, to being told by preamble or resolution that we are occupiers, with all the pejorative hatred and negative connotations that that term implies. This country has been built and developed by people who came here with goodwill, not to do harm to anybody, not to do harm to the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people, but to participate in the growth and development of this country. To be told by Mr Hand or Senator Coulter that we are part of the `subsequent European occupation' of this country is a gross insult, and one which I reject entirely.
The motion continues as follows:
dispossession occurred without compensation . . .

Compensation to whom? Two hundred years later we are to find people to compensate, people who themselves may have only the most tenuous and vague connections, of blood and of race. I thought that those terms went out of our concept of how to deal with people some years ago. The motion continues:
and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land . . .

This is again a denial of a large part of the tradition of European history on the Australian continent of attempting to deal fairly and equitably. It does not say that inadequate attempts were made; it says, `no serious attempt was made'. All of those people who participated in the work of the churches and the missions, and all of those who, during the last 200 years, have seriously sought to find an accommodation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, are dismissed. The motion states, `no serious attempt was made'. Again, that is a misstatement of the historical truth. It is part of the guilt-building and is a quite appalling attempt to indicate to people that somehow we ought to be generationally guilty and generationally apologetic for what has gone before. I do not accept that, and I do not believe that the majority of Australians do.
The motion continues:
as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations . . .

The subsequent deprivations have had more to do not with questions of occupation, ownership and traditional relationships but with the failure to deliver proper health services, education, and proper housing services. Nobody denies that. But it is not the sort of thing to be put in a preamble or a resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene for the purposes of this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague; I shall finish as quickly as possible. The motion goes on to deal with past injustices. Again, one does not deny that injustices have occurred. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: to ensure for all time that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples receive that full recognition and status within the Australian nation to which history, their prior ownership and occupation of the land-
that is a point upon which I have already touched-
and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire.

One would have thought that `full recognition and status' implies that somehow everything had been wrong, and that there had been no proper recognition of, or proper status accorded to, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this nation.

Madam Temporary Chairman, let me give one example which, undoubtedly, will be a matter of particular interest to you, and that is the question of the franchise. You will recall that the Commonwealth Constitution provided that at the time of Federation anybody who was entitled to vote in the elections for a State parliament was entitled to vote in Commonwealth elections. At the time of Federation the Aboriginal people of New South Wales were entitled to be electors. They were entitled to be on the electoral roll and, if they were on the electoral roll, they were entitled to vote, and subsequently they were subject to compulsory voting. In Victoria the electoral law provided that Aboriginal people were not denied the franchise. The only difference was that in Victoria it was not compulsory for Aboriginal people to enrol whereas it was compulsory for other people to enrol. Senator Coulter would have no objection to that; when we were talking about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) roll the other day, he found voluntary enrolment attractive. In South Australia the majority of Aboriginal people were entitled to be on the electoral roll. There was no prohibition in the States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia of Aboriginal people being on the electoral roll, nor was there in Tasmania. In other words, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia, if they were residents of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia or Tasmania, were entitled to be electors in 1901, the time of Federation, whereas in the United Kingdom women were not entitled to the full rights of the franchise until 1928. The idea that in every respect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were not granted recognition and status, which is implicit in the words of this motion, is absolutely incorrect. Certainly they were not treated or respected in the way in which we think all people-whether they happen to be Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, new Australians or old Australians of European descent-should be treated.
The motion continues:
it is also the wish of the people of Australia that there be reached with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples a real and lasting reconciliation of these matters.

That is another tokenistic form of words, again unsuitable for a piece of legislation or a resolution of the Commonwealth Parliament. There is then the matter of the maintenance of Aboriginal cultural and the recognition of traditional laws `wherever practicable'. `Wherever practicable'-what weasel words they are in this respect. One only has to look at the massive two-volume report by the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled Recognition of Aboriginal Customary Laws to see the enormous difficulties inherent in that. This is a holding out of some sort of a promise, some sort of a token hope, which we know will not be recognised.

Not only are these difficulties raised in the Law Reform Commission report but also they are raised in a paper given by His Honour Mr Justice Kirby, the former President of the Law Reform Commission, entitled T. G. H. Strehlow and Aboriginal Customary Laws. In that paper, Mr Justice Kirby draws attention to the difficulties of recognising Aboriginal traditional law and discusses unacceptable secrecy, unacceptable substantive rules regarding kinship relationships, unacceptable punishments and unacceptable procedures. One only has to look at what the High Court of Australia said in the case of Denis Walker v. The Queen in terms of the recognition of the problems of Aboriginal traditional and customary law. One only has to look at what Mr Justice Michael Maurice said in 1985 when dealing with the Warumungu land claims. Apart from his significant warning about the role of professional anthropologists in the Northern Territory, Mr Justice Maurice, then speaking as the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, said about the matter before him:

There is a unitary system of law in Australia and Aboriginal people live under it. I doubt it they have any problem understanding this but I am afraid that a lot of the evidence I have heard from non-Aboriginal witnesses suggests that some of their advisers do not.

It seems to me to be wrong to put down in a preamble or a resolution that there ought to be recognition of Aboriginal traditional laws, wherever practicable, when we know that this is a vain and forlorn hope. It is not the sort of thing that ought to be held out by way of Government preamble or Democrat motion because it will not be taken seriously and acted upon by this Commonwealth Parliament or indeed, I imagine, by any other Parliament.

I now turn to the addition which Senator Coulter has proposed, namely, the declaration that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people be negotiated by the Australian Government. Frankly, I thought we had effectively disposed of all of these questions of treaties, compacts and makarratas; of whether a nation should make compacts or treaties within itself and between its constituent parts 200 years after the event. This is not like starting to negotiate a Treaty of Waitangi; this is 200 years later. Australians will be divided into two classes-black and white-if we say, `We now want you to make a treaty with each other'. I can think of nothing more divisive, nothing more fundamentally likely to increase tensions and divisions or to set group against group, person against person, institution against institution than a motion passed by the Commonwealth Parliament which says that we want to have an instrument of understanding and reconciliation.

I conclude with the point that I made earlier. I do not accept the philosophy of generational guilt which underlies both this preamble and this motion. What happened 150 or 200 years ago does not concern a large number of people, particularly those who migrated to this country in the post-war period. Indeed, I do not feel personally responsible for the incidents that occurred in the 1920s, 1930s and 1940s when Aboriginal families were broken up and separated, when children were taken away from their parents and when physical acts of violence took place in the remoter parts of Australia as they did in colonial times. I will not have a sense of guilt and sense of personal responsibility for those events put upon my shoulders. It may well be that generations of my ancestors were guilty of oppressing native people in India. That is where members of my family were for several generations before they went to the United Kingdom and then came to Australia. Maybe I should have a sense of guilt about the natives of the province of Hyderabad, but I do not. And I certainly do not have it about contemporary politics and contemporary events in Australia.

The underlying philosophy of this preamble and this motion that we should feel guilty is wrong. In exactly the same way as attempts to make current generations of young West Germans feel responsible for incidents that occurred in their parents' era are wrong, it is wrong to attempt to make current generations of Australia bear the burden of guilt for the past. We are responsible for the present and we are responsible for the future; we are not responsible for bearing some sort of collective guilt as is put forward in this motion and this preamble. For those reasons, and with the degree of concern that I express, I indicate once again that we will support the removal of the preamble from the Bill; it should not be in the Bill. However, the motion is flawed, wrong, wicked and divisive and it will not be supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Puplick's concerns about the intent of both the preamble and the motion. Whilst for technical reasons it is appropriate to support the Australian Democrats' motion to remove the preamble for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill-and that will be a formality-it is really a matter of looking in detail at the content and the wording of both the preamble and the Democrat motion, which the Opposition cannot support. The concentration of effort and argument really hinges on the concept of what is the resultant dispossession of Aboriginal people. This is a matter of contention in our society that cannot help being highly controversial. Given the general philosophical stance taken by the Australian Democrats, I am surprised that they want to pursue and maintain this degree of controversy in an area in which we should be seeking to negotiate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have problems with some words in both the preamble and the Democrats' motion-words such as `original owners of the land', `dispossession', `dispossession occurred without compensation', `as a consequence . . . Aboriginal . . . peoples have become . . . the most disadvantaged in Australian society' and `rectification'. These types of words concern us. They create and continue the very unnecessary common debate in the community. If the Parliament were to pass the motion or the preamble, it would set down Australia's negotiating position on the proposed treaty even before any such discussions had begun. We would be setting out in the preamble matters that, at court, could be held to be prima facie evidence of fact. The preamble could then have some unexpected, even unintended, legal consequences in relation to other legislation. It is concerning that in the preparation of the legislation the Government has chosen not to tender the legal advice given to it by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). It has been notified by the Queensland and New South Wales Ministers that they have legal advice as to the undesired consequences that could well arise.

Probably the best article I have seen on this whole issue was that by Professor Colin Howard from the University of Melbourne. The article, headed `Australia's Proposed Race Law', was published in the IPA Review of December-February 1988-89. I seek leave to have the article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Australia's Proposed Race Law
Colin Howard
A Bill currently before the Federal Parliament would establish a separate system of political representation for blacks.

The Australian Constitution includes a power for the Australian Parliament to make laws on the subject of the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws. This clause of the Constitution raises the question whether it is right and proper to make laws by reference to people's race at all. The widespread public assumption that such a legislative power is for the benefit of groups of people described by the imprecise term `race' has no legal foundation. The power can be just as well be used to oppress people identified by race as to assist them. But this is only the beginning of the problem. What is a race? It seems easy to distinguish between, for example, black Africans, Arabs, Polynesians and Chinese on a racial basis. But this line of thought will not get you very far. Difficulties arise when you consider groups of people who have some characteristics in common and others which are very different. Are Greeks a different race from Turks, Italians from Icelanders, Iranians from Iraqis, Zulus from Shonas, English from Scots? Are the Jews a race? Only arbitrary answers can be given to such questions because of each of them depends on what one means by race, there is no agreement on that subject.

When one considers how vociferous the Hawke Government has been about racially-based laws in South Africa, it is worth remembering that no one has suggested that we repudiate the power to make laws with respect to race. It can be argued that we are different, we do not make laws directed against the people of any race and that any such policy would be politically unacceptable. As a justification this is a weak reed. The current danger is not that the power will be used to make laws which are crudely and overtly directed against one minority group in the community. The danger is that in the pursuit of a course of action believed to be good, damage will be done to our entire social structure by way of racially-based laws because nobody perceives what their underlying significance is.

There is, before the Australian Parliament at the moment, a Bill for an Act entitled the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, or ATSIC Bill for short. According to the Government this is a good thing because it represents the first major attempt in our history to provide a formal framework through which Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders can influence government decisions which affect them and their interests. The Bill has for the time being been sidelined by the uproar about the Aboriginal Development Commission and the dismissal of Mr Charles Perkins.

If and when the Bill comes to life again, one thing above all should be squarely confronted. It is that the Bill aims to set up an organization closely resembling a mini-parliament for the sole use and advantage of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. What this will mean is that a section of the Australian population will have been singled out by reference to race for separate representation based on a separate voting roll. If anyone suggests that this resembles apartheid, the answer will no doubt be made that in the first place the Bill does not deprive Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders of any rights they may already enjoy, but on the contrary adds to those rights, and that the Government is trying to help them, not repress them. The fact remains that they are being singled out, and the process enshrined in law, on undisguisedly racial grounds.

Some of the consequences may not be welcome. Among other things, a body will have been brought into existence with which the Federal Government can negotiate a treaty analogous to the Treaty of Waitangi reached between whites and Maoris in New Zealand a century-and-a-half ago. Although there are supporters in this country of the idea of a treaty, there are others who legitimately have misgivings about it. It can be said, for example, that land rights have caused enough trouble already, without giving one side of the argument the status of a quasi-national independent community. It can be said also that in the long-run it is folly to enact a racial law which manifestly divides Australians instead of uniting them. The New Zealand experience has not been an entirely happy one, to put it mildly.

It is a fundamental cause for unease that, contrary to our professed political ideology, the ATSIC Bill, if it becomes law, will have revealed us as being as racist as anyone else. We should not be in the business of deliberately creating a sub-nation with a sub-parliament with enormous powers to claim land and other property as its own. Whatever the motives, this is a recipe for racial disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Ever since the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, handed down his study document Foundations for the Future in December 1987, there has been tremendous and lengthy debate on this issue. The nature of consultation on the part of the Government has been to sell a concept that was highly flawed. That is best demonstrated by the fact that in this place we have passed some 120-odd amendments to the legislation. Of course we have debated considerably more amendments that the Government chose not to accept, though we on this side of the chamber argued that those amendments would have been commonsense and would have taken us a long way into the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The concentration has been on putting forward a very patronising system of government for Aboriginal people which crosses many areas. The focus has not been, more appropriately, on reconciliation, on looking to the future rather than dwelling on the past and talking largely in terms of compensation. We must ensure that in our society all groups are able to work together conveniently and appropriately. Any preoccupation-whether it is with ATSIC, a compact, a treaty or some legal implementation-always gives us cause for great concern. The former Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Charles Perkins, was quoted in the Canberra Times of 5 September this year in these terms:
He described the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as the greatest calamity that ever faced the Aboriginal people, apart from the arrival of the Europeans 200 years ago.
``I supported the concept,'' he said. ``But I do not support the mechanism . . . It's a disaster worse than the missionaries, or the introduced diseases they brought.''
He criticised the lack of consultancy with the Aboriginal people and said the commission would lead only to conflict and disillusionment.
``It's a recipe for racial disharmony,'' he said. ``[Minister for Aboriginal Affairs] Gerry Hand and the bureaucrats did not have the mandate to proceed. They had no right to go ahead.''
Mr Hand had not spent the months consulting the people, as he had promised. Mr Perkins had been there for the initial consultations.
``We promised we'd go back,'' he said.

Mr Perkins has certainly highlighted the problems that have become apparent in ATSIC. We need to look carefully at the words of the preamble and the motion. Several very important statements were made by the Northern Territory Government in evidence before the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I quote from page 22:

. . . it is virtually certain that the Preamble would be used as a tool to seek to influence the High Court to recognise an antecedent title of the Aboriginal inhabitants of Australia and further, that title to that land continues in respect of those lands which can be shown to be (or even to have been) traditional lands. In other words, if the Federal Government acknowledges prior ownership by way of the Preamble, and that ownership continues or some residual Aboriginal rights continue, then the Commonwealth may, in effect be creating a mechanism, not through the Parliament (where the decision should properly belong) but through the Courts, whereby the failed uniform land rights proposal sought to be imposed on the States and the Territory in 1984, is imposed by another means, namely the Courts. The regime thus achieved would extend land rights to land in towns and also to non-urban leased land (pastoral land). The regime would seem to apply to all land in the States and, given the preamble as proposed, any litigation is likely to favour Aboriginals.
Page 29 of the submission states:

. . . the Northern Territory Government's concerns as to effects of the proposed Preamble it is believed that the Federal Government has a duty to make its intentions clear on a number of key issues. These are:
(a) What does the Preamble purport to do as a matter of law?
(b) What are the effects on mining and industry?
(c) Are proprietary rights of individuals or the Crown in right of the States and Territory affected and if so how?
(d) What are the constitutional and compensatory ramifications?

It is incumbent on the Government to table any legal advice it has received on this issue from the Commonwealth Attorney-General. The Government has been negligent in that throughout this entire debate it has not sought to provide the advice that has been available to it. Obviously it wants to camouflage some serious issue. Senator Collins and I represent a peculiar and particular electorate, the Northern Territory, which contains a very high proportion of Aboriginal constituents. The issues of the preamble, a treaty, ATSIC and Aboriginal administration are almost daily reading in Northern Territory newspapers. There is no uniform or standard approach either within the Aboriginal constituency or in the broader community of the Northern Territory regarding the proposals which the Labor Government has put forward. The difficult problems will not be solved by pious motions that the Democrats might seek to put forward, and they will not be solved by the convoluted and fundamentally flawed provisions that are so inherent in the ATSIC legislation.

We need to consider the future options of how the Government can provide support for Aboriginal Australians. We are well aware that currently the Commonwealth Budget provides about $1 billion per annum for specific programs that will assist Aboriginal people. In addition, Aboriginal people enjoy the standard entitlements such as social security and welfare, health and education as well as the facilities of State governments and local government throughout Australia. The order of costs is probably double the $1 billion that is actually expended by way of identifiable Aboriginal programs of the Commonwealth Government. The expenditure is provided for the 230,000 Aboriginal Australians who have a very important role to play in our society. Their culture and traditions are rich. They have a lot to offer by way of family relationships and example both in consultation and in communication. It is a pity that the Minister, Mr Hand, did not choose to continue a negotiation process that would have ensured that the entire Australia community, and Aboriginal Australians, could have understood the new forms of administration that he has proposed. Instead, we will be left with a bastardised form of legislation that will not serve the purposes of Aboriginal Australians or the Australian community generally.
