If one goes back to that letter-I do not have a copy of it now but I would be happy to make it available to Senator Stone if he does not have one-one finds that I said then that, were Coronation Hill to be considered on its own, I would have no objection to it going ahead on the basis of the assessment done by my Department. I put that in black and white so that no-one could suggest that we would be hoodwinking anyone.

ANSWER.PARA: Coronation Hill is not to be considered on its own because of the impact upon it of El Sherana going ahead. The drilling program at El Sherana is a comparatively new thing. It has only been on in very recent times, but it has shown a highly promising deposit. If that deposit were to go ahead, the ore from El Sherana would be trucked into Coronation Hill and processed there. That would mean, at a minimum, a doubling of a number of facilities like tailings dams and storage dams, not to mention the processing facility itself. As well as that, one would have to look at the impact of an extraordinary number of trucks carrying not just the ore but, of course, the chemicals and equipment that would go into the processing.

They were the things that Cabinet was considering when Cabinet made its decision on Coronation Hill. In my view Cabinet quite rightly came to the view that Coronation Hill could not be considered on its own because of the impacts that were possible from El Sherana. Those impacts had not been examined. Within that strip which is being referred to Mr Justice Stewart are the prospects of not only Coronation Hill and El Sherana, but also a number of other sites. After his examination and that of his fellow commissioners, the Government will be in a position to know just what is entailed in the operation of Coronation Hill and we will be able to make the appropriate decision then in the light of that full knowledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and refer particularly to that part of it in which he informed the Senate that in the light of exploration in most recent times a `highly promising'-I think those were his words-mineral deposit has now been located at El Sherana, as distinct from the original Coronation Hill deposit. Will the Minister therefore explain to the Senate and thereby to the Australian people why the Government has taken it upon itself to lock away for the rest of time-that is, if it were left to this Government-almost 99 per cent of the so-called conservation zone in order that Australians will never know what other highly promising deposits are to be found in that part of what will now be national park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked why the Government has taken upon itself a decision to `lock away', as Senator Stone puts it, 99 per cent of the conservation zone. I will not quibble too much with the figure but I think it was 98 per cent. It will always be a difficult task to balance figures like $7 billion of potential as against the state of the environment and the importance of an area. To millions of Australians Kakadu has a very special importance, and rightly so.
—You do not know whether it is $7 billion or $77 billion.

—No, I do not know whether it is $7 billion. I think that is a speculative figure, but it is the figure upon which we were asked to work. One needs to look for a balance. If one looks at 98 per cent of the conservation zone, one is looking at practically all of the catchment area of the South Alligator River. The Fox inquiry recommended that the full catchment area be conserved. Cabinet had to weigh up the environmental values of the conservation zone against its dollar value or potential dollar value, whichever figure one wanted to believe. Rightly, Cabinet came down on the side of the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: On Sunday night when I was watching television I saw an advertisement to promote the Northern Territory. It was sponsored by the Northern Territory Government. It heavily promoted Kakadu. It heavily promoted the magnificent natural beauties of the Northern Territory. Not once did it suggest that anyone came to the Northern Territory to view mining. Not once did it suggest that it would be happy with mining trucks carrying tonnes of ore battling with tourists along the road from the South Alligator River. It concentrated, quite rightly, on the magnificent natural values of the area. I suggest to Senator Stone that, like the Tourist Bureau of the Northern Territory, he look at these values as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's position on the reported declaration of 33 Australian members of parliament expressing support for the request of Bishop Belo for a referendum on self-determination in East Timor? What is the Government's position on the latest allegations of brutality and torture in East Timor following the Pope's visit? Would cutting diplomatic relations with Indonesia, as some groups in the Australian community are reportedly demanding, enable Australian concerns on the human rights situation in East Timor to be registered with Indonesia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister's statement to Parliament on 22 August 1985 confirmed that the Australian Government recognises the sovereign authority of Indonesia over East Timor, though it does not condone the manner in which the province was incorporated into Indonesia. The reported declaration of 33 Australian members of parliament lending their support to the request by Bishop Belo for a referendum on self-determination in East Timor does not therefore reflect the Australian Government's view. In the statement on 22 August 1985 the Prime Minister also affirmed that Australia would continue to raise questions of human rights in East Timor. Since that time the Government has continued to make known to the Indonesian Government Australia's concerns that internationally accepted standards of human rights be universally observed. Specifically, the Government has pursued Australia's legitimate interest in the human rights situation in East Timor through raising with Indonesian Ministers concerns about human rights abuses and regular visits to the province by the Australian Embassy in Jakarta.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the allegations of brutality and torture following the Pope's visit to Indonesia, including East Timor, in the period 9 to 14 October, our Ambassador in Jakarta will visit East Timor in the period 19 to 27 October. The visit will provide the opportunity to examine and raise a number of issues with the authorities in the province and remind them of the continuing interest of Australia in developments there. The Ambassador is being instructed, in particular, to report on these recent allegations of human rights abuses. There have been other allegations concerning East Timor in the recent past which the Government has investigated fully and found to have been inaccurate and exaggerated. The Government remains firmly of the view that the only effective way of pursuing Australia's interests in East Timor is through our diplomatic relations with Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women support moves to increase the status of women in Australia and internationally? In particular, does the Minister believe that increasing women's participation in the work force at all levels, including within the political system, improves the status of women? Does the Minister agree that many countries in the world still regard women as second-class citizens whose status is less than men's? If she does, will she agree that Australia has a responsibility to promote the issue of the increased status of women on both national and international stages? If the Minister and her Government support these things, can she explain why the Australian Government has decided not to sponsor an official delegation to the Inter-parliamentary Symposium on the Participation of Women in the Political and Parliamentary Decision-making Process to be held in Geneva from 20 to 24 November this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government and I agree with the first parts of Senator Haines's question. This Government has done more than any other government in Australian history to promote the status of women. I know that this view is not shared by the Opposition, but it is quite clear from the work that has been done by my Government-work that has been recognised in international forums-that the Australian Government has been the first to implement the United Nations forward-looking strategies in its National Agenda for Women and thus that the Government has a very strong and convincing record.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines asked about the decision not to sponsor a delegation to a forum in Geneva. I will have to ask my colleague Senator Evans about that because I do not have any information about the delegation. I take the opportunity to say that what Australia is doing, with the support of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-in particular, with the support of my colleague, Senator Evans-is, in conjunction with New Zealand, hosting a CEDAW conference--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that?

—I am sorry that I did not spell it out for Senator Bishop. That forum will be sponsored by the Australian and New Zealand governments in the Pacific in 1990. As Senator Haines indicated, we do recognise that not all countries do have the very fine record that Australia has but, in stating that, I would certainly not boast that there is not a lot more that the Australian Government can do. We have made tremendous advances in nearly seven years and I am proud to be associated with those advances. As I am sure Senator Haines would agree, when one comes to raising the status of women in any society, be it Australia or any other country of the world, there is certainly a great deal of discrimination and practices that have built up over many years that need to be changed on a gradual basis.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to Senator Haines's question, yes, I totally agree with her premise that we have a responsibility. Because we have made so many advances we do have a responsibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh; sit down!

—I am sorry that Senator Vanstone is not interested in the question of the status of women. She used to be; in fact, she told a Liberal women's conference that we had a great deal in common only about 12 months ago. I will seek more information for Senator Haines on the question she asked in relation to the decision not to sponsor a delegation, but I certainly welcome the fact that in conjunction with New Zealand we will be sponsoring the CEDAW conference for the United Nations in 1990.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's somewhat inadequate response to my question, could she explain why, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, she is not aware of a conference of this importance? Why has she not been party to the decision made, apparently by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and recently announced by the Speaker of the House of Representatives?

—As I have said before in this place, the Hawke Government is committed to the status of women. It has a Prime Minister who is committed to the status of women, it has all Ministers committed to the status of women, and all Ministers have a responsibility within their portfolios. Obviously the question Senator Haines asks relates particularly to the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is quite in order that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, knowing that the Australian Government is hosting a conference within the region-I would have thought that it is important that we are hosting a conference in the region-made this decision. I am quite comfortable with the fact that Senator Evans, knowing that we are already initiating a conference within the region, made this decision and I do not see any contradiction at all.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to the fact that this Thursday, 19 October 1989, signals the tenth anniversary of the establishment of the Australian Federal Police (AFP). Can the Minister acknowledge the contribution of the Australian Federal Police to the Federal law enforcement effort in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are times when one has to travel abroad really to appreciate the virtues of living in this country. After travelling abroad during the winter recess and talking with law enforcement agencies in Europe, the United States and elsewhere, I came back greatly reassured at the very evident high standing in which the Australian Federal Police is held by its colleagues in many nations overseas. I believe that that very high standing has been earned by the taking of innovative steps over the last decade since its formation so that it can carry out the mandate and the challenge which has been placed before it by this Parliament and by successive governments.

ANSWER.PARA: The 10 years of work have occurred under three commissioners-Sir Colin Woods initially, Major-General Grey, and now Mr Peter McAulay. Each commissioner has brought very distinctive abilities to the task of forming and refocusing the Federal Police in attaining its objectives. I will mention only two areas where I believe it has been innovative: first, the placing of overseas liaison officers in our embassies abroad has enabled the Australian Federal Police-I believe in a way which is cost-effective, but also requires courage and perseverance on the part of those officers placed abroad-to gather intelligence and information, particularly in relation to drug trafficking into Australia, which has enabled us to become aware of those who want to peddle and traffic those drugs down to Australia. We have been able to nip some of those operations in the bud; break up syndicates. Sometimes we allow the drug in, then put it under surveillance, following either the container to a warehouse or the passenger through an airline terminal to a hotel room, and find the persons who were going to be the first distributors within Australia. This has been a very effective method indeed of policing in relation to drug trafficking.

To take another example in relation to the Australian Capital Territory and its community policing, once again I have been able to reach a general agreement with the new Chief Minister of the Territory to enable the Federal Police to draw on its nationwide pool of very talented men and women to enable the local community in the Australian Capital Territory to get the best possible policing service on a model which is akin to the way in which the Canadian Mounties operate in relation to various provinces and cities throughout Canada. I believe the particular adaptation of that model indicates once again how the Federal Police is really focusing on being quite creative in the sorts of ways in which it provides policing, in this case not only to the local community in the Australian Capital Territory, but also nationwide in its responsibilities as it earns the title of the premier law enforcement agency in Australia and certainly becomes the leading investigative agency in the Commonwealth.

I know that the Prime Minister has written to the Commissioner offering the Government's congratulations. I certainly join him and wish the AFP success in its next decade. Its success will be a measure of our success as we remain a free, democratic and civilised society where the adherence to the laws promulgated by our parliaments and courts is guaranteed. I firmly believe that the AFP-by that I suppose I really mean the several thousand men and women throughout Australia, both police and staff members, who I continually meet while travelling around Australia and who give their service-can meet the challenge of its next decade with great distinction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and also relates to Coronation Hill. I hope it will not be treated with the ignorant and misleading type of answer given earlier to Senator Stone. I ask whether the Minister's Department received a report or letter on the proposed mining development at Coronation Hill from Dr Roy Green of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Institute of Natural Resources and Environment which, in part, stated:

QUESTION.PARA: To make the CSIRO position clear, at no stage have we opposed mining at Coronation Hill.

I ask further: Does the Minister acknowledge that this is the view of the CSIRO Institute? Does he accept the CSIRO view that mining could be undertaken at Coronation Hill in an environmentally acceptable fashion? Will he make public the full text of Dr Green's letter, which has been reported selectively in the press?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —When it comes to ignorance and a capacity to mislead, Senator Tambling is a champion; I am but a novice. However, Dr Green's letter has been fairly well leaked in the press. I am not sure whether there are any parts of it left to be made public, but I will have a look and if anything is left out I will let Senator Tambling know whether it can be released. It certainly would not be just a matter for me; I would have to consult Dr Green and his Minister, but I will have a look at that.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think I have ever pretended that CSIRO gave a report to me orally or in writing that it opposed mining. I have never claimed that it did. All I have claimed is that CSIRO, again in a very well publicised report, pointed out the environmental sensitivity of the area and the endangered endemic species there-and did so very well. My own Department did not oppose mining at Coronation Hill if it was considered to be a one-off event either. I am not making a claim that it has in some way opposed it; so I do not see any reason to be concerned by the honourable senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to an article in the Australian Financial Review of Friday 13 October entitled `Government services to be contracted out'. In that article the Opposition shadow Treasurer stated that a 20 per cent saving could be made by contracting out such items as security for government buildings. Will the Minister tell the Senate what the current position is with security in government buildings and whether savings of this order are achievable and compatible with security and government obligations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the security services in government buildings and installations are currently provided by private contractors appointed through a public tender process. The Australian Protective Service (APS) provides security and guarding services under the following criteria: firstly, the fulfilment of security aspects of international obligations, such as protecting embassies, visiting dignitaries, et cetera; secondly, protection of the highest political institutions and public offices of the Commonwealth, such as Parliament House, the Lodge, Kirribilli House, et cetera; and, thirdly, the prevention of access to sensitive national security and law enforcement information and sensitive dangerous materials, such as defence facilities, the National Crime Authority, et cetera. Finally, it looks after the custody of certain persons such as immigrants in immigration detention centres, et cetera. Those specific criteria require the services of the Australian Protective Service. In most instances those services cannot be carried out by private contractors because these functions require very rigorous selection procedures and security clearances, a high standard of training, unequivocal powers of arrest and search, ready access to backup information from other Federal agencies and State police and experience and understanding necessary to deal sensitively with security incidents and demonstrations. We need a permanent and reliable work force and sufficient resources to allow flexible deployment. The Australian Protective Service operates on a fully commercial basis, charging clients the full amount for its services in order to avoid overservicing and to ration resources effectively. Contracting out in the areas currently covered by APS would compromise security and leave Australia open to charges of human rights abuse and dereliction of international obligations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources, who has primary responsibility for dealing with the mining industry. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the comment recently made by one proponent in the environment debate:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no greedier, more impossible to satisfy group in our society than the mining industry. They are unbelievable. They want every square inch of our country . . .
Does the Minister accept this characterisation of the mining industry as insatiable, greedy, unbelievable and wanting every square inch of our country?

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept certainly that some spokespeople for the mining industry could be rightly characterised in the terms that Senator Puplick used. But I do not accept it as a description of the entire industry. The reason for that is that I believe that the Australian Mining Industry Council, the peak body representing the industry, has embraced the concept of sustainable development. Indeed, my understanding is that the Executive Director of that Council, Lauchlan McIntosh, has just recently met the Norwegian Prime Minister, Madam Brundtland, the author of the Brundtland report of the United Nations World Commission on Environment and Development, which sets out the parameters for sustainable development. The Council advocates, as a central council on behalf of the industry, that line. When there are major mineral developments in prospect, it seeks to have environmental impact surveys properly conducted and to have an obligation on miners at the completion of mining to rehabilitate the mine site. However, like all organisations, it represents a general view. It does not represent all viewpoints and it is true to say that some spokesmen for the mining industry have made comments worthy of the description that Senator Puplick has given.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. On the basis that the Minister says that he does not accept that those comments are an accurate description of the industry as a whole, will he convey his views to Senator Richardson, who is the author of those remarks?

—This is a cheap shot. When I answered the question, I was aware who the author of the remarks was. The author of those remarks made them within a special context on a special issue relating to the activities of a particular company. Senator Puplick can play this game across the chamber, we will all be entertained and spend a bit of time on it, but, in terms of contributing to the public debate on a serious issue including development and environment, it rates about zilch.

—I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women to last Friday's Australian Financial Review which stated that Canberra's porn king, Mr Lark, would be applying to the Federal Government for taxpayer subsidisation of the marketing costs of his exports of X-rated videos. Has the Minister noted that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material in its majority report found that such videos treat women as `sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience' and `reduce persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure' and cited evidence that such videos engender `sexually calloused and manipulative orientation towards women'? Does she agree that an application for taxpayers' funds to market Australian-made hard-core pornographic videos is a contentious issue and that the status of Australian women, as well as Australia's international image, is at stake? What action does the Minister intend to take to ensure that the Government prevents the export of X-rated videos which sully the image and degrade the status of Australian women in the eyes of the world?
—I did read the press report to which Senator Harradine refers. I also read that it is estimated that one-third of those seeking to hire videos of the type that Senator Harradine describes are women.
—That is the argument that he has used.

—I accept that that is his side of the argument. This is an extremely contentious and controversial issue and I have heard both sides of the argument from a number of different groups in the community. Of course, the specific question that Senator Harradine raises should quite properly be directed to either me or Senator Button. But it was Senator Button who was quoted in the article as indicating that it was being processed in the normal way. Before Senator Harradine's question, I had made a note to discuss the issue with Senator Button because I appreciate the extreme sensitivity of the issue in the community, and I will do that.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to press reports that pineapples valued at more than $1m, representing about 8,000 to 10,000 tonnes of fruit, were left to rot on Queensland farms because of a market glut triggered by cheap Asian imports. In view of the fact that imports of canned pineapples from countries such as Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines have jumped 50 per cent in the past year to the equivalent of about 25,000 tonnes of fresh fruit, would the Minister consider supporting the industry in mounting a case to have dumping duties imposed on these imports?

—It is not my function to take dumping complaints about a particular product which has been imported. That is the function of the industry concerned. Mechanisms are available to the industry if it wants to take those steps. In so far as whether the allegations contained in the honourable senator's question are correct, I did have some information about this because Senator Bjelke-Petersen's colleague Senator Boswell asked me some questions about this matter a few weeks ago. At that time I gave him an answer. As I understand the nature of the imports, a large number of them are from the Philippines and are a result of very heavy investment by United States companies in pineapple growing in the Philippines.
—And Indonesia.

—I do not know about Indonesia, but I know it is happening in the Philippines. Inevitably there will be market pressures from those countries where those sorts of activities such as the growing of pineapples take place in environments which are entirely suitable for that type of agricultural activity. As of a few weeks ago the pressures on the industry, although obvious and significant, were not as large as is suggested in the honourable senator's question. I will have a look at that and--
—Why don't you read my speech? It was a very good speech and it will inform you about the matter.

—Senator Boswell says that he has made a speech about it. That may be the source of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's information. If Senator Boswell's speech is the source of her information I really will have to check that out. I would be very sceptical about that. When Senator Boswell makes occasional visits to the pineapple growing areas of Queensland he makes speeches like that and they should be thoroughly checked.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security confirm that the number of people receiving the unemployment benefit has fallen progressively since the Hawke Government came to office so that the unemployed now represent 6 per cent of the work force compared with over 10 per cent at the end of the Fraser Government's term of office? How has the Government achieved this fall? How does its approach compare with that proposed by the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that as of last Friday the number of people receiving the unemployment benefit and the Jobsearch allowance had fallen to 363,313. This is a remarkable achievement, given the peak number of 635,000 people who were in receipt of the benefit in 1984.
—Would you like to table the speech?

—Senator Stone makes another gratuitous comment. I will refer to him in a second. The Government recognises that there are two factors which obviously influence unemployment benefit numbers. One is the state of the labour market and the other is the integrity of the administration of the work test. The Government has used both these measures in its last six years in office. We can compare this to the way in which the Opposition has abused those measures in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: It is informative to look at the numbers from 1981 to 1983. Because of the labour market collapse in that period, there was a massive increase in unemployment numbers. Not only was there a labour market collapse but also administrative controls were removed. It is no surprise that Senator Stone has intervened because he was the principal economic adviser to the former Government. The other two players who were as important were Dr Hewson, who was the Fraser Government's alternative economic adviser at the time, and Senator Chaney, who managed the social security policies and who was responsible for the integrity of the administration of the work test.

In essence, our policy differs from that of the past in that Senator Stone and Dr Hewson set out to control inflation in the only way that they could without a wages policy-by driving the economy into a recession. We are not in the business of doing that. At that time Senator Chaney, responsible as he then was for the administration of the work test, took the approach that the Opposition wants to take again. He was responsible for abolishing the lodgment of fortnightly continuation forms and for abolishing the requirement for unemployment beneficiaries to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). Because of the pressure applied by Dr Hewson and Senator Stone, Senator Chaney found it all too hard then. This is not the policy response of this Government. Our policy approach is fundamentally different. Fiscal, wages, monetary and social policies, as well as employment and training policies, have been meshed together and directed towards creating jobs and helping Australians to find work. We reject policies that say that we need unemployment to control inflation. We have re-established the integrity of the unemployment benefit system.

In regard to this year's Budget, the Minister for Social Security published a booklet which lists the measures we have taken in the administration of the unemployment benefit. I will table the document for Senator Stone and Senator Chaney. I will go through some of the important ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are going to table it, read it.

—It is quite apparent that if the Opposition, particularly Senator Stone, took time actually to listen to this part of my reply, the sort of policy they would come up with in the future might be different from what Senator Stone has come up with in the past. We have reintroduced the requirement to register with the CES and the personal lodgment of benefit continuation forms. We have also tightened other aspects of the unemployment benefit administration. For example, we have deployed 20 mobile unemployment benefit review teams. Ten were announced in the last Budget. We introduced work intention forms to ensure that applicants genuinely seek work, and so on. As I said, they are all listed in this booklet. In summary, the full detail of our measures runs to over 30 pages. As I said, I will table it for the information--
—Read it! Read it!

—I will table it for the information of all senators, particularly for Senator Chaney and Senator Stone. An important measure we undertook was the introduction of the Newstart program which is a most intensive review program and one that is getting people back into the work force. Another vitally important aspect of the policy-and I am sure the Opposition does not want to hear this-was pointed out by Senator Walsh last month. If Australia today had the same labour market that we had under Senator Stone, Dr Hewson and Senator Chaney, in 1983, we would have to spend an extra $3.2 billion on the social security system every year in order to meet the cost of the unemployment benefit. The question is: Are we now faced with a new policy direction from the Opposition? What the Opposition is saying in essence is that it will return to the Hewson-Stone-Chaney prescription, with a deregulated labour market and no effective wages policy--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. This is Question Time and the Government is meant to be expressing its own policy and not trying to elucidate what ours is. We can do very well on our own, thank you.
—Order! Senator Bolkus's answer is relevant to the question. I do think his answer is excessively long. It would help if he would conclude fairly quickly.

—Mr Deputy President, I am surprised that you think that; but, in deference to you, I will conclude quickly. I say to Senator Bishop-who is ungraciously referred to as Eva-that I will table this 30- page document, rather than go through it in detail, so that she can see what the Government's policy is. As I said, we have one prescription from the Opposition and that is a recessionary one. When we look at the administrative measures to control unemployment, to control social security, we see the all-too-hard approach being applied.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Opposition's policies, people who have been receiving the benefit for nine months will transfer to special benefit. So, once again, we have a policy that drops the statutory requirements, firstly, for personal lodgment of continuation forms and, secondly, for registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service by those who apply for the unemployment benefit. Those requirements will be dropped under the Opposition's policy which transfers people to special benefit after nine months. Once again, the Opposition had not done its work and thought through its policy or the administrative details. As I have said, Labor's policy makes rational responses to the problem; it is not built on prejudice and irrationality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the next questioner, I draw the attention of the Senate, and Ministers in particular, to the length of answers. The purpose of Question Time is to get succinct answers to questions and I do not think that has always been achieved today.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the reply that he gave to a question asked earlier today by Senator Lewis. Senator Button said, in effect, that he had had some discussion with Mr Kerin about his comments and he was certain that Mr Kerin accepted the principle of Cabinet solidarity. Does this mean that Mr Kerin now admits that he was wrong in what he said and did? Has he given an undertaking not to repeat these comments? Has he been warned that he should not do so in accordance with the principle of Cabinet solidarity and that this could result in dismissal? Did the Prime Minister authorise Senator Button to discuss this matter with Mr Kerin? Has he taken, or does he propose to take, any steps in relation to the matter?
—Good question!

—It is a good question but it really goes to all sorts of matters which I am not disposed to answer. I am not here to provide information about who said what to whom on every conceivable topic and I will not do so. I have had a discussion with Mr Kerin about it and the Prime Minister has had a discussion with Mr Kerin about it and that is all I have to say on the matter.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, relates to Cambodia's representation at the United Nations (UN). Since the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia and the heightening of both local and international fears that the Khmer Rouge forces will regain military control in that war-torn country, the presence of the Pol Pot representative in the United Nations seat is seen by many as a gross insult to the majority of Cambodian people. As Australia is on the Credentials Committee of the United Nations this year, I ask the Minister whether the Government is doing anything to challenge the credentials of the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea to hold the Cambodia seat at the United Nations when the CGDK consists of three factions, including the Khmer Rouge, and holds little, if any, territory within Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cambodia seat at the UN is held by Democratic Kampuchea, the government of which is the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea. The CGDK comprises the Khmer Rouge, the Funcinpec group led by Prince Sihanouk and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by Mr Son Sann. The head of the CGDK delegation at the United Nations is a member of the Khmer Rouge faction. Australia has never accepted the claims of the CGDK or the Phnom Penh regime led by Hun Sen to be the government of Cambodia. There has been no challenge to CGDK credentials since 1982. On that occasion Australia abstained in the ensuing vote. There are no indications so far that a challenge will be mounted in the current session of the UN General Assembly. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Lewis proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the Liberal and National Parties' Economic Action Plan to relieve the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian economy is about to enter its most difficult period since the Second World War. When we get into government the Liberal and National parties will be facing the problems of a nation suffering from the highest taxes ever, high inflation, high interest rates, high domestic demand, a massive overseas debt and imports exceeding exports by about $2 billion a month.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no world recession, as there was in 1982. There is no Australia-wide drought, as there was in 1982. Our commodity prices are currently at very high levels; indeed, some have been at record levels. In short, there is no excuse for our current economic crisis. Clearly, this crisis is the direct fault of the policies, or lack of policies, of this Labor Government. The Government's snake oil remedies-the accord, Priority One, the promise that no child will live in poverty by 1990 and other shoddy high-profile gimmicks-have all failed because they did not address the basic problems of the economy. The public is now aware that they were snake oil remedies and is dissatisfied with the expensively advertised product.

The economic mismanagement of the Hawke-Keating Government has left Australia with a legacy of debt, the servicing of which has already mortgaged the future of all Australians. Indeed, the simple fact is that the accord and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have hamstrung the Government so that it cannot attack inflation. It cannot cut further into public expenditure; it is unable to fix up the waterfront or coastal shipping; it is unable to privatise public enterprises; it is unable to reduce the burdens on business; and it is unable to free up the labour market.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) continues to engineer high interest rates in the hope that this will delay the crisis long enough to enable the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to call an election. Home owners in Australia continue to be sacrificed to this policy. Small business continues to be sacrificed and manufacturers continue to be sacrificed all because this Government is unwilling or unable to address the real problems of the nation.

The coalition's Economic Action Plan is the most detailed and comprehensive economic policy document ever prepared by an opposition party, which puts it in sharp contrast to the hotch-potch of proposals put forward as the policies in the Australian Labor Party's platform speech in 1983. This action plan, with supplementary notes on expenditure decisions, runs to many pages and addresses the basic problems of the economy so that by the end of our first term in government tax rates will be cut, interest rates will be lower, government will be smaller, inflation will be reduced, productivity and real wages will be higher, growth in foreign debt will be brought under control, and fraud and abuse of government programs will be reduced.

Tough decisions have not been shirked and that is in marked contrast to this Government which has failed to match its rhetoric by pursuing a genuine broad-based program of micro-economic reform. Senator Bolkus is to follow me in this debate. I will be interested to hear him set out where the Government has followed any broad-based micro-economic reform. In 1987 this Government said that micro-economic reform would be the key to its policy program. What have we had? Nothing except an attack on one area of primary industry in relation to micro-economic reform. All the tough decisions have been dodged.

Honourable senators should look at what is happening on the waterfront at the moment. This Government is dodging the issue of trying to bring about some reform on the waterfront and with coastal shipping. Where is the equity? Where is the tough mindedness in the actions of this Government? What is equitable about giving unlimited millions of dollars to a couple of rich mates in the airline industry? Senator Bolkus should answer that question in his speech. What is equitable about giving these people millions of dollars? What is equitable about using $60m of taxpayers' money to buy off an American company in the Prime Minister's seat of Wills? What is equitable about giving $200m to the four big banks? What is equitable about the $160,000-each average redundancy package given to waterside workers without any guarantees of major reform or increased productivity? What is tough minded about any of these decisions?

The Australian economy is currently teetering on the edge of an economic abyss. This Government is using taxpayers' funds to try temporarily to buy its way out of its problems. At the same time it keeps its fingers crossed and keeps touching wood looking for some lucky way out. The Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan will end Labor's tax rip-off. We have undertaken to hand back the increase in revenue from bracket creep. That is a very significant discipline to impose upon ourselves. We should contrast this with Mr Keating who is openly acknowledging at present that this year his taxes will claw back 50 per cent of the recent tax cuts.

Our package recognises the forgotten people of Australia-the families-and the economic burdens of raising a family under the Hawke Government. It seeks to ease those economic burdens which are at the centre of so many family crises and marriage break-ups. Honourable senators can ask families what has happened to their weekly shopping budget or any other item of their household budget under the Hawke-Keating Government. The average Australian family is really battling under the high interest rate policies of this Government. Inflation and interest rates are well in excess of our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development counterparts. Our program seeks to remedy this huge burden on families as a priority. One of the most common complaints heard today is, `If I work harder and earn more the Government grabs it all back'. There is no incentive from this Government. All this Government is interested in doing is lowering everyone down to some common denominator. Our program seeks to remedy this huge burden on families as a priority. Our policy addresses this and gives a commitment to give back money from bracket creep and eventually to have a two-tiered tax system.

The problems of small business, which provides the bulk of employment in Australia, are also recognised. Small business will welcome the replacement of Labor's capital gains tax with a speculative gains tax. The glib Government response to this Economic Action Plan-we have heard Senator Bolkus during Question Time trying to come out with these sorts of glib responses-is that it is divisive and an attack on the poor, the Aboriginal people and the underprivileged. Those allegations are simply not true. Hardworking people will be delighted with the decision to finally end the waste of their taxes on hand-outs to people who just abuse the system. After nine months on the dole under a coalition government people will have to prove why further benefits should continue. But those benefits will be available as a safety net if they can establish their entitlement to them. There are people who have abused the system at the taxpayer's expense. A Liberal-National Party government will be cracking down on them.

Migrants coming to work in Australia-that is, excluding refugees-should be expected to support themselves for at least 12 months. We will ensure that they do so. Illegal migrants should not be entitled to any benefits and we will make sure that they do not receive them. Certainly our program attacks the wastes and inefficiencies of the administration of Aboriginal affairs but this will be to the benefit of the Aboriginal people of Australia. Claims that the plan involves an attack on welfare are nonsense. All the existing welfare programs for low income families have been left intact. I wonder how Senator Bolkus will respond to that statement. The elderly are also protected and receive some genuine benefits. The assets test will be made fairer. People who delay their retirement age will have their age pensions increased and pensions will be indexed and paid on time. Under our new superannuation scheme no tax will be paid on lump sum entitlements up to $125,000, whereas under Labor anything over $60,000 is taxed.

The whole policy package provided by the Liberal and National parties eases the pressure on families, protects the elderly, gives small business a fair go and stops people rorting the system. It is a thoughtful, caring package and it is fully funded by cuts in expenditure-not like the Treasurer's recent unfunded tax cuts.

That is only the revenue and expenditure side of the package, the side which gains the most publicity. The really crucial side is that part of the package which deals with our economic policies-our economic liberalisation process. Here we address the fundamental economic problems of the nation. The cornerstone of our strategy is a coordinated approach to economic reform, getting the basics right to improve the general economic environment and create a more productive and fairer Australia. Industry problems are addressed, with the introduction of greater flexibility into the labour market; reform of the waterfront, coastal shipping and transport services; the promotion of real competition in industry, for example, communications; a reduction in the regulatory burden and business on-costs and incentives to work and to invest.

We have been saying for two years in this Senate chamber that these are the areas to which the Government needs to address its mind. Under the Hawke Government we have seen nothing other than reports, with committees set up to inquire into matters, but no fundamental restructuring. Nothing is happening with regard to the restructuring of the labour market or the waterfront. There is some talk about a package of about $160,000 to members of the waterfront industry to retire but no talk about what they will do to increase their productivity. We have been talking to the Government about real competition in this industry. Earlier this year the Government had an opportunity to introduce real competition in the communications industry. What did it do? It dodged the issue. The Government established a Business Regulation Review Unit but it starved it of staff-I think there is a maximum number of only six on its staff. It has not bothered to implement any of the recommendations which have come from that Business Regulation Review Unit. When we get into office we will make sure that the Unit is freed up from oppressive government interference with its recommendations.

Business on-costs are a great disincentive to manufacturers in Australia but how will we turn around the $2 billion deficit occurring each month-the deficit between our imports and our exports-unless business is encouraged? Our economic policy directs itself to that. The proceeds of the sale of 12 Commonwealth enterprises will be used to reduce the public debt. We believe that a vigorous, competitive and internationally oriented manufacturing sector is absolutely fundamental to the future prosperity of Australia and the restoration of our living standards. Protection will be reduced further to accelerate the pace of adjustment. Our plan will be an integrated one to improve production and productivity and to reduce inflation so that we can trade our way out of our difficulties.

The Reserve Bank of Australia in its most recent annual report said that changes at the micro-economic level were `essential if we are to avoid a re-emergence in the next upswing of the problems of the past year'. We have addressed the micro-economic changes referred to in the Reserve Bank's report. But the Reserve Bank went on further and said:

. . . but the vital key is inflation. Restructuring is much more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment which destroys competitiveness and discourages saving. Altering this situation must have top priority.

That is the priority we have given it. We are determined to attack inflation. We have announced that we will bolster the independence of the Reserve Bank to help us in this attack. A monetary policy pursued steadily over the medium term in conjunction with our industrial relations, fiscal and structural policies provides the only means of reducing inflation and hence interest rates. That is what ultimately it will lead to. I will say that again so that it is perfectly clear: our policy to reduce interest rates is monetary policy pursued steadily over the medium term in conjunction with our industrial relations liberalisation and our fiscal and structural policies which will provide the means of reducing inflation and hence ultimately reducing interest rates. Interest rates will no longer have to be kept at record and punitive levels as this Government has done to cover up lack of action in other areas. Home buyers and small business operators no longer will have to pay a heavy price for the policy failures of the Government being unable to deliver the right economic strategy.

Our commitments and our integrated policy package stand in sharp contrast to the Hawke-Keating Government's current abysmal performance. With the basics right, the coalition package provides a basis for sustained national recovery and a more productive and fairer Australia. It is clear now that the Liberal Party is the party of low taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the National Party?

—I apologise, the Liberal and National parties are the parties of low taxation. Taxpayers will not be forced into higher tax brackets because of inflation. We will hand back the money Labor would steal. We will not squander the taxpayer's money in the way this Government has done. Forgoing the increase in revenue from bracket creep is the most significant discipline ever imposed on a government.

SPEECH.PARA: We will provide long overdue support for families, especially those with children. The Hawke-Keating Government does not care about collapsing living standards. We do. We are taking action about it. Our child care tax rebates are a break for working women-for those who want to work and those who are forced into the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should have been done years ago.

—Of course it should have been done years ago. Abolishing the capital gains tax will provide a lasting future for small business in particular-not like the Labor rip-off. We are taking direct and tough action to ensure that people on welfare benefits who have the capacity to work are encouraged to do so. The unemployment benefit will cut out after nine months. The lazy will no longer be able to avoid working for a living and depend on hardworking Australians. All Australians will applaud the move to stop rip-offs in the welfare system. The elderly will be fully supported and encouraged by a coalition government with an end to compulsory retirement and superannuation becoming a savings plan.

SPEECH.PARA: The dream of all Australians is to buy a home. Our policies will get down high interest rates. Labor's huge foreign debt is a millstone around our children's necks. Our policies will bring foreign debt under control and begin to wind it back. As I said before, our main attack is on an economic basis. Once we get the basics right the coalition package will provide a basis for sustained national recovery and a more productive and fairer Australia for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of those who may be listening, it is probably worth while reciting the words of the matter of public importance this afternoon because I am sure that after the last speech they might be a bit lost as to its content. The matter of public importance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the Liberal and National Parties' Economic Action Plan to relieve the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery.

What has the Government been asked to do? It has been asked to endorse an economic policy which is no more than a black hole-a con job. It is a black hole in more ways than one. It is a black hole because, no matter how hard one seeks one will not find the economics in the policy. Where is the tax policy costed? Where is the fiscal policy addressed? Where is the monetary policy addressed? Where is the wages policy spelt out? It is a black hole for rational and economic thinking. Where is the costing of the Opposition's bracket creep policy and who will pay for it and how and when? It is a black hole for the millions of Australian families who will suffer because it leads to the only policy that Senator Stone knows, and that is the policy of the short, sharp shock-a recession.

There is no targeting of the poor in our community and, because of the general sweep of the policy direction, the poor will miss out. What about the migrants? It is very easy to target the migrants, but they will be disadvantaged, as will the long term unemployed. As Steve Burrell wrote in the Australian Financial Review the other day, this policy requires a leap in faith from the community. The Opposition want us to leap with it into an uncertain future; it wants the Australian people to sign a blank cheque.

We have waited a 2 1/2-year gestation period for this policy. Andrew Peacock was expected to bite the bullet but by this policy he has shown that he could not even make an impression on a cream puff. Who is here today to spell out this policy but Senator Lewis. Poor old Senator Lewis-Mr 5 per cent. He has absolutely no credibility when it comes to dealing with the major economic issues facing Australia today, but he had to raise the issue in the Senate this afternoon. I remind the Senate that it was Senator Lewis who so confidently predicted in August this year that during the first term of a Peacock Government interest rates could be expected to fall to 5 per cent. Having then displayed his ignorance of economic matters and having so thoroughly embarrassed his coalition colleagues, he has the temerity to stand here today and pretend that the Opposition can deliver an economic plan which will achieve something positive for Australia. He does not understand economics, has shown that he does not understand economics, and his colleagues have recognised that.

Let us look at the issues which the Opposition promises to tackle in its Claytons tax policy-the tax policy you have when you do not bother to address taxation issues. It was only a few weeks ago that Mr Peacock announced in his mock election campaign-and one wonders whether he will call this a mock campaign in a few weeks time-the `bold initiative' of inflation adjustment which would `cut to the heart of one of the most critical problems we have in Australia'. If the problem is so critical, why was he rolled? Where is inflation adjustment in this policy? Senator Stone knows where it is-he rolled him.

Another member of the committee was Dr Hewson. Dr Hewson came into this committee system with grand plans for a broadly-based consumption tax, and he canvassed them widely at the weekend. Where did his plans go? They were rolled by the committee as well. Senator Chaney, happy now to accept this vicious slug on Australian Aborigines and struggling families, came to the committee wanting a wages policy. That is not spelt out in this policy. He also came with a long history of targeting welfare. I quote Senator Chaney in 1982, when he said:

If one can isolate those who generally need assistance one can provide assistance to them. The job is possible. However, on the other hand, if one tries to apply a broad blanket measure to the whole population of Australia it is unlikely that any success will be achieved.

Where was Senator Chaney when this policy was devolved? This is a blanket plan. Has he given up on fighting poverty? It is quite apparent, from what he believes and what this policy is about, that Senator Chaney has either given up or he, too, was rolled.

Then there is Senator Lewis-the doyen of kindergarten economics-who was obviously prejudged by his colleagues as having not much of an understanding about economic measures. He was simply left out. In the Australian, dated 14 October, Laura Tingle wrote:

The `kitchen Cabinet' comprises Mr Peacock, Dr Hewson, Senator John Stone, Mr Charles Blunt and Senator Fred Chaney. Senator Austin Lewis also plays a role, but does not have the same economic credentials as other members of the group.

What a field to run last in. Who, then, was the winner? It is quite obvious that the economics committee of the Opposition was well and truly stoned, because all that is left in this policy are the politics of the Stone-age of Senator John Stone. This policy is going back to pre-1983. Senator Stone is the winner. The rationality and prejudice are part of his philosophy. That is what he talked about on radio last week. He said, `This package is about some philosophy'. Senator Stone's blatant attack on the social justice and social security policies of this Government last Friday spelt out what the real agenda of this Opposition is. It is not, as he and others might claim, about helping families. The result of this policy-the result of the short, sharp shock-will be a direct and vicious attack on family life in Australia. If one really wants to help families one targets, as Senator Chaney said. This policy is not about targeting.

Who will benefit? It is quite obvious that the coalition's rich mates will benefit-families like the Hewsons will be better off-but ordinary Australians will be made to suffer more and more and face harder times. The trouble is, it doesn't feel like a gift-it feels like a bribe.
