That is what this policy is all about. It is also about the politics of economic disaster, because it is certainly not a comprehensive policy. Where is fiscal policy addressed in any decent, comprehensive way? Where is tax policy adequately covered? Where is monetary policy adequately covered? It is certainly not a wages policy. What is more, no-one in Australia believes that this is a relevant and appropriate social policy.

As I said, the document which we have been asked by Senator Lewis to implement started life 2 1/2 years ago as a tax policy, but it is a tax policy with no fine print. It is a tax policy without costings for its key elements, and without costings there cannot be firm commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Can Senator Stone tell me how the Opposition will pay for bracket creep in the next financial year? The Opposition has not costed that and told us what cuts will be made to pay for it. Senator Stone will not admit that. I ask how the Opposition will do that. This goes back to the edicts of Senator Stone and Mr Peacock that the Opposition would not give comprehensive listings of cutbacks before the election. This is a deceptive document, and to that extent Senator Stone acknowledges that it is. There are no firm costings about how the bracket creep policy will be paid for. It is a tax policy without costings and, consequently, cannot be treated seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: We are promised a flatter tax system, but where is it? What are the scales? Again, what are the costings? We are promised indexed bracket creep. Once again, who will pay? That is the major question we have to ask when we are talking about extra funding and measures in this area. We were told it would be a radical fiscal policy, but its surplus would probably not be lower than what we have got now. In fact, it would not be lower. We were also told it would be a monetary policy. Senator Lewis is on record as saying that it would reduce interest rates to 5 per cent in the Opposition's first term in government. Instead, the direct consequence of this, as economic writers such as Ross Gittins can attest, is that we can expect interest rates to rise. What do we have when we look to the wages policy aspect of this package? There is nothing but a bland, general statement and silence.

As I said before, this is not an economic policy at all-it is an economic black hole. All of the questions are raised; none of them are answered. The Opposition has asked Australians to take a leap into the dark. Some media commentators have seen through it. For instance, in the Australian of 16= October the economic editor states:
Andrew Peacock's economic policy adds up-once you realise it's predicated on protracted recession.
It is a recipe for slow growth, weak investment, rising unemployment, falling real wages, high interest rates and an over-valued dollar.

Let us turn to the family policy-the sugar coating of the bitter pill. It is not a policy for families; it is, in fact, a policy for family apartheid. It creates two classes of Australians-those who are mates of Stone, Peacock and Chaney and the mass of ordinary Australians; those who are able to avoid tax and those who have to pay for it. All Australians should ask themselves, `How many families with children will need to be thrown onto the streets to pay for Elliott's latest tax break?'. That is precisely what will happen. This Opposition plans to abolish retrospectively the capital gains tax, giving a windfall gain of hundreds of millions of dollars to Elliott and other Liberal mates. Not only that, it will be replaced in such a way that distortions will be brought into the system. Senator Stone, with his professional knowledge, should know something about this. I do not know how they got this one past him, but they must have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am totally in favour of removing the capital gains tax.
—Senator Stone is in favour of the distortions that will be brought into the system with his speculative gains tax.
—I am totally in favour of removing the capital gains tax.
—But what about the distortions arising out of the speculative gains tax? Has Senator Stone recognised those?
—I am totally in favour of removing the capital gains tax and replacing it with a speculative gains tax.
—But does the honourable senator support the distortions that would come into the system?
—They could not be any greater-they could not be half as great a distortion as that arising from the capital gains tax.
—The honourable senator refuses to admit that he supports the distorted effect of the speculative gains tax.
—It's the capital gains tax that is a distortion.

—It is the speculative gains tax that will bring about distortions. But, basically it is inequitable that the Opposition's proposal can remove the obligation on people to pay capital gains tax. This financial year Labor's capital gains tax will produce half a billion dollars. That money is targeted at and directed back to ordinary Australians through the family allowance, the family allowance supplement and Medicare. Hewson wants to give this money back to Elliott. We are asked to sacrifice not only this money but also fundamental, well thought out, long term changes to our system of government and to our social security system-changes that have been worked out comprehensively through independent reviews, changes which are laying the groundwork for future developments.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are the Opposition's commitments to the indexation of children's benefits? Where are its commitments to a long term retirement incomes policy? We are asked to sacrifice all these for tax breaks for the rich. So it is very much the politics of family apartheid. Why have we embarked upon this? Why does the Opposition promise a return to the politics of division? The answer is pretty clear. A graph of unemployment benefits between 1978 and 1989 shows very clearly that during the time of Hewson-Stone-Chaney unemployment skyrocketed, almost to the top of the graph, to almost 640,000. The people who created this situation are the ones who are now responsible--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how they got there in the first place.

—Having failed once, Senator Stone and Dr Hewson-the men who brought Australia record unemployment and record inflation-have been promoted. It is a sad reflection on the Opposition that Senator Stone and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) have been recycled. These men, who threw 200,000 Australians on to the dole queues in the last two years of coalition government and who threw into poverty almost half a million children of those unemployed parents, have been promoted to do it again. They want another chance. Australians may well ask why they still have no answers, why the bullet has not been bitten in this policy. I suppose that one of the meretricious players in the group of three-Dr Hewson-can tell us. He was there last time. What does he have to say about policy development in the coalition? I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the whole thing was that big decisions were not taken . . . the consumption tax, industry protection levels, policy restraint measures . . . it was very frustrating.
Howard would get rolled, Cabinet Ministers would sway the debate on the basis of an anecdote in the non-Members Bar the night before-even if we had four feet of paper on the table . . .
The farmers could produce anecdotes out of the air. I used to wonder a lot how much many of them understood.

That is the way it was played. I am sure that Senator Stone, when writing his memoirs after losing the seat of Fairfax, will tell us that that is the way it was played this time. We are concerned, but I am sure that the Australian people will not be conned. The Opposition has some basic problems. This Government does have a fiscal policy, a monetary policy and a wages policy. It is now up to the Opposition to show us the fine detail of its grand plan.

The Australian people will not be conned because they do not believe that Andrew Peacock can deliver the morning's milk, let alone deliver on this economic policy. They do not believe Andrew Peacock when he says that fighting inflation first will not mean higher unemployment. And they do not believe people such as Senator Lewis, who expects interest rates to fall to 5 per cent. The Opposition has a major credibility problem-a problem that was around before the mock campaign and which was underscored by that campaign. The major policy of that campaign has been dropped. I am sure that as the Australian people analyse more precisely the policy that has been put to them, as the parliamentary press gallery, commentators and economic analysts are starting to do, they will also see that one cannot trust Andrew Peacock to deliver the morning's milk, let alone an economic policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before us today, which has been proposed by the Opposition, calls on the Government to implement, as a matter of urgency, the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan to relieve, it claims, the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery. Those of us who have been watching the behaviour of the Opposition in this chamber for the last five or so years are somewhat astounded at the claims being made in this matter of public importance. The fact is that, of course, the majority of Australian families are hard hit simply because of the very policies that the Liberal and National parties in opposition in this chamber have supported and which the Australian Labor Party has been implementing over the years. We have seen a number of most inequitable moves undertaken by the current Labor Government with the support of the Opposition that have put the needy in the community into an even more parlous situation and left those who are already well off even better off.

SPEECH.PARA: All that we can say about the Opposition's package is not that it should be undertaken as a matter of urgency by the current Government because, by and large, it is already being implemented, but that the additional aspects of it will serve only to make matters worse. Despite the fact that some writers were deluded into using such headlines as `Liberals' package aimed at helping families', other journalists and editorial writers saw it for what it was-a significant con trick very largely playing on the prejudices of those people who believe that anybody who is a long term unemployed is a layabout 18- or 19-year-old who does not want to work, is not capable of working and would not accept a job if he were offered one on a gold plate. The fact is, of course, that many of the long term unemployed in Australia are men in their forties and early fifties who have been made redundant by changes in industry plans. Those people will not benefit in any way at all from the policies contained in the Opposition's tax package. Ross Dunn, writing for the Australian Financial Review, had this to say on 13 October under a headline of `Needy to subsidise big hand-outs to families':

The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, shifted the Liberal Party significantly to the right yesterday by asking the most disadvantaged groups to suffer the burden of a decision to focus more government spending on families . . . But new measures have been found which will be applauded by those who believe honest hard-working families are paying higher taxes than necessary to keep dole-bludgers, migrants, and invalid pensioners on social welfare benefits.

He went on to point out some of the examples that Mr Peacock gave of how families would benefit. He said that a two-income family earning $26,000 and $13,000-that is, a total income of $39,000-with one child under the age of five and one between five and 12 would benefit by $36.35 a week extra after tax. If a family earned $24,000 and $15,000-that is, a total combined income of $39,000-and was supporting a four-year-old, a nine-year-old and an 11-year-old, it would get $49.42 a week extra. The article stated:
The dependant-spouse rebate will be made more generous, with spouses able to earn $1,000, rather than the existing $282, before the rebate is phased out.

The point that Mr Dunn makes, which is most telling and was picked up by an Age editorial of the same day, is that the benefits will be funded by huge cuts in social welfare-a budget which, I might add, has been pared down by the current Government, with the support of the Opposition, over the last few years. The Age editorial highlights the policy with the headline `Clever politics, dubious economics'. The first paragraph states:

The federal coalition parties' long-awaited economic and tax policy may possibly achieve its purpose of winning for them the next election. If it does, it will do little to solve Australia's daunting economic problems and less to create a fairer society. It is essentially a political document, carefully crafted to tantalise the hip-pocket nerves of the potential swinging voters of Middle Australia. In so far as it addresses Australia's economic crisis of growing indebtedness, excessive inflation and poor productivity, it makes the right noises but offers little convincing evidence that the proposed remedies would bring about the desired results. In so far as it proposes to redistribute taxation and welfare, the message is that more shall be given to those who have, and less shall be available for those who have little.

It is outrageous for the Opposition to call for a fair deal for struggling Australian families when in recent years it has supported policy after policy of the Labor Government, particularly those of the second and third Hawke governments, to cut, both directly and indirectly, the living standards of those families. We have seen families which are classified as low income families deprived of Austudy payments for 15-year-olds in their last two years of school. We have seen 45-year-old women told that, once their youngest child turns 16, they must go off the class B widow's pension and onto the unemployment benefit. The unemployment benefit will be denied after nine months if the Liberal Party comes to power. We have seen the Opposition and the Labor Government combine to delay consumer price index linked increases for pensioners by six weeks and to discount ex-service pensions by 2 per cent.

At the time the Opposition supported these cuts it quite cheerfully supported, at a cost of $2,000m, a 20 per cent tax cut to big business-a cut from 49c in the dollar to 39c. So it is hardly surprising, given these joint actions of the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party, that recent university studies show that the top 20 per cent of Australian families own 44 per cent of the wealth and the bottom 20 per cent own 4.6 per cent of the wealth and income in this country. Presumably the remaining 60 per cent share the remaining 51 per cent of the country's income and wealth.

What does the Opposition want to see happening? If we are to believe the policy that Mr Peacock has released recently, it wants to decrease the income of the bottom 20 per cent so that the top 80 per cent can get a bit more. One wonders what impact it thinks its nine-month unemployment benefit proposal will have on 45- to 50-year-old men who have been made redundant because of restructuring within the industries that have employed them, or on the 45-year-old women I mentioned a moment ago. Has the Opposition thought what will happen to families who are getting some benefits from child tax rebates but are then expected to front up with $1,200 in fees for their university students? Has it added up the net loss to families who are being promised $200 to $350 per annum in tax benefit for children under 15 but who face a cost of $1,200 when they send their 17-year-olds and 18-year-olds to university? Where is the fairness and equity in that? The result will be that high income families will send their sons to do the long courses of medicine, law, dentistry and architecture. The profile of universities will return to that of the 1960s. When I and most of the people in this chamber were university students, we were lucky if 25 per cent of students on campus were women. Very few low income earners and migrant families were able to afford to send their offspring to university.

The Opposition's policy is no better than the policy of the current Government when it comes to directly benefiting Australian families. It fails to deal with some of the major issues. It has ignored the need for incentives to encourage saving generally. Certainly, it has done something with regard to retirement savings accounts, but it has done nothing to release the tax burden on interest paid by ordinary individuals and the fact that pensioners have to pay provisional tax once their interest earnings reach $1,000 a year. It has done nothing to address the issue of increased housing interest costs to the average Australian family and it has done nothing to attend to the level of foreign investment in this country. The first two factors-that is, savings incentives and housing loan interest costs-barely rate a mention in the package. The third, far from being attended to, was given a green light, with no restrictions, no impediments and no questions asked.

Where are Australian families going to benefit from the Opposition's wages policy, unless the wage earners are in a powerful position and are able to hold employers to ransom? Anybody who thought there was any merit in an enterprise-based system for wage fixation should look closely at the pilots dispute. Where guns can be held to employers' heads there will be big wage increases. For shop assistants, nurses, teachers and others who have no chance of holding a country to ransom, there will be little benefit.

Where and how will Australian families benefit from deregulated, totally privatised transport, health, financial and communications systems? We have already heard Liberal senator Richard Alston deriding the idea of cross-subsidies for people living in country areas and needing affordable telephone services. Clearly, a Liberal-National Party government is prepared to impose additional costs on people in country areas. There is no plan to encourage saving, there is no plan to relieve the costs of housing loan repayments and there is no plan to end the foreign debt, foreign investment, high interest rate cycle. There is no plan to do anything but to play on the prejudices of some middle-class voters to win short term political gain.

The Opposition's policy is based on the theory-outlined at page 17 of its document-that an economic environment should be encouraged `in which winners can select themselves'. But, if that is the case, what chance will small business and ordinary Australian families have when the likely winners are given a head start; when investors in housing get a tax deduction for interest payments but home buyers do not; when Australian big businesses can borrow from overseas at lower interest rates but small businesses have to borrow on shore at high interest rates; when major companies can push up our foreign debt to record levels forcing governments, including a possible coalition government, to keep interest rates high to encourage foreign investment to come into Australia; and when the Opposition is planning to do this by removing all restraints on foreign investment, including abolishing the Foreign Investment Review Board?

Who will be the winners if these policies are put into effect? It certainly will not be the Australian families in the middle income bracket or low income earners. The winners will be the Japanese and other foreign investors, shareholders in major Australian companies, the private owners of our transport and communications systems and well off families who can afford high interest rates and the high cost of tertiary education and whose capital gains tax payments will be reduced. Australian families on $59,000 per annum and up will have no difficulty at all living under a future coalition government. The rest will be even worse off than they have been under the second and third Hawke governments.

I suggest that anybody in the community who believes that these policies are a recipe for improved standards of living in Australia ought to look at what some areas of deregulation have already achieved for Australian families. The banking sector, for example, far from providing cheaper interest rates and better services and putting more flexible items on offer to the public, has done just the reverse. This policy offered to us by the Opposition will make matters far worse in the short as well as the long term for most families in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing today the need for the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the Economic Action Plan of the Liberal and National parties announced on Thursday of last week in order to relieve the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery. Senator Bolkus, who has spoken for the Government on this matter, seemed to describe this policy as a black hole. I have probably forgotten most of my physics, but I seem to recall that black holes have an extraordinarily powerful gravitational force, uppermost in the firmament. I suspect that this policy will have exactly that quality about it. It will have a very strong gravitational force upon Australians, particularly the 2.7 million Australian families whose cause this policy takes up.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing which Senator Bolkus was at pains to say was how terribly unfair and biased this policy was, how it was all directed towards the interests of our rich mates. I am not aware that I have any rich mates, as a matter of fact. The funny thing about that is that on the one hand Senator Bolkus seems to feel that the policy can be directed at a few rich people and on the other hand he describes it as a political document. I thought that political documents were about attracting votes from large numbers of people. I think there is a certain inconsequentiality, a certain internal contradiction between Senator Bolkus's arguments which I suggest he look at before he makes another speech on the subject.

The principal economic challenge of the 1990s is to restructure our economy in order to deal with the excessive external debt levels which have accumulated under the feckless period of office of the Hawke-Keating Government. Today our net foreign debt is over $110 billion. We are now third in a list of countries ranked according to the level of external debt they own to commercial banks. We are behind only Brazil and Mexico in that list. We are just in front of Argentina and the Soviet Union.

Inflation, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating), two Budgets ago, described as Australia's number one economic disease, is averaging twice that of our major trading partners and eight times that of the Japanese. The Hawke-Keating Government has had no answer to inflation, no answer to the growing problem of foreign debt, no answer to the imbalance in our external accounts. It has been complacent about all of them for far too long and it has no answers to them today. The Government's blind faith in its now clearly failed accord has led to high money wages growth-not real wages growth-resulting in a floor on inflation of 7 or 8 per cent. We have interest rates today at record high levels because the Government has no answers except its brutal, one-dimensional, tight money-that is to say, high interest rate-policy.

The fact is that the Hawke-Keating Government cannot undertake the necessary micro-economic reform that will get the cost structure of industry down and get inflation down. It cannot do so because it is hamstrung by the need to obey its trade union masters. As a result, the economy continues to go down the plughole.

Last Thursday we produced a blueprint for reform. The coalition's action plan represents an integrated attack on Australia's problems. It calls for cuts in Commonwealth Government spending and other savings of over $2.7 billion. It calls for an end-and it makes not apologies for doing so-to the present open-ended unemployment benefits way of life system. It calls for a far reaching program of reform to transport, communications and other key areas of the economy. It calls for a credible, medium term monetary policy directed at reducing inflation. It calls for a major program of privatisation of government enterprises to transfer to private enterprise what it can do more efficiently and at lower cost. Most importantly, it calls for total reform of the labour market to boost productivity-the only source of rising real incomes-by encouraging closer and more rewarding working relationships between management and employees. It also calls for an end to compulsory age retirement. Those people who do not want to retire should not be forced to do so. It is a policy that in all respects the Government cannot challenge.

The accord has failed. The Australian Council of Trade Unions will not let this Government privatise government business enterprises, even though it would like to do so in a few cases. Its union masters will not let it undertake reform of either the coastal shipping industry or the waterfront. The Hawke-Keating Government today has been reduced to an empty shell of empty rhetoric which it cannot even get right. The day after the coalition policy launch, Mr Keating, the Treasurer, from a doorstep somewhere in Perth uttered what are still his only substantive comments on our policy. What did Mr Keating say? I can put it no better than it was put in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Alan Kennedy in his `Stay in Touch' column:

The Federal Government has been running around in ever-decreasing circles trying to find a counter to Opposition Leader Andrew Peacock's tax policy. Just before he disappeared completely, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, weighed in with a few well-chosen words.
He said: `In actual fact, the Opposition has brought down a set of intended changes that overwhelmingly endorse the basic economic direction being pursued by the Government.'
Near the end, however, he said: `But what is crystal clear is that today's document does nothing fundamental to address Australia's balance of payments and external debt crisis.'
The Silver Budgie-
I think that is slightly disrespectful to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but that is how Mr Kennedy describes him-

Mr Hawke, didn't help clear matters up, either. He took time off from dismantling the trade union movement to say of Mr Peacock's statement: `It is obviously economically irrelevant. It offers no alternative to the basic economic strategy that is being followed by this Government.'
Exactly.

Without committing oneself to agreeing with the limited views that have been stated either by Mr Hawke or Mr Keating, one can only say that the sheer internal contradictions of the Government's attitudes on these matters could not be more starkly revealed than by those quotations. Why was the Treasurer saying all this from a doorstep in Perth? It is widely known, after all, that he cancelled his annual trip to the International Monetary Fund meeting so that he could stay in Canberra, so he said, to attack the coalition's tax policy. A heading in the Age of 25 August is `Keating cancels Washington trip'. The article states:
The Treasurer, Mr Keating, has cancelled his annual trip to the International Monetary Fund meeting so that he can stay in Australia to attack the Opposition's tax policy.

A spokesman for Mr Keating said last night that nothing at the IMF meeting, in Washington next month, was as important as the tasks Mr Keating could undertake in Australia. `We'll see what Andrew Peacock comes up with at around that time.'
An article in the Canberra Times on Wednesday, 13 September, states:

The Labor Government is like a `heat-seeking missile' bearing down on the federal Opposition and ready to destroy its policies in the run-up to the next election, according to the Treasurer, Paul Keating.
`We are just like those infra-red missiles targeted on the Liberals,'-
he might have included the Nationals as well-
Mr Keating told a meeting of Australian Labor Party supporters in Sydney. `We are now on red alert and locked on.

On red alert? Nobody can find the Treasurer! He has gone into a burrow somewhere in Western Australia. I am not sure whether he is still in Western Australia; he may have come back. Is he hiding in a bunker here in the Parliament? Where is he? Mr Keating continued to beat up this hype about what he would do to the Opposition's tax policy. Geoff Kitney, in the Australian Financial Review on Friday, 6 October, began his article with the headline, `The political Cobra winds up for the strike'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Carpet snake.
—Senator Panizza is quite right with his interjection. Mr Kitney's perceptive article begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal Treasurer Paul Keating looking like a political cobra, is wound up and ready to strike.
I have to ask where he is. When will we feel the fangs?

TALK.START.PARA: —With a forked tongue.

—As Senator Puplick says, he might be ready to strike with a forked tongue. I love these analogies. This year, Mr Keating is a cobra. Last year, he was a black widow spider, if I recall correctly, crawling over the web he and Mr Hawke were spinning for the Opposition. I can only say that we are still waiting. Yesterday Mr Hawke flew out to Kuala Lumpur for 10 days, so presumably we will not get any comment from him in that time. Apart from that doorstop interview in Perth last Friday, Mr Keating's only contribution was to put out a three-paragraph press statement yesterday. Talking about the sharp fall on the stock markets, he states:

SPEECH.PARA: At a time of international economic tension such as this, the Opposition claims that it could meet the challenge of governing Australia with a policy of at least $5 billion of tax give-aways in its first Budget.
The Liberal Party-
I regret that he does not talk about the coalition-
must be the only party in the Western World which believes that what is required at the present time is a profligate policy of public handouts.

This is the man who in that very same interview in Perth on Friday said that since 1 July this year, which is four months ago, the Government has spent $5.7 billion. He does not describe that as a `profligate policy of public handouts', even though he has paid for none of it with spending cuts, not a penny. This man cannot even get his lines right any longer. He is a figure of fun. The greatest Treasurer in the world has been reduced to a figure of fun; it is a pathetic farce.
To see the manner in which the Government is facing up to the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, we need only look at the list of Government speakers today, headed by Senator Bolkus.

TALK.START.PARA: —They brought in the heavyweights.

—They really brought in the heavyweights. I do not wish to be in anyway slighting about Senator Crowley, but I also have to say that she and Senator Faulkner will not add much additional weight in the economic area, whatever their claims may be in other areas. With the Treasurer out of the firing line-I suppose we would have to say retired hurt-what about his colleagues? The Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, keeps on bleating that the coalition's policy is not fair. We will just have to see how fair the Australian people think it is. We will just have to see how fair they think it is for the Labor Party to call upon the decent, honest, hard-working people of this country who go out to work and pay their taxes to support the welfare industry that this Government has encouraged and built up over the course of six and a half years of office.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dawkins made a singularly inept contribution of an extraordinarily limited kind. So far, I have certainly seen nothing from Mr Hand, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I hope I do not do him an injustice. But these, after all, are still the lightweights, leaving aside the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, with whom I have dealt. But where is Senator Walsh? Time will not allow me to develop my argument as to what Senator Walsh might have been saying if he had had anything to say on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I have a point of order. It should be recognised by the Chair that we have had 15 minutes of craving for attention from Senator Stone, without addressing the motion. I cannot see why he is asking for more time now.
—There is no point of order.

—The fact is that Senator Walsh is on record as supporting almost every expenditure and savings program we have proclaimed. Time will not permit me to run through them, but I will quote a remark he made in September 1987. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We've been a lucky country for a long time, not so lucky any more and if we don't challenge most of the absurd notions that the majority of Australians have about what they are entitled to and what's essential to them and what isn't then we are going down the Argentinean road.
He preceded that by saying that he could give us a list of 200 `bloody' programs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to a quite extraordinary contribution from Senator Stone. More in sorrow than in anger, I have to say that I expected better of him. After he had spoken a little on the metaphors of black holes and wandered amongst some other language-by the way, he had better have a look at exactly what a black hole in space does with its gravity-he then gave us a travelogue of where our colleagues may or may not have been when they were or were not saying whatever pleased him. Finally, he devoted three or five minutes to abusing Senator Faulkner and me on the grounds that we were probably not economic heavyweights. If his contribution is what an economic heavyweight gives us, I am glad that we do not have to rely on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Austin Lewis read his paper. This side of the chamber was too civil to interrupt and say he should speak it but he read a written speech. I would like to know who wrote it. That is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't trust him, I would say.

—Senator Faulkner can tell the chamber what he was. I am just fascinated to know that Senator Lewis had to read his speech and that Senator Stone, who sometimes gives us to understand that he has a good grasp of these things, fell into abuse and irrelevance, which is somewhat disappointing. That is perhaps because he is not prepared to address the substance of his Economic Action Plan. I want to take up that point. The matter of public importance we are debating today states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the Liberal and National Parties' Economic Action Plan to relieve the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery.
If $2.7 billion is taken from outlays and put on to inlays, or at least on the other side of the revenue thing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Inlays?

—I thought Senator Puplick would like that. For the record, I am sure that Hansard has that in parentheses, because Hansard understands how such things are said. Senator Puplick will spend a lot of time saying I do not know economics. Indeed, I may have just succumbed to Senator Stone's sin of using the smart word instead of the accurate word. Nothing in a balanced budget of the sort the Opposition has proposed-taking from one side and putting it on the other side-will do anything to alter the broad economic criteria with which Opposition members claim the Government is ruining the country. Nothing the Opposition has offered in its Economic Action Plan document will do anything to address that. The big concern I have is about words like `steady monetary policy' which, according to any advice I have, will do nothing to lower interest rates; indeed, it would probably put them up. If it is to have any effect at all, it will be only by increasing unemployment. If we look at the years 1981 and 1982, we see that it is a policy which those opposite are very well practised at.

SPEECH.PARA: I take issue with the definition of `family' and which part of the Australian family will benefit, as presumed in this extraordinary document. Quite clearly, the Opposition thinks that a family has one breadwinner and occasionally two. Those opposite have finally come round to the fact that occasionally there are two breadwinners in a family and that they have the standard 2 1/2 children. We do not find any reference to women in this document. That is, at least, a going back on the Opposition's previous Future Directions document. It is pretty hard to go further back than that, but it has. At least that document mentioned women; they rated a very small comment. The figures have changed very little for child-care, which rated two column inches in the original document. Now women do not get a guernsey at all, but child-care gets a lot. We presume that that is because those opposite think that that will talk to women.

What is this family? It is not a family that covers low income people. It is not a family that is affected by being on social security benefits or pensions. The Opposition's notion of a family in this document does not include those on low incomes, the poor or black people. Migrants are excluded if they have just come here and cannot speak English too well. The Opposition says, `That is not a real family'. It says, `You are not a real family; we do not want to target benefits to you'. Of course, those opposite could not target benefits to those people because all they would have to do is improve on the splendid record of this Government. One of the people who say that we have a splendid record for low income people is Senator Fred Chaney! In the Hansard of 23 November 1988, at page 2632, he states:
With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.

—Exactly; that is what we have done. As a priority we have helped those on the lowest incomes. Those opposite come in here with their program, which is a different policy-goodbye the low income earners, hello the people who are better off. Honourable senators should just listen to what those opposite are proposing to do.
—Do something about the other 2.7 million.

—They are being looked after. Senator Stone has not understood our policy and the tax cuts. If Senator Stone wants to attack Mr Keating because he talks about the Opposition's profligate spending, he should understand why Mr Keating can say that. He has given tax cuts that are funded, that are on a promise and that are tied to a wages policy that means that they do not bite into inflation in the way that those opposite are proposing. But members of the Opposition do not want to know that, and I do not care if they do not want to know it. This is not a debate that is about convincing others; at the very best it is about putting the Government's point of view, which is what I intend to do. I leave it to those opposite to put up the absolute nonsense that Senator Stone did or read a good paper like Senator Lewis did. I refer honourable senators to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Adele Horin, headed `Why Peacock's bounty feels just like a bribe'.
—Are you taking notice of Adele Horin?

—Many people do. That is why she is a columnist with a paper and that is why Senator Stone should take notice of what she says. I would like to pick up on what she says because she gives, rather succinctly, a very good critique of the Opposition's document. First of all she mentions that those opposite have re-introduced the policies of scaremongering and prejudice. Adele Horin begins by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The dole bludger is back.

That is exactly right. Unemployment benefits are to be cut off if a person has been on the benefit for nine months. Senator Haines spelt out figures that I could run through that describe the characteristics of long term unemployed people. They are not dole bludgers.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard all this.

—Fancy! I am amazed that Senator Stone has heard it, because quite clearly he does not understand it and does not incorporate it. What does happen to people? Who are the people who will be dealt with by those opposite who will be losing unemployment benefits after nine months? What policies have those opposite got that will direct them to education and training and give them support? How many of those people do those opposite really seriously consider are in families? The majority of them are in families. Those opposite have a policy for families that will do nothing for these people. They pay no tax; they will get no tax rebate. They pay no tax; they will get no tax rebate for child-care.
—Read it properly.

—We do read it properly. These tax `benefits' will be of no use to thousands and thousands of families who pay no tax. Those opposite do not understand it; we do. We speak for those people and we understand exactly what happens to a long term unemployed person with children. We have heard Senator Bolkus say on a number of occasions over the last few days that the number of people on unemployment benefits has dramatically reduced under this Government's policies, which are encouraging people back into work. What do those opposite think 1.6 million jobs since 1983 means? It means that people in Australia are working-not the people who had a job, but people who could not get a job under the previous Government, under the dreadful Liberal Government policies of 1981-82 which drove unemployment so high. Those people want to work. In fact, 1 1/2 million people have taken up the opportunity to get back to work under this Government. This Government has helped those people. This Government has provided employment opportunities and has provided the criteria under social security to ensure that people are properly in receipt of benefits. The Government has also made it quite clear that it does not sanction rorts and wrong use of social security pensions and benefits.
—You ought to open your eyes.

—Indeed we do. We now target the benefits, but the benefits have been dramatically increased for families, aged people and so on across the whole scale. In 1987-88 social security outlays fell from 6.9 per cent of gross domestic product to 6.2 per cent. There has been a fall in outlays, but an increase in better targeted programs. Under social security we do not abandon the unemployed. We say, `Those of you who are legitimately able to enjoy these benefits can do so', but we are also sure that we do not want people abusing the system.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, this Government is not singling out the unemployed or sole parents. I am a bit surprised to find that members of the Opposition did not give them a kick on the way through; they usually do. We are not singling out any recipients under social security, but the rules, which require a thorough scrutiny to ensure that people are properly using those benefits, have meant a number of important things. Firstly, the percentage outlays have fallen. Secondly, the payment of benefits has dramatically increased and, for the first time ever, this year the Australian Government has increased family allowance and indexed it. Payments on behalf of families are now all indexed and associated with the consumer price index; if they are not directly indexed, they are indexed as a package. Benchmarks and standards in relation to the cost of rearing a child have been established as a percentage of the married rate of pension and are fixed, indexed and are never to be written down-unless those on the other side get into government.

That is the commitment this Government has made to families and to all children. The benefits are there for all people across the country under the April statement and the recent Budget that has seen them implemented. The next stage in the Government's stepped program is to assist low income earners as a priority. There have been recent changes to assist the middle income earners. Of course we have appreciated the contribution that people have made. We have had tough times-left to us after the seven years of Fraser Government. The Hawke Government has redressed those tough times and has asked everybody in Australia to take part in that recovery. So they have, with fairness, honour and dignity.

The worst thing about the Opposition's program is not so much that its figures are funny or that it is targeting middle-class families, but that it insists on going back to the policies of disgusting division, of singling out the people who have to be kicked and blamed in this country. Over the years the Hawke Government has done away with blaming and singling out a group in the community that has to be held responsible--(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate this afternoon states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to implement as a matter of urgency the Liberal and National Parties' Economic Action Plan to relieve the unfair burdens on Australian families and provide a basis for sustained national recovery.

This focuses on the twin elements of how our recently announced Economic Action Plan would, first, help Australian families and, secondly, help to rescue the Australian economy from the parlous state to which it has been reduced purely as a result of the policies of the Hawke-Keating-Kelty Government. My colleagues Senator Lewis and Senator Stone have already dealt with the broad issues of the economy. They have demonstrated how this package would constitute a major attack upon inflation, how it would have a major impact in bringing about the reduction of interest rates and how it would have a major effect on increasing incentives in the Australian economy-incentives to work, incentives to save, incentives to productivity and incentives to raise living standards.

The responses that we have had so far from the Government in this debate have been absolutely pathetic. We had 15 or 20 minutes of disaggregated waffle from Senator Bolkus, who is the responsible Minister. His only contribution to public life in Australia has been to persuade Telecom Australia to introduce tamper-proof telephones. We had 15 minutes of equally disaggregated waffle from Senator Crowley, who has decided that, as one half of the Budget is called outlays, the other half of the Budget must of necessity be called inlays-the sort of economics that one would expect from a Balmain basket weaver. She told us that the tax cuts of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were, firstly, funded, when they are totally unfunded, and, secondly-and probably the only correct thing that she said during the whole of her remarks-that they were `on a promise'. They certainly were on a promise! That is precisely what the Treasurer has been doing-promising to get everything right and promising to restore the Australian economy. Undoubtedly Senator Crowley knows all about being on a promise as far as these things are concerned. But, frankly, that is not a good enough basis for the conduct of the Australian economy.

It is my intention this afternoon to deal with the family taxation package, which is an integral and an absolutely central part of the Economic Action Plan produced last Thursday by the Liberal and National parties. The coalition parties' family tax package comprises, firstly, a new program of child tax rebates, secondly, an increase in the eligibility threshold and a reduction in the withdrawal rate for the dependent spouse rebate and, thirdly, a new program of child- care tax rebates.

The tax rebates for children would be available for deduction against the tax liability of a sole parent or against the combined tax liability of both parents in two-parent families. It was our recognition of the legitimate sole parent component that had Senator Crowley in such a lather. The amount of child tax rebate that can be claimed would vary according to the number and age of children in each family. For example, a first child under the age of 13 would attract a rebate of $250 per annum and those aged 13, 14 and 15 would attract a rebate of $350 per annum. For the second and each subsequent child under the age of 13 the rebate would be $200 per annum and for the second and each subsequent child aged 13, 14 or 15 it would be $300 per annum. The cost of the child-care tax rebate reaches the figure of approximately $1,000m.

The dependent spouse rebate is to be changed in two ways. Currently, where the dependent spouse derives separate net income, the maximum rate is reduced by $1 for every complete $4 by which the separate net income exceeds $282. The eligibility threshold would be raised from the current level of $282 to $1,000 and the withdrawal rate would be eased. So, where a spouse's net income is up to $1,000, the dependent spouse rebate would be $1,000 per annum without children and $1,200 with children. Eligibility for the dependent spouse rebate would fall by $1 for every $6 by which the dependent spouse's separate net income exceeds $1,000. The cost to revenue would be about $200m.

The child-care tax rebate would be available for deduction against the tax liability of a sole parent or against tax calculated on the secondary earner's income in two-parent families. A rebate of $20 per week would be paid for the first child under five years of age. For each other child under five years and for each child aged between five and 12 the rebate would be $10 per week. For couples, rebates would be paid only where the second earner's income is derived from wage, salary or self-employment income and where that income exceeds the relevant tax-free threshold. For example, a parent who earns more than the tax-free threshold and has one child under five, assuming four weeks' annual leave, would receive $960 a year. To receive the full rebate entitlement, child-care expenditure would have to be fully substantiated. That point is fair. However, payment of the rebate would not be restricted to formal child-care. As far as possible a range of child-care facilities would be eligible. The estimated cost of that child-care rebate package is $820m.

Why have families been particularly singled out and targeted as the key element in this recently announced package? It is because families have been the most disadvantaged, neglected and financially abused group in Australian society under the policies deliberately pursued by the Hawke-Keating-Kelty Government. One has only to look at a few of the comments that have been made in that regard in the last couple of years. In October 1988, the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) produced its report entitled Income Support Policies, Taxation and Incentives which drew attention to the fact that at that time the proportion of families with children in relative poverty had been higher during the 1980s than during the previous decade. It drew attention to the facts that low income families with children and individuals with families on low incomes and with high housing costs were among the neediest groups, and that the impact of high housing costs has continued because it is part of the Government's central economic strategy to keep interest rates at their highest level ever in Australia. Other research to which EPAC drew attention indicated that housing related poverty had continued to increase. A number of comments were made at that time and I draw attention to one by Peter Stephens in the Age in November 1988. In discussing the EPAC report he said:
To alleviate poverty among families (EPAC says families have done badly) the tax system should recognise the existence of children and compensate to some degree for the costs of raising a family.

That is absolutely correct and central to what this package will do. In February this year the Institute of Family Studies issued a report entitled Families and Tax in 1989. I quote from the first paragraph of the summary:
Average tax rates have risen between 1976-77 and 1988-89 for all individuals and families with the exception of those on very high incomes and low income families with children.

The exceptions have been those on very high incomes, who basically constitute the new class of mates which this Government has been so assiduous in courting, and low income families with children. Let me remind Senator Crowley that the first important step taken to deal with the problems of low income families with children was not taken by the Hawke Labor Government but by the Fraser coalition Government when Senator Chaney as the Minister for Social Security introduced the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 and the start of the family income supplement program. The very basis upon which assistance to low income families is predicated grows from a program introduced by Senator Chaney and the Fraser coalition Government. The summary in the report from the Institute of Family Studies, referring to average weekly earnings, goes on:

In 1988-89 dollar terms, the same AWE family is now paying $30.80 per week more tax than they did 12 years ago compared to the twice AWE single person who is paying $18.88 more and the single person on four times AWE who is paying $105.32 less.
It goes on:

Since 1984-85, real disposable incomes have fallen sharply for all income units dependent on one income. The falls have ranged from $30.61 for single persons to $47.85 for couples with four children . . .
It further states:
`Bracket creep' has contributed to the rises in average tax rates for all taxpayers . . .
It concludes:
Tax cuts are justified for all taxpayers but the cuts should be especially targeted to middle income families, particularly those with children.

That is precisely what this package does. It attacks the problem of bracket creep by the policies which Senator Lewis and Senator Stone have indicated are central to this package, to this commitment, to return the profits of bracket creep to Australian taxpayers. It is no wonder that the reaction to this package has been as favourable as it has. The Daily Mirror says that this is a:
. . . radical strategy for returning to middle Australians (and particularly those with children) much of the ground they have lost in recent years.
The Daily Telegraph says:
Mr Peacock's support for the family unit is admirable, a reinforcement of one of the strongest planks of Liberal philosophy in this era of the breakdown of traditional lifestyles.
Paul Kelly, writing in the Australian, draws attention to the considerable benefits to be gained. Daryl Dixon, writing in the Sydney Morning Herald, says:

. . . the Opposition has targeted the weakest parts of the Hawke-Labor tax policies-the reliance on bracket creep to raise revenue and the unfair treatment of families, especially those incurring child care outlays.

Senator Robert Ray described this policy in here yesterday as bludging on the less well-off in our society and diverting income from them to the better off. He said that that is what the Opposition is doing. I will tell the Senate who is diverting income to whom. The Labor Party is diverting income to the less well-off called Rupert Murdoch. As announced by Senator Button today, another $1m or so will go to Rupert Murdoch. It is diverting income to the less well-off called Sir Peter Abeles, and the less well-off called Alan Bond. It put forward $30m to defend a sporting trophy. It is diverting income to the less well-off called Rothwells Ltd, the less well-off called Laurie Connell, the less well-off called the four large banks in this country and the less well-off called Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, owned by an American multinational company, which used to be in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is now in Mr Howe's electorate. This Government is taking $60m away from the poor and needy in this country to give as a handout to an American multinational company. That is what this Government's priorities are in terms of who is getting the money, who is getting the redistributed income. Let Mr Howe, as the Minister for Social Security, explain that to all the homeless youth and children in poverty.

You will remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there are no children in poverty in this country any longer because the Prime Minister has abolished that, not by doing anything about it but by changing the definition! Let him go out into the streets of Sydney at night and tell those kids living in the parks, sleeping on the streets, in genuine need and in genuine poverty, that there is no child poverty and that there is $60m for Kodak, $30m for Bond, a couple of million dollars for Abeles, a couple of million dollars for Murdoch, $200m for the banks and millions of dollars for Connell and Rothwells and all of the sleazy mates that the Labor Party has tucked away in the hollow logs around Western Australia and the rest of this country. Let him tell them what the impact of this package is as far as they are concerned.

A number of questions have been asked by the Government about this package in the two days that we have been sitting here so that Senator Bolkus can give his pre-arranged five-page statements. Senator Robert Ray made one feeble attempt today to talk about the Government contracting out costs and services. The Labor Party has not been able to lay a glove upon this package. Every commentator, every editorial, every writer and every analyst has demonstrated quite clearly the benefit that this package gives to Australian families. They have denounced the extent to which families and family living standards have been targeted, have been depressed, and have been driven down under the policies of the Hawke-Keating-Kelty Government. They have remarked on the relief families will get as a result of our package being put in place, as a result of the bracket creep decisions which we have announced, and as a result of funding our promises out of cuts in profligate government spending-not on the basis of overlaying inlays, as Senator Crowley would have it, with taxation deals which, as she described them, were on a promise from Mr Keating. That is why the package will succeed. That is why the Opposition will win the next Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is the first opportunity we have had to make a parliamentary response to the Liberal Party's so-called Economic Action Plan. The Economic Action Plan represents the most cynical and immoral vote buying exercise in the history of Australian politics. It is a document based on prejudice and aimed at dividing the Australian community. The document claims to target the so-called forgotten people of Australian politics-the family. I was interested to read in the Sun-Herald on the weekend in the `Candid Comment' column by Peter Robinson a comment on this question of the forgotten people. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: These voters, for some incomprehensible reason, are being dubbed ``the forgotten people''
What indescribable balderdash this is-a classic case of the inbred Canberra hothouse creating its own jargon remote from the realities of Australian life.
The truth is that this group of swinging voters must be the most-remembered ``forgotten people'' in the history of Australian politics.

He may or may not be right. However, I know that the Opposition's definition of families is very narrow indeed. The Opposition cares nothing about families who do not live in marginal electorates. The Opposition is very interested in families whom it defines as families of swinging voters, but outside that small number of families the Opposition could not care less. In our community there are all kinds of families-families from ethnic communities, Aboriginal families, sole parent families, families of the unemployed, those on low incomes and a whole range of other disadvantaged families. What interests me-and I am sure it will interest the Australian people-is what this Liberal policy means for ordinary Australians; the ones who do not have great property portfolios; the ones who do not have share portfolios; the ones whose sole source of income is their salary and their biggest investment is the family home.

I think it is important to compare the Hawke Government's record for families with these desperate promises of Mr Peacock and the Liberals' most recent leadership team. This Government has an effective social justice strategy, a strategy that is working. Even at a time of reduced and reducing government expenditure, the Hawke Government has continued funding to people and families in need. No-one with an ounce of credibility would say that the Labor Government was other than totally responsible in the manner it runs the country and manages the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I do not count Senator Puplick and Senator Lewis as people of responsibility. They are certainly not people of credibility. According to Senator Lewis's own colleagues, he has so much credibility that, when it came to the inner leadership group of the Liberal Party who determined this Economic Action Plan, Mr Peacock, Senator Chaney, Dr Hewson, Mr Blunt and Senator Stone were the five people in the core group, and who was on the reserve bench? Senator Lewis was carrying the oranges, of course. They would not even let him into the group of five who determined this Economic Action Plan.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government's record is there for all Australian families to see. It is a record to be proud of. This Government has created 1.6 million jobs; this Government has reformed the tax system; this Government has created 70,000 child-care places; this Government has bolstered family allowance payments; and this Government has introduced the family allowance supplement. Our record on behalf of Australian families cannot be questioned. We have the runs on the board. But I am afraid that the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan would throw all these achievements out the window. Of course, the fairness and equity of the Government's program would be lost. It is the old Liberal Party philosophy that we all know: assist the powerful, the rich and the wealthy in our community always at the expense of the powerless and the most disadvantaged.

Coming from the State of New South Wales, I do not need reminding of what a Peacock Liberal-National Party alternative government would mean, at the household level, for ordinary Australians. In March 1988, many New South Wales voters blithely committed political suicide at the ballot box in the belief that there were no major differences between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. Of course, many New South Wales voters believed that the Liberals would never carry out the more extreme promises that they made. They have not carried out too many of their promises, but their more extreme policies have been put into action. After 18 months of Greiner Government, after the loss of some 20,000 jobs in the New South Wales Public Service, after the creation of the newfangled, unmanned railway station, after the closure of thousands of hospital beds, after the breaking of some 150-plus pre-election promises, after the closing of dozens of viable government schools, after the implementation of policies which mean that decent and affordable housing is beyond the reach of the ordinary citizens of New South Wales, and after the breach of the promise that no Greiner State Government would increase State charges beyond the consumer price index, not to mention the destruction of the environment that the Greiner Government has been responsible for at the behest of Senator Stone's National Party mates, does anyone seriously believe that Andrew Peacock would be more trustworthy than Nick Greiner? Do we have any reason to believe that Andrew Peacock would deliver on any of his promises? Would Andrew Peacock show the same commitment to the Economic Action Plan as he showed loyalty to John Howard just a few months ago?

Of course, John Howard is no longer the Liberal Party Leader, but his economic views prevail in all elements of this Liberal Party Economic Action Plan. I suppose that it is not surprising because his one-time staffer, John Hewson, is there to keep the flame burning. Does anyone really believe that a powder puff like Andrew Peacock-or a feather puff as I am sure he will be called in the future-has a single strong view on economics or any other area of government activity? Of course not! Andrew Peacock cares only about winning the next election. It is the politics of expedience-cut $2 billion off the most needy in our community and, hopefully, redistribute it to the swinging voters. He figures that, if he does that, it will be a sufficient election bribe for him to become Prime Minister. As I have said, I believe that Andrew Peacock is just as trustworthy as Nick Greiner.

The Hawke Government recognises the needs of disadvantaged people. This Government is doing something about the plight of Aborigines-the most disadvantaged people in our community. What about Aboriginal families? Where do they figure in the Liberal Party's Economic Action Plan? Of course, the Liberal Party figures that there are not too many Aboriginal families in marginal seats. The Liberal Party's Economic Action Plan will have a monumental negative impact on the Aboriginal people in this country.

The Opposition's policy on Aboriginal affairs offers no new policy prescriptions; it merely proposes a savage reduction in funding. The programs targeted for the biggest reductions are the community infrastructure programs and the community development employment projects scheme. These programs are the very areas for which funding is directed at the most impoverished, disadvantaged and remote Aboriginal communities. Cuts in these programs will serve only to emphasise further the Opposition's determination to redistribute funding away from the most needy in Australian society without any thought for the consequences of its action. By any measure Aboriginals are the most disadvantaged people in our community.

The Opposition speaks of reform of the structure and method of service delivery as a medium-term goal; yet it continues to oppose the fundamental reform envisaged by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation as we have seen in the Senate over the last few days. One of the Liberals' most vicious proposals is to cut $23m from the Department of Employment, Education and Training for Aboriginal employment, education and training programs. This is full on the Liberal Party's strategy of hitting the most disadvantaged groups in our community. The Aboriginal unemployment rate is six times higher than the national rate. Aboriginal employment rates are half those for other Australians. The Aboriginal retention rate to year 12 is a third of the national retention rate. Only 85 per cent of Aboriginal children are receiving compulsory schooling compared with the national rate of almost 100 per cent. Participation rates in technical and further education, in higher education and in senior secondary education are only one-third of those of Australians generally. These proposed cuts-they will never be implemented because the Opposition will not win the next election-are incredibly short-sighted and will inevitably lead to higher government outlays on welfare and obviously reduce the prospects for Aboriginal people to reduce their dependency on welfare payments. In finishing, I refer to the Age editorial of 13 October 1989 headed `Clever politics, dubious economics'. It sums up very well the Economic Action Plan of the Opposition. It says:

. . . all higher-income earners would benefit through the promised reduction of the top marginal rate and restructuring to a flatter two-tier system. this would be financed by a $2.7 billion drop in federal spending, largely from social security and welfare. The losers include the jobless, the disadvantaged, the sick and disabled and Aborigines.

Its impact on Australian society would be to widen the gap between the haves and have-nots. Political cleverness, unfortunately, is not an admirable substitute for economic credibility or social justice.
That is absolutely right. Lastly, the Canberra Times in its editorial calls it, quite properly, `Appeal to greed by Coalition'. It says:
Mr Peacock hopes that an appeal to greed will win him the Prime Ministership.
On the question of equity, the policy released yesterday falls wide of the mark.
The documents are high in rhetoric, especially on fairness for families. But doesn't Mr Peacock realise that Aborigines and the long-term unemployed come from families, too.
He realises it, but he could not care less.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS' DISPUTE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Lewis, for Senator Chaney)-by leave-agreed to:
(1) That the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(b) two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and
(c) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(2) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(3) That the Committee elect as Chairman one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government.

(4) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(5) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the Committee being equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(6) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(7) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(8) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(9) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(10) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorized by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
