SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Democrat motion moved by Senator Coulter. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, which we have been debating now for some time, is practical legislation which will, if implemented, enable the Aboriginal people to move towards self-government, self-management and self-determination. It will certainly result in regional councils containing councillors elected by Aboriginal people who will work towards aiding the Aboriginal people to move to self-management and self-determination at a local level. These regional councils will also be responsible for electing commissioners.

SPEECH.PARA: The words in the motion moved by Senator Coulter would indeed be misleading if included in a preamble to this practically motivated legislation. As Senator Coulter said, it could lead people to believe that explicit in the legislation would be the results included in the motion itself. That is not necessarily the case. The legislation, as I have just said, provides the framework within which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can forge their own cultural, educational and financial destinies.

I found what Senator Puplick and Senator Tambling had to say earlier today about the words in this motion quite offensive. I believe that Senator Puplick, by semantic nitpicking in describing the words, was really expressing his opposition to the general substance of the words and the sentiments included in those words. As Senator Puplick said, the motion is not legislation, but I can assure Senator Puplick that the substance and sentiments included in this motion are of great importance to a large number of Aboriginal people with whom I have spoken at length. Senator Puplick believes that we have to feel guilty to accept these words. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is a matter of social justice at present, albeit in words only. Whether Senator Puplick, and presumably the coalition Opposition, can accept it or not, a lot of Aboriginal people feel dispossessed right now. They feel dispossessed not just of access to their former tribal lands but also of their language, culture, their self-esteem and, indeed, in many cases their essential being. We see very many tragic results of that today.

I believe that coalition Opposition speakers to this Australian Democrat motion have revealed their real stance towards the Aboriginal people in this present debate. That stance is that it is better to argue in terms of semantics than to show any generosity of spirit towards our own Aboriginal people. In this case I can state quite categorically that members of the Opposition divorce themselves from the stance of the Catholic Social Justice Commission in Western Australia, the Anglican Social Responsibility Commission in Western Australia and the Uniting Church in Western Australia. All these bodies have made very strong statements in support of the Western Australian Nyungah Aboriginal people who seek continuous access to their former lands of importance and the sacred site where the old Swan brewery stands today. Paragraph (i) of the motion moved by Senator Coulter states that the Senate notes that:

the Australian people voted overwhelmingly to amend the Australian Constitution to provide the Parliament of the Commonwealth with power to make laws for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples . . .
In other words, this was to grant them citizenship. Senator Puplick said that he did not like the wording of that, so he is not going to vote for it. Paragraph (ii) states that the Senate notes that:
the people whose descendants are now known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land . . .
They were here before the Europeans. That is what that says. Paragraph (iii) states:
they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights over land yet recognised by the Courts, other than those granted or recognised by the Crown . . .
That happens to be true. Paragraph (iv) notes:
dispossession occurred without compensation and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land . . .
That also happens to be true, although happily there are now some agreements being made. I suggest that these are by no means lasting or equitable at present. Paragraph (v) states:
as a consequence of these and subsequent deprivations, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have become, as a group, the most disadvantaged in Australian society.
Whether Senator Puplick likes it or not, I would put it to him that that statement is certainly true. Paragraph (vi) notes:

it is the intention of the people of Australia to make provision for rectification, by measures referred to in legislation and such measures as are agreed by Parliament from time to time, of the consequences of past injustices and to ensure for all time that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples receive that full recognition and status within the Australian nation to which history, their prior ownership and occupation of the land, and their rich and diverse culture, fully entitle them to aspire . . .
I really cannot see how that motion of intent could be objected to, bearing in mind the past paragraphs in this particular motion. Paragraph (vii) states:
it is also the wish of the people of Australia that there be reached with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples a real and lasting reconciliation of these matters . . .

Senator Puplick took particular objection to the term `lasting reconciliation'. However, where we have ethnic or indigenous minorities in a nation we either have revolution, continuous bubbling unrest or a real and lasting reconciliation. I believe that at present it is inevitable that books such as Sally Morgan's My Place will be written. For those honourable senators who have not read it, Sally Morgan describes how her mother and her grandmother felt obliged to deny their Aboriginality for fear of being discriminated against and for fear of the most cruel kind of discrimination, that is, having their children removed from them. When we read the recent history-when I say `recent history' I mean going back over the last few years-of these sorts of feelings still being there because of incidents which occurred up to a mere 20 years ago, obviously people feel the need for a lasting reconciliation. Paragraph (viii) states:

it is the firm objective of the people of Australia that policies and programs be maintained and developed by the Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, that will overcome the economic and social disadvantages of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, entitle them to the enjoyment of their culture and recognition of their traditional laws wherever practicable, and enable them, with pride and dignity, to achieve full recognition and status within the Australian nation . . .
I cannot see how anyone could disagree with that statement. Paragraph (ix) states:

it is appropriate to establish measures for the furtherance of the aforementioned objective that are consistent with the aims of self-determination and self-management for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples within the Australian nation . . .

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander legislation itself is such a measure. It is certainly consistent with the aim of self-determination and self-management of our indigenous peoples. Other measures may need to be set up and in that case should be supported. Finally, paragraph (x) states:

the Australian Government has given effect to its long-standing commitment to protect the rights of all of its citizens, and in particular its indigenous peoples, by recognising international standards for the protection of universal human rights and fundamental freedoms through the ratification of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and other standard-setting instruments such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenants on Economic Social and Cultural Rights and on Civil and Political Rights . . .
Again that is simply a statement of fact. Australia is a signatory to these conventions. Therefore, it is correct that we should follow them through. Part (b) of the motion states that the Senate:
declares that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government.

The Australian Democrats firmly believe that this particular move should be thoroughly explored. As Senator Coulter said, there have been various ways suggested of doing this and various names for such an understanding-a makarrata and so on. Some names have been found to be objectionable by some people. I believe that this is a measure that should be thoroughly explored. This is the right time to make this move.

I was disappointed earlier to find the degree of abuse that has passed from one side of the chamber to the other during this debate because in the early stages of the debate it did seem that we were really seeing democracy in action and the various clauses were being debated sensibly and rationally. So far the debate on this particular motion moved by Senator Coulter has not been totally rational. I look forward to hearing what further speakers from the Opposition will have to say on this score because I believe that they are doing themselves and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia a very great disservice if they cannot vote for this motion put forward by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the debate I want very briefly to support the remarks made earlier today by my colleagues Senator Puplick and Senator Tambling in respect of the motion moved by Senator Coulter to excise the preamble from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill and have it put in place by way of a separate motion of the Senate. As Senator Puplick said on behalf of the Opposition, the Opposition agrees with Senator Coulter's proposal to remove the preamble from the Bill. From the outset we have argued that that preamble should not for legal and a whole host of other reasons be part of a Bill of this nature. It is not just for that reason that we are opposed to the preamble's inclusion in the Bill; we are opposed to its inclusion because of its content and the proposed motion itself.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the detail of the motion, Senator Puplick made most of the points that I would have wanted to make today. There are two broad sections of the motion. The first is a noting section and the second is a declaration proposal that an instrument of understanding and reconciliation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples should be negotiated by the Australian Government. In other words, the proposal for a treaty, compact or makarrata-whatever one may wish to call it-has surfaced yet again. Part (b) of the Australian Democrats' motion flows from the 10 preambular points contained under part (a) of the motion. As Senator Puplick put so cogently today, we are in grave disagreement-the strongest possible disagreement-with all of the paragraphs of part (a) of Senator Coulter's motion. The whole tone is negative and divisive. The motion smacks of separatism of the worst possible kind in a nation where surely the goals and objectives of us all should be to work together as a cohesive nation to solve the problems of those who are most disadvantaged amongst us.

I am not aware of any dispute from any quarter in Australia that parts of the Aboriginal community are without any doubt among the most disadvantaged in our society. But the way to tackle the problem that is implied in Senator Coulter's motion is to me the very worst possible way that one could go about attempting to solve the problem. The content of Senator Coulter's motion, which is taken straight from the preamble to the Bill, is of crucial importance because it gives the flavour of the motives behind the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation as a whole. To excise the preamble from the Bill does not in any way change that motivation and the way in which it will be read.

As we have all seen, the preamble recites the prior ownership of Australia by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. It also refers to their dispossession without compensation or agreement and to the current disadvantaged position they occupy within Australian society. The Opposition certainly accepts and fully agrees with that point. I and other members of the Opposition have several concerns about the motion. As Senator Puplick and others have said, the motion is not correct. It is not based on historical fact. It is highly negative; there is no positive approach at all in the motion, which looks back with anger and bitterness at the past but offers no hope or prospect for the present or the future. That is a very sad, unfortunate and wrong way to go about solving the problems that confront the Aboriginal communities and the Torres Strait Islander communities in Australia.

The preamble is absolute nonsense. The argument that all Aboriginal people of Australia blame the white men of yesteryear for their cruelty towards Aboriginal tribal ancestors is, as has been said by a leading spokesman for Aborigines in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, an absolute falsehood so far as the Aboriginal people themselves are concerned. The preamble also touches on and goes right to the doctrine of terra nullius, again a matter of very considerable importance. The first three clauses of the preamble suggest that European settlement in Australia was a thoughtless and unjust invasion and that thereby the Aborigines have been dispossessed. The preamble gives the impression that Captain Cook and Governor Phillip acted in an illegal and unjust way in taking possession of land by proclamation and settlement. It is also a de facto attack on the doctrine of terra nullius and eighteenth century international law and doctrine. I do not want to get into a debate on this now but I raise it to point to the negative approach of Senator Coulter's motion which was moved on behalf of the Australian Democrats. In terms of coming to grips with the real problems and issues that face the Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal people of Australia it is about time that we in this country started to look positively at these issues.

Once the Parliament agrees to the words in Senator Coulter's motion or in the preamble we will find it extremely difficult for this or any subsequent government-unless it is prepared to display quite unusual and sustained resolve and political will over a considerable time-to reverse the momentum and wind down the expectations which this motion will create for the development of separatism in this nation-a separate nation within a nation-and the divisiveness that will bring. The motion boils down to nothing short of an advocacy of a form of apartheid in this country which I think every Australian would find abhorrent. I join my colleagues on this side of the chamber in rejecting absolutely and totally the tone, nature and specific content of the wording of this motion. It would be a very sad day indeed for this nation if the motion in its new form or the preamble to the Bill were to pass through this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has just expressed a misgiving that the words in the proposed resolution or the preamble might be the precursor to, or somehow herald, a system of apartheid. I think he used that very word in respect of relations between Australians in this great Commonwealth. I think that Senator Short is wrong in any thought of separatism of that kind being found in the language of the preamble of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989 or the proposed resolution. I think Senator Short is straining the language terribly. It has to be emphasised that whether the words become part of the preamble to the important enactment with which we are dealing or become a parliamentary resolution or simply a resolution of the Senate they have to be seen firmly in the context of a resolution of the Australian Parliament or a preamble to an enactment of the Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to keep on emphasising that we are all Australians, united in one indissoluble federal Commonwealth as stated in the preamble to our own Constitution. It cannot be said often enough that that indissoluble federal Commonwealth has but one sovereignty, and that is as expressed in this Parliament by the elected representatives of all the Australian people. That paramount sovereignty which resides here is recognised in a sense in the making of a resolution of the Parliament dealing with these matters or in putting in a preamble to an enactment of the Parliament. Nothing in the statute before us or, I believe, in the wording of the proposed resolution that Senator Coulter has put to this chamber intentionally or inadvertently creates a situation of dual sovereignty, apartheid or separatism, to use Senator Short's milder word. We certainly do not want ATSIC-and I have emphasised this on occasion during the debate-to become a black parliament. It is not to be vested with the sorts of powers that one would equate with a parliament. I do not believe that any Australian would tolerate for one moment the creation, by resolution, preamble or, certainly, enactment, of a situation in which dual sovereignty was allowed to creep into our society. There is but one nation, one indissoluble federal Commonwealth, in which all the peoples of Australia are united.

I believe that if one looks at the language employed by Senator Coulter, or contained in the preamble, one will find that it builds on foundations which have already been laid in various resolutions of this Parliament. In fact, I recall Senator Bonner's resolution of 20 February 1975. I was not a member of this chamber at the time, but honourable senators will recall that unanimous resolution of the Senate to this effect:

That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

That motion was moved by a most eminent Aboriginal Australian, Neville Bonner, for whom I know we all have tremendous affection and respect. The sort of language to be found in that motion, unanimously passed by the Senate, is, as I say, the true foundation for the sort of language to be found in the preamble or motion now before the Committee.

Senator Puplick has made some criticism that the language in the motion builds on the foundation of the Bonner resolution. Once again, I think this criticism is somewhat strained. I can see some of the points that he is making and I do not deny the validity of some of the colouring which he sought to attach to some of the language. Senator Puplick was greatly concerned about the idea of occupation. Although the word `occupation' is not found in the Bonner resolution, one finds that the Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders are spoken of as being in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay. I believe that the words `prior occupation' in the preamble are used in the same way and do not relate to the matters about which Senator Puplick sought aid from an historian or a professor of anthropology. Even he conceded that the first inhabitants of this continent were, I think he said, very distant ancestors of the present Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. But the question is really, prior to what? They are the occupiers prior to European settlement, and that is made clear in the next recital. I think there is no doubt about their dispossession, in a physical sense, from areas and tracts of Australia which were their exclusive responsibility and over which they exercised rights.

I have tried to use the language of rights and responsibility. I concede this point to Senator Puplick: it is hard to find language understandable by non-Aboriginal persons which we can all employ to convey the meaning of the relationship of Aboriginal persons to the land. The word `ownership', I suppose, normally has a feudal lineage and conveys certain meanings such as `freehold title'. Indeed, the Crown is the ultimate owner of all land in our system. But I think `ownership' is not a bad word to use when one is trying to convey to all Australians, through this motion or preamble, the notion that the Aboriginal people had a relationship to the land which was an exclusive responsibility for the sites which they had to tend or which provided areas for hunting and foraging which groups, clans or tribes required to sustain their physical being. Both their physical and spiritual needs, in so far as they can be differentiated-and it is difficult for us to differentiate our physical and spiritual needs-required a special relationship with a tract of land and the idea of ownership, while somewhat crude, can be seen to be a useful way of describing that exclusive relationship. For that reason, it is used in the preamble.

Senator Puplick was worried about the idea that some of these rights over land are said to be not only granted by but also recognised by the Crown. I think that is a fair expression because it is common on some of the pastoral leases in the Northern Territory and Western Australia-the Temporary Chairman may nod, if not speak, if I am correct-for hunting and foraging rights to be reserved for traditional communities. A right over land, not a land right in the sense of title, would be recognised by the Crown in the giving of those leases. I think that might be an example to which the preamble properly points.

The most difficult point brought up by Senator Puplick, who I take to be the spokesman for the coalition in respect of the motion or the preamble, is the question of collective guilt. I happen to share Senator Puplick's view that individual Australians of our generation do not bear personal guilt for past injustices done to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. In so far as that is suggested, it is a quite unfair burden to place on the shoulders of those of our generation. But I think it has to be recognised that we are the beneficiaries of a society which was able to accumulate its common wealth-whether one is talking in a strictly financial sense or about the general, social and political life we lead-on a basis, as we are all aware, of initial dispossession, marginalising, and the disruption of Aboriginal life which has led to the present situation of grave disadvantage in which Aboriginals find themselves. That sense of responsibility to the persons who currently suffer grave disadvantage-generated, as it has been, by that initial dispossession, disruption and displacement-is really what is behind the idea of some collective responsibility which is focused on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We are the beneficiaries-the legatees-of much that went before.

The fact is that many Aboriginal people themselves are able to point, within their own recent family experiences, to the terrible injustices, of marginalisation and being treated as subhumans. It is amazing that more of them do not bear the sort of malice which would lend itself to violence in view of the consequences of this disruption to their families and the recent history of such terrible injustice. Perhaps it may be that because of their personalities they have been able to deal with these consequences. We have been spared the violence which might have otherwise been our due from a people other than the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They have been really remarkably forgiving. Only last week, on Friday, 13 October, I read a letter to the Australian newspaper and sent from Rodney Rivers of Toowoomba. I will read it to the Committee:

In Western Australia during the 1930s, my grandmother-a full-blood Aborigine but married to a white man-was separated, rounded up by police on horseback at Landsdowne Station and made to walk to Fitzroy Crossing in chains with her sister for about three days over rough terrain.
The police in those days were only obeying orders. Gran and my great-aunt had chains around their wrists and necks. They were linked to each other by a chain from neck to neck.
At nightfall when the police set up camp, Gran and my aunt had chains tied around their ankles to prevent them escaping. My mother, who was then a child, followed them to Fitzroy.

A few years later at Fitzroy Crossing, my mother-then seven years old-was separated from Gran and taken away to Moola Boola, a government settlement 100 miles east of Fitzroy. Mum grew up there, married and raised a family. In 1955, Moola Boola closed down and I was sent away as a boy on the back of an old blitz truck to a mission station near Fitzroy Crossing. I remained there for five years. During that time I was reunited with my mother, and later with Gran, who died in 1957.

What a remarkable recent history. Many thousands of Aboriginal persons could point to similar situations in their family lives which led to their present grave disadvantage. Yet the following paragraphs are even more remarkable:

We do not hold or harbour grudges or ill feelings towards those who treated us unkindly in the past. They are forgiven. Certainly, we cannot condone what happened in the past-but neither can we condemn the innocent white race of today and try to force them to pay restitution for events they played no part in. We of today are responsible for the present and for the future, not for the past. He or she who does not forgive, breaks the bridge over which they too some day have to cross, for each one of us needs to be forgiven!
My story is only one of hundreds of Aborigines who have suffered similar circumstances in the past, but who have also forgiven.

We can rectify present day consequences of past injustices. It is true that the past injustices cannot be put to right; no restitution can be made to those earlier victims. But there are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons and communities living out those consequences at present to whom we have a special responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene just to assist the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that situation the Parliament is now called upon to pass the motion. Naturally the Government would prefer that the substantive words be found in the preambular form which we first put to the Committee. I found Senator Coulter's statement rather extraordinary. He said that the preamble was misleading, deceptive and immoral. I thought that that was rather intemperate and strong. If he meant it in relation to the actual substantial parts of the preamble, of course that would condemn his motion. So I take it that he does not mean that. He must be referring to the fact that it has no legal force or effect. But there has never been any attempt-in fact the attempt has been all the other way, that is, to emphasise, whether in the second reading speech or in other public forums, that the preamble is indeed not of legal force and effect in the normal way, that it is not part of the enactment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is part of the history of our parliaments that the social setting which explains a statute of significance or the mischief which it seeks to remedy is set out in a preamble in order to provide in the statute books an indication to future generations of the sorts of considerations which led the parliament to make the enactment which it has. In so far as the second reading speech makes clear the sort of status which we wish to ascribe to this preamble and re-emphasise for the benefit of any future court that might ever be tempted to look at the preamble at the invitation of some litigant, we have made clear the position and certainly do not intend to mislead or be deceptive in that regard.

Historically, preambles have a very real role to play. When one has a statute of this significance, the placing of these words, with which Senator Coulter agrees, in a preamble can be clearly justified. However these words emerge from the Committee, they are important. They will always be related, even if not in preambular form, to the passage of this legislation which, as the debate draws to its close, I believe will eventually find favour, or at least a majority vote, in its passage in this Committee and in the Senate as a whole.

In that situation we are well poised then to throw the challenge from this Parliament to all those involved, whether they be descendants of the original inhabitants, descendants of the convicts and settlers to whom Senator Puplick referred, or to the new waves of migrants or refugees who have come to this country-all Australians united in one indissoluble federal Commonwealth with one sovereignty and being one nation. We will have to respond to the challenge of this legislation to create for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples within our one nation a future which is indeed worthy of their human dignity. I believe that this legislation, this Parliament and all the Australian people will respond to that challenge in a way that ensures that human dignity is indeed recognised and enhanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to make two or three comments only on the matter now before the Committee. The first relates to the argument to which Senator Tate has just been addressing himself. It relates to the presence in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill of this preamble, which we are now debating. If Senator Tate is correct in saying that it was never intended that the preamble have any legal effect, there is no place for it in the Bill. A Bill is a legal document, certainly a document with legal consequences. The thought that one can tart up Bills with learned dispositions, whether accurate or, in this case, inaccurate, simply for effect or for some public relations purpose, is nonsense. We should recognise it as such.

SPEECH.PARA: The proper place for this chamber to express a view about the matters contained in this preamble, if it is to express such a view, is in a resolution of the chamber. That is indeed the course which Senator Coulter has taken. Either the preamble has legal and interpretative force, in which case it would be properly placed in the Bill, although I would object strongly to it being there, or it has no legal force, in which case it has no place in the Bill. That is a very clear cut-I hesitate to say black and white-argument. Its outcome is crystal clear. Senator Tate has said quite clearly that in his view it has no legal force. Therefore, on the basis of his statement, it ought not be in the Bill. At least that is my view.

I now come to the terms of the preamble and Senator Coulter's motion. I do not want to take the time of the Committee at this late stage in our deliberations on this very large and complex piece of legislation by going over ground which has already been particularly well covered by Senator Puplick and other speakers from this side of the chamber. But it is important to say, simply in my capacity as Leader of the National Party here, that many of the aspects of the preamble, and indeed of the motion to come before us, would be objected to most strongly by the people whom I represent, not merely National Party voters but the people of Queensland. I would even go so far as to say that in that respect the people of Queensland are no different from most people in Australia.

When one finds emotive language of the kind contained in this preamble and/or resolution-whatever the Committee determines it to be in the end-which openly invites the raking up of the very kinds of old scores which Senator Tate, in quoting from that very moving and impressive letter a moment ago, was agreeing should be laid to rest, one sees that it is simply laying the foundations for future trouble. I do not want to take up the time of the Committee by speaking to the particular paragraphs of the preamble or the motion in detail. I am happy to let that aspect of my comments rest there.

Senator Tate read to the Committee a letter from a gentleman in Toowoomba. I am very glad that he did so. I noticed that letter in the Australian a day or two ago. I had meant to bring it into the chamber this evening, but, in the rush of doing other things, I omitted to do so. One lesson that I draw from that letter in relation to the matters which were the subject of Senator Tate's remarks a moment ago, the great bulk of which I agreed with, is that government had nothing to do with that gentleman's reconciliation and coming to terms with his fellow Australians. That gentleman has done us a great service by writing that letter and putting on record not only the wrongs that were done to his family but also the manner in which he has approached the historical burden, if you like, which those wrongs placed on him.

Over a long period in public service, I have not noticed governments do much good in matters of this kind. That is why in the end I do not have any time for this whole elaborate construct of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission which the Minister has placed before us. I conclude by saying that I support the amendment to excise this preamble from the Bill and oppose the preamble in its resolution form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to the matter of the motion being dealt with as a separate motion. Senator Tate has correctly drawn the conclusion that my remarks in relation to the placing of these words as part of the Bill related to the placing and not to the words themselves. Clearly, I have abstracted the words and used them in the separate motion. Senator Puplick has called this a pious motion. I guess that Senator Puplick means that it is a motion without any force and one which does not necessarily lead to any action. The honourable senator will have noted that the motion calls on the Government to do something, namely, to negotiate an instrument of reconciliation and understanding. So it certainly is not a pious motion. It presages a further action by the Government. If the Committee passes the motion, which I believe it will, we will be calling on the Government to proceed down that path.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for such a course of action could not have been better illustrated than by Senator Puplick's remarks. He showed a remarkably superficial intellectual understanding of Aboriginal culture. He certainly has no emotional understanding of or commitment to Aboriginal culture. A few moments ago Senator Short remarked that the terms of the motion were wholly negative and would be seen as such. However, it seems to me that the context in which those statements are made is a context in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people necessarily must become totally integrated in the mainstream culture, that there is no place whatsoever for a contribution from their unique and very valuable culture to a new and different Australian culture which incorporates elements of both the prevailing culture and that of the indigenous population.

Senator Puplick argued that this motion is divisive. I think that the very fact of this debate has illustrated how divided Australian society still is in relation to the two cultures. There are still two cultures in Australia. On the one hand, we have the Western, industrialist, exploitative, competitive, economic, growth oriented type culture. On the other hand, we have the indigenous culture-a culture which has lived with this country for at least 40,000 years-which is far more cooperative, healing and living with nature than living against nature. It seems clear that at the level of the two cultures and at the level of the effects on those two cultures, given what we now know of the environmental impact of our European approach, a confluence of these cultures-a melding of the cultures-and the emergence of a new culture are desperately needed. The instrument which we anticipate in the motion is an instrument of healing to lead towards that process.

Quite clearly the Opposition, from its remarks, does not share those views. It does not understand the very point that we are trying to make. The Opposition's view of reconciliation is one in which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders integrate totally in the mainstream culture. If one could invent a new and useful word, to be used in the same way as we use other words, such as `sexist' and `racist', it would be `culturist'. The Opposition's attitude is `culturist'. It accepts that the mainstream culture not only is dominant and superior but also should totally replace the culture of Aboriginal people.

Senator Puplick spoke of the need for housing for Aboriginal people. One would not argue with that. However, the cataloguing of those material needs which are seen predominantly as needs in a non-Aboriginal culture indicates again the attitude which the honourable senator has to the needs of Aboriginal people. One notes that the Opposition is preparing-if it forms government-to take $100m from the Aboriginal affairs areas, including $22m from the Government's infrastructure program which provides essential services such as water and sewerage. Therefore one has difficulty in accepting a real commitment even to those basic needs which are recognised as needs within the mainstream culture.

Senator Tambling again quoted Mr Charles Perkins. I cannot see how Senator Tambling can continue to do that, given that the Opposition, and Senator Tambling in particular, led the attack against Mr Perkins. The attack went on for some considerable time. There was nothing that that gentleman could do that the Opposition, and Senator Tambling in particular, saw any merit in whatsoever. Yet the Opposition now comes into this chamber-and Senator Tambling in particular-and quotes Mr Perkins and touts him as a font of wisdom and virtue because he said something on the ATSIC legislation which supports its case. It simply cannot have it both ways.

A point in passing I would like to pick up, because I did not pick it up earlier, concerns the preambles to two other Acts which have been passed by this Government, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act of 1987 and the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Act of 1987. Both of those Acts say specifically in their preambles that the Commonwealth does not acknowledge the matters acknowledged by the Government of Victoria. The Government of Victoria had acknowledged prior Aboriginal occupation and dispossession but the Federal Government, in the preambles to both of those Acts, failed to carry that through and, in fact, specifically dissociated itself from that acknowledgment. That, again, is a strong indication as to why this motion must be carried today. We must reverse the tendency which this Government has shown in the fairly recent past.

Senator Puplick also spoke in terms of not having any personal responsibility. He said, among other things, that he was not guilty, nor did he feel guilty, of the sins of his forebears or, indeed, the sins of previous possessors of Australia. He was referring to the non-Aboriginal possessors of Australia. I would certainly agree with Senator Puplick that guilt is a totally inappropriate emotion. Guilt is a very unproductive emotion. However, Senator Puplick and every other senator in this chamber are the inheritors of the advantages which accrued from that dispossession. Senator Tate referred to the same point. We are the inheritors of the advantages which have flowed from the acts of those who took this land from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That, I believe, places a very great responsibility upon us, not because we feel guilty but because we are the inheritors of an advantage. Not only do we have the conditions described in the letter which was read out a few moments ago but we still have in our midst many descendants of the original inhabitants of the country who are severely disadvantaged by that same process which has advantaged us. So while guilt is not appropriate, certainly the picking up of responsibility is.

Senator Puplick went on to analyse the words of the motion bit by bit and took exception to certain words. He questioned whether `prior occupiers' referred to the first, second or third wave of Aboriginal occupation. It does not really matter. What it really means is that those people were the occupiers of this land before European occupation. Senator Puplick did not like the word `occupation', but he knows that probably everybody in this chamber owns and occupies land in a very Western sense. We buy and we sell land. We do not have the same commitment to land that the original occupiers of this land had.

Clearly, in writing a short form of words like this, one does not write a book of history. One does not attempt to use a sufficient number of words to define exactly what one means at every stage. One must, as it were, draw a line through this preamble or this motion and see what, in sum total, the motion and the preamble mean. In sum total one must be totally committed to the intention of those words.

Senator Puplick also took exception to the idea of land ownership. He quoted Professor Strehlow. Let me quote Professor Strehlow on the matter of ownership. I quote from Strehlow's `Central Australian region', page 44. I find these words very moving because they exactly underline the difference between the non-Aboriginal attitude to land and the Aboriginal attitude to land. Strehlow says:
My final comment on monototism-
that is a technical word, but I think it is self-explanatory-
relates to the sense of security based upon an inalienable right of personal land ownership which every individual derives from his conception site-
here he is talking about the Aranda people-
To every Aranda adult in the old days his conception site was `my home' . . . a place from which no-one could be debarred . . . his possession for as long as he lived.

What a marked difference between that attitude to land and the attitude to land which is exhibited by non-Aboriginal people. Clearly, the Aboriginal people in that sense have been dispossessed. They have been prevented from going back to their conception sites. `Dispossession' and `occupation' are absolutely the appropriate words to use.

The final remark I make is in relation to the handling of this motion when it gets to the House of Representatives. I make a plea to the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke): a motion dealing with this matter was moved by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives on the first day of sitting in this new Parliament House, and it would be very appropriate, when this resolution goes down to the House of Representatives, that it be put to the House not by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, but by the Prime Minister of Australia. That would elevate it to the importance that it should have.

That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

MEDIA RELEASE
WE SAY ``NO'' TO THE GOVERNMENTS ATSIC LEGISLATION

Members of the National Aboriginal Professional and Business Women's Association can no longer remain silent, passive and tolerant recipients of policies and programs the government and their officials have decided for us with the forthcoming ATSIC legislation.

We are Aboriginal women of a proud heritage building a future with realistic targets which take into consideration our cultural role and active participation in decision-making. We have stepped forward to grasp new opportunities to make our own decisions, to make our voices heard and to make a positive and important contribution to our culture, economic and political life. We have sought a new dignity and pride in being Aboriginal women. We refuse to change our direction to promote, organise and foster activities in our environment that do not appeal to our needs, objectives or mission.

ATSIC is not what we want. We strongly support and have adapted to the economic, business and education climate and are working vigorously networking across the nation (and internationally) with professional and business people (black and white) to develop business interests that will give us independence.

The Aboriginal women of Australia are in fact the persons most competent to decide their own futures and destiny, and it certainly is not with ATSIC. We alone can feel our blood, emotional ties and duties. We are the ones with the leaky self-esteem and need economic independence as the confidence repair kit. Our thrust is to become owners of property and businesses. The hard earned dollar we have saved is our wealth-NOT ACCUMULATED FROM WELFARE OR GOVERNMENT HANDOUTS.

The Federal Government's philosophy, rationale and criteria places a high priority on equal opportunity for Aboriginal women because they recognise that the Aboriginal women of Australia are the most disadvantaged of all Australian women. ATSIC doesn't give us equal status with non-Aboriginal Australia, it gives us welfare dependency.

We appeal to the Federal Government to hold a Referendum to clear all resistance to ATSIC which is crucial to its chances of success. The information about the numbers of supporters in the form of individuals and organisations supporting ATSIC is inadequate and unqualified. The referendum was overlooked when ATSIC plans were rumoured. It would demonstrate vision and communication by the Government to organise the referendum through the Electoral Commission as soon as practicable.

In the absence of the referendum, the rumour mill will go to work and non-cooperation will surface again, in the form of tense, hostile or antagonistic relationships between the Government and those against ATSIC. SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take just a couple of moments to remind honourable senators that this is the way in which the Senate should operate. Unlike the House of Representatives, which is the Executive's House, we are the House of Parliament precisely because no government has had a majority here for most of the last 20 years. Governments that wish to have their legislation passed--

TALK.START.PARA: —How was Reg Withers when he did have one?

—For most of the past 20 years. I was Whip when we had a majority and it was much easier. When one does not have a majority, it is necessary to negotiate and consider legislation. I do not wish at this late stage to earn the ire of my political opponents, but I wish to make a couple of quotes from Mr Odgers's book on Australian Senate Practice where he talks about the function of the Senate. He makes clear at page 3 that one of the functions of the Senate is to act as a House of review with the responsibility of expressing second opinions in relation to legislative and other proposals initiated in the House of Representatives. Mr Odgers goes on to put it in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: In every walk of life-be it medicine, science or day-to-day family problems-the second opinion is sought and valued. So it is in government, where an Upper House acts as a brake on hasty legislation, imposes a period for reflection and provides an opportunity for anyone-the farmer, the banker, the industrialist, the representative of labour-to voice his opinion, support or protest regarding proposed legislation, after which the Upper House may make or suggest amendments to proposed laws.

He then goes on to talk about the Senate's committee system. Odgers goes on to discuss at some length criticisms which have been made of the Senate, and which I have heard recently, about its failure to function as a States House. I do not want to raise that argument. He goes on further to say at page 13:

The Senate's role as a House of review has not been challenged in like manner to its States House function. The accepted theory of Upper Houses is that they exist to apply the brakes to hasty legislation, to introduce a period of pause for second thought, to improve proposed legislation if the need be shown, and in a federal system to provide checks and balances on national and State issues. That two sieves must be better than one is an indisputable truth. It is one of the facts of Parliamentary life that the House of Representatives is more concerned with broad legislative policy than with detail and that it is in the Senate that the close examination of the clauses of bills takes place.

That is what has happened with this legislation. Whatever honourable senators can say, we have quite a notable achievement with this legislation. I have taken out from the Senate office a list of what were the most amended Bills of recent years. They include the Family Law Bill (No. 2) 1974, the Freedom of Information Bill 1981-I just interpolate that some of these were Bills when we were in government and some were Bills when Labor was in government-the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983, the Insurance Contracts Bill 1983, the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1984, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill 1985, the Aboriginal Land Rights Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988, and the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988. To each of those Bills there were extensive amendments. Almost all of them were government amendments-whether the government was a Labor government, or a non-Labor government. For example, the Family Law Bill (No. 2) had 116 amendments inserted in the Senate, of which 104 came from the government of the day, the Labor Government.

I can advise the Senate that on this package of Bills, as was reported by the Deputy President a few moments ago, a very large number of amendments have been accepted by the Government-91 amendments to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill, 14 amendments to the Aboriginal Development Corporation Amendment Bill, and 17 amendments to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill. Some of the amendments, particularly to the ATSIC Bill, have come from the Australian Democrats and some amendments have come from the Government, but the majority have come from the Opposition. This is the largest number of amendments that have been put into Bills by an Opposition in recent times. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address briefly a matter that was mentioned in Estimates Committee B on 11 October 1989 relating to Royal Brunei Airlines Ltd crews. I hope Senator Collins will remain in here for a while as I wish to address some of the remarks he made. At page B214 of Estimates Committee B Hansard of that day, Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: I noted Senator Panizza's claims that Royal Brunei crews had, in fact, exceeded their approved operational times and out of a healthy degree of self-interest, as a regular passenger on Royal Brunei Airline, I spoke to a number of Royal Brunei crews myself. I also spoke to the senior operations officer within Ansett responsible for scheduling and supervising the Royal Brunei operations. The story I got from both sources was absolutely consistent even though I spoke to them independently.

Senator Collins did mention this today. I point out that I did not make any claim that the Royal Brunei crews had exceeded their operational times. I simply asked a question in this place on 6 October about whether it was correct or not. I asked it of Senator Button and to this day I have not had an answer. Senator Collins went on to say at the Estimates Committee:
I got a categorical denial from both Royal Brunei pilots themselves and from Ansett that there have been any breaches of regulations in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not what I said, Senator.
—I am reading from Hansard. Senator Collins can read page B214 for himself.
—That is not what I said, Senator.
—Well, it is in Hansard; so I will continue to read it. Senator Collins further stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza's specific claim that a Royal Brunei crew had flown for 14 hours straight was categorically denied. I was told by Ansett that the longest scheduled period of flight that has been allowed so far for a Royal Brunei crew is 11 hours and 10 minutes, which was followed, as I understand, by a flight of six hours on the following day.

Senator Collins would know that a scheduled flight may not arrive at the scheduled time of arrival. No fool will say that he has exceeded the scheduled time. Has Senator Collins ever been on a flight that has been held up because of strong winds, for instance? Has he not been on a flight from Canberra to Perth that has taken two hours longer than the scheduled time? Does Senator Collins not understand that that can happen?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what happened?
—I asked Senator Button the question and I have not got an answer.
—You do not know, do you?

—No, I do not know, but I will know when I get the answer. I would prefer to get the answer from the Civil Aviation Authority rather than the pilots of any foreign aircraft who may put their own interpretation on it. We are not allowed to talk to our own pilots, and foreign pilots think they are a law unto themselves. I was talking to a German ex-military fellow last weekend about the airline pilots dispute. He said, `The pilots are the same as the Luftwaffe pilots in the last war. They thought they were great, but they were useless'. He thinks that the Australian pilots, and many pilots from other countries, are in the same category.
—Why aren't you on the Select Committee?
—I was not on the Estimates Committee because I could not get back from Perth. There were no flights. I was replaced by Senator MacGibbon on the day.
—The Select Committee.

—I did not volunteer, but we can worry about that later. The Chairman of the Estimates Committee asked Senator Collins to make his statement a question. Senator Collins carried on for a while before he got around to asking the question. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The question that I want to obviously ask is: Is the information that I have got from both sources correct? Is Senator Panizza's claim-
that is wrong; I asked a question and did not claim anything-
accurate that Royal Brunei crews have been breaching regulations?
Dr Lee answered:
We in the Bureau have not had any reports relating to that matter. I think the question of our standards versus overseas standards would be one for the CAA.
Mr Freeland said:
If I may comment, it is also our understanding, as it is yours, that Royal Brunei operates under British standards. To my knowledge we have had no reports of breaching any of those standards-none.
Senator MacGibbon then said:
What Panizza said was that on one occasion-and is it true?-Royal Brunei operated a duty period of 14 hours 40 minutes on one day. He also went on to say-
in fact I did not go on to say; I asked a question-

that the airline is entitled to do that under British civil aviation regulations. He made the point in the question that there is a difference between the Australian duty periods and the British duty periods. I think that is where the matter ends. If Senator Collins can prove that on one day Royal Brunei did not fly a duty period of 14 hours 40 minutes, then that is another matter. The essence of that question was to illustrate that there is a difference in the periods of duty required for an Australian crew operating under CAA regulations from what applies for an overseas group.

The matter was discussed further. Apparently, a senior operations manager of Ansett Airlines of Australia said that the longest period of time that a Royal Brunei crew has ever flown in Australia is 11 hours 10 minutes. Senator Newman asked whether we could get that information verified. The transcript then reads:
CHAIRMAN-Is that something the officials are in a position to answer now, or is it something they can give us information about later?
Mr Freeland-No, it is not. As has been mentioned, the oversight of that operation is by the British authorities.
It is not by the CAA. The transcript continues:
If you wish, we could go and ask them if they have had any different reports.

That is where the matter rests. I have been through the rest of the Hansard and the question about whether that information could be verified was not answered and no answer has been given to this day. No answer has been given to the question I asked Senator Button in the last week or so about Royal Brunei. When I get those answers we will know what happened. In the meantime I ask Senator Collins to refrain from making statements saying that I claimed this and I claimed that when I simply asked a question. If we want to ask a question about somebody breaching regulations we should ask the Authority. We should not necessarily ask the pilots. They are not the be-all and end-all. We do not have to take their word for it. It is just like asking a thief, `Did you take it?'. Generally, he will say that he did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a brilliant observation.
—Yes, it is brilliant. Senator Collins said that I made a statement in the Estimates Committee B hearing when I simply asked a question. If he has any gumption he will admit that.

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter that concerns me and all members of the Commonwealth Public Service in Victoria is an apparent political pay-back to certain Commonwealth public servants in Victoria because they had the temerity recently to question some of the activities taking place in the Australian Electoral Commission in Victoria. On 15 May this year 34 divisional returning officers for the Federal electorates in Victoria wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, expressing their concern about the operations of a newly installed computer enrolment system called RMANS. It is a system specifically designed for terminal access. They pointed out in their letter that in several States, including Victoria, terminals have not been provided and that RMANS is currently used on a batch processing basis. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the following reasons the signatories to this request no longer have confidence in the accuracy of their electoral rolls . . .
That is a fundamental lack of confidence because the state of the electoral roll is the whole basis for the propriety of elections. They said that because of the situation then prevailing:
(1) electors are being removed from the rolls for reasons unknown to the Divisional Returning Officers,
(2) there are unknown numbers of duplicated entries on the rolls as a result of mispunching, and
(3) many Divisions are reverting to outdated processing practices in an attempt to reduce the possibility of enrolment error.

Very serious allegations and concerns have been expressed in that letter of 15 May from 34 very responsible divisional returning officers in Victoria. On 18 May the Minister wrote a letter to all members and senators. It was addressed to `Dear Colleague'. He said that he had received a letter from returning officers for 34 Victorian divisions regarding electoral enrolment. The letter conveyed the response to the allegations that the Minister had received from the Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner. Of course, that letter found its way into the hands of the divisional returning officers and, as far as I know, it may have been sent to them directly. They were unsatisfied with the response by the Minister, so on 7 June they wrote him another letter in response to his letter of 18 May. I will not go into all the details but in that letter they say:
The information provided to you-
the Minister-
by the Commission is in some areas misleading and in other areas totally incorrect.

Dear Colleague

I have received a letter from Returning Officers for 34 Victorian Divisions regarding electoral enrolment. I understand that a copy of this letter has been forwarded to you. I feel that it is important that I convey to you the following advice I have received from the Australian Electoral Commission:

``The recently introduced, computer enrolment system RMANS, to which the letter refers, replaces another computer system which was old and difficult to maintain and enhance. The new system was designed to run in State Head offices using batch processing. It was never designed specifically for terminal access from Division Offices as suggested in the letter.
In response to the specific points raised:
(1) Electors are being removed from the rolls for reasons unknown to the Divisional Returning Officers.

This is not so. In most cases electors are removed from rolls as a direct result of a DRO's action. When an elector enrols in any Division, the new system checks the national roll to determine whether or not the elector is currently enrolled elsewhere and automatically deletes the elector from the previous division's roll. Losing DROs are informed on a deletions report which advises them what has become of the deleted elector.
(2) There are unknown numbers of duplicated entries on the rolls as a result of mispunching

The introduction of RMANS has made this less likely. There will inevitably be duplicates under any system due to inconsistencies in key data provided by electors such as date of birth, order of given names and spelling of names. The number of duplicates resulting from mispunching should be no more under the new system than under the old. The rate of duplicates from causes other than punching errors in the new system is significantly lower than in the previous system. The AEC is also at present further enhancing RMANS to identify more accurately and eliminate possible duplicates.
(3) Many Divisions are reverting to outdated processing practices in an attempt to reduce the possibility of enrolment error

The Australian Electoral Commission has been made aware of a redundant practice in some Divisions where claims for enrolment are checked against earlier microfiche records of enrolment before the claim cards are put into the system. There is no requirement for this procedure because RMANS does it automatically. The Australian Electoral Commission is writing to DROs to end this unnecessary practice, and to ensure DROs have a better understanding of the system.

The reference to multiple acknowledgments is a reference to an incident when duplicate acknowledgments were indeed sent to some Victorian electors in mid to late March this year. The problem which involved data transfer procedures between Canberra and Melbourne, not the enrolment system, was fixed.

The Australian Electoral Commission is happy to demonstrate the RMANS system at West Block for the information of Members, Senators and parties. Should you be interested in a demonstration, please contact the Electoral Commissioner (tel. 714400) to arrange a suitable time.

(1) Electors are being removed from the rolls for reasons unknown to the DRO's

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. My reasons for raising that correspondence tonight are two-fold. The first is to draw attention to serious concerns expressed by the divisional returning officers in Victoria about the state of the rolls in Victoria. With a Federal election coming up in the near future-at some stage between now and presumably the middle of next year-the state of the rolls is of the utmost importance. The Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner has said-and I do not doubt this; it is a fact-that a habitation review was undertaken in Victoria over the last 12 months or so, and that under the normal processes of the habitation review the rolls have been cleansed, to the extent that habitation reviews can cleanse rolls. Even if that is so and even if that habitation review produced a highly accurate roll review, the scope for computer error in deleting names from the rolls or causing other inaccuracies is a matter of considerable concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is at the table tonight, to convey that matter to the Minister and to the Electoral Commissioner because I think it is demanding of an urgent response. Indeed, we have already had an example of the cost of computer errors to eligible voters. In the Victorian council elections in August 25,000, or thereabouts, eligible voters were disenfranchised, unable to vote at the council elections, because of these types of computer errors leading to their deletion from the rolls that the divisional returning officers have drawn attention to in the correspondence to which I have referred.

The second reason why I have raised this matter tonight is another serious issue. As a result of this correspondence initiated by the divisional returning officers in Victoria, there appears to be a payback against them by the Labor Party in relation to the non-inclusion of any divisional returning staff in the Australian delegation that is shortly to go to Namibia as the observer team for the forthcoming Namibia elections. Mr Deputy President, as you may know, Australia is sending a team of 30 observers to Namibia in the next few weeks to join observers from many other countries to observe and, in some instances, take part in the actual conduct of the forthcoming elections in Namibia. I am told that about 1,000 observers from around the world will be at those elections. It is an important trip for observers and it is a particularly important trip for members of the Australian Electoral Commission. I understand that one senior member of the Commission, Mr Mike Maley, has been in Namibia since June, actually participating as an adviser in the run-up to the elections. As I have said, he will be joined by another 29 or 30 people, as observers, in the next few weeks. It is a plum trip; it is an important trip; and it is an important opportunity for Australian Electoral Commission personnel to gain valuable overseas experience.

I have been advised from Public Service sources in Victoria and elsewhere that no member of the staff of divisional returning officers in Victoria has been invited to join the team. Three persons from Victoria are part of the team but, as I understand it, none of those three comes from any of the divisional returning officers. It has been said by Public Service sources that the reason for this exclusion is political. It has been said by these sources that Victorian divisional staff are being punished for corresponding with the Minister and with other members of parliament about faults being experienced with computer equipment and, in particular, the failure to go ahead thoroughly and completely with the new RMANS system.

The omission of Victorian divisional staff from the team for Namibia appears to be a prime example of political or bureaucratic pettiness, or both. If the Minister has not been directly involved, I state categorically that he should carpet those responsible for this political payback. If he has been party to the decision he, too, stands condemned. The Australian contribution to this significant democratic event should not be allowed to become a junket for administrative favourites. It should be based on appropriate selection criteria. I want to know-and I ask the Minister whether she can convey this to the Minister for Administrative Services and to the Electoral Commission-the strength and the content of the allegations that I have raised tonight. As I have said, they are well based from sources within the Victorian Public Service. If those allegations are correct, both the Minister and the Commission deserve condemnation and this Senate certainly deserves an urgent explanation.
