TALK.START.PARA: —Many of my learned colleagues in the Senate have put down a book for a moment, reflected upon the times to which it relates and imagined the settings of the story being told. I ask my learned colleagues to stop and reflect upon the extraordinary times we live in today. In time to come some young historian will put down his or her book and imagine what it was like in such momentous times. The momentous events to which I refer are occurring in eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. We are witnessing the tentative collapse, step by step, of the Marxist ideology and its communist system. Seventy-five years after the First World War and 50 years after the Second World War, the shape and direction of Europe are changing again. Poland has a democratically elected non-communist government; Hungary is to follow. The East German Government is losing its grip on its people with the exodus of its youth to the West; and the Baltic states and the Ukraine peoples are speaking out irreversibly for independence. Even the centre of the communist empire, the Soviet Union, has, to a qualified extent, freed up the press, held public elections and introduced free enterprise measures into the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: These changes are affecting the politics of every continent. The most obvious examples are in the withdrawal of support and funding by the Soviet Union to many revolutionary and terrorist groups. It is almost as if, before the close of this century, the ledger is being balanced against the horrific effects of the two world wars and the subsequent aftermath, with a promise of peace and freedom into the next century. However, like any detailed study of historical events, it is often found that the turning points have been due only to good fortune. Perhaps some historians will tell us that many of the key events in history have been driven only by good fortune. I suggest that the moves towards democracy that we are witnessing in eastern Europe today could just as easily have been a time of great conflict in Europe, if not for a great deal of good fortune.

One should stop and remember what times were like in international politics between 1979 and 1984. In light of the nuclear age, it was potentially the darkest time in world history as it was the last gasp of the Soviet old guard before Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985. By 1979 it was evident to the old guard in the Kremlin, who had ruled since the Leninist and Stalinist times, that the communist system was in terminal decay. The Soviet Union could simply not feed its people. This was my own conclusion following a visit to Russia and through Siberia in 1976. With a system in decline, yet in possession of an unprecedented military power, the old guard in the Kremlin knew nothing else but to strike out.

Afghanistan was invaded on 27 December 1979. The significance of the invasion lies in the fact that it put the Soviet forces only hours from the oilfields of the Persian Gulf, the blood supply of the economies of Europe, Japan and the United States. So great was the shock to the world of the invasion that it prompted President Carter to say about it:
A more dramatic change in my own opinion of what the Soviet Union's ultimate goals are than anything in the previous time I have been in office.

He added that, should the grander plan of the Soviets be to attack the oilfields of the Persian Gulf, he would have no choice but to deploy any means available, including nuclear means. The strength of this statement was significant in that the Carter Administration in its term had allowed the Soviets to gain a military superiority and was in the midst of the demoralising Iran-United States hostage crisis.

I recall my visit to Afghanistan in 1979, just prior to the invasion. People came up to me in the streets pleading for help from the West as the Russians were poised to invade. The feeling of desperation that sweeps through a people who are about to lose their country is something I will never forget. United States intelligence must have been aware of the imminent invasion. However, the Kremlin under Brezhnev took advantage of the weakened United States Administration. Did the Kremlin have a grander plan of taking the Persian Gulf oilfields? It seems highly likely that this was the plan by the Kremlin, certainly if the opportunity arose, and particularly in the light of the Soviet Union's own oil supply crisis at the time. Anyone who doubts the intent of old guard Marxists to protect their power should remember the reaction of the Chinese leaders towards the students in Tiananmen Square, even as the world watched on television.

Soon after the invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, the Solidarity movement began to rise led by Lech Walesa, and undoubtedly inspired by the election of the Polish Pope in 1978. The election of a Polish Pope was an inspiration towards freedom in a country whose history is intertwined with its religion. The flame of freedom, probably foreseen by the Kremlin, had been lit; yet to the Kremlin Poland was of supreme military importance to the Soviet bloc as well as being a political influence upon the other Eastern European states. They could not lose Poland if communism was to survive. The world stage was then set for its most tense period of international relations since World War II.

In 1980 Ronald Reagan was elected President of the United States. Reagan's first action was the freeing of the United States hostages in Iran. This sent out the strongest message possible that America had lifted itself out of its morass of self-doubt in world affairs. It was more likely that Reagan's strong leadership in these days had more to do with halting any grander plan of the Soviets in Afghanistan than did any of Carter's earlier threats. The tide was turning on the Soviet leadership. Poland was cracking, America was strengthening and Afghanistan was bogged down. However, the old guard was still in power in Russia and Brezhnev was their symbol.

Then in early 1981 two key events occurred which, if successful, I believe would have changed the course of today's events in Europe. The two events were the assassination attempt upon President Reagan outside the Washington Hilton in March 1981 and the assassination attempt upon Pope John Paul in St Peter's Square in May 1981. In both attempts the leaders were shot. Reagan was hit in the chest and required half his blood replaced. For a man in his seventies, this was an extraordinary strain. It would be an understatement to say that the assassination attempt was a near miss. The attempted assassination of Pope John Paul was probably more remarkable. The Pontiff was hit by three bullets. Yet, like Reagan, the Pope did not even sustain a permanent disability. A successful attempt upon Reagan's life at this early time in his presidency would have had a devastating effect for the Western world.

The years 1980 to 1984 required a special kind of leadership to confront the ailing and nervous Soviet empire. Reagan was the President for the times. His Vice-President, George Bush, could not have brought to the job the same vital skills that were needed in those crucial years of East-West relations. It was widely accepted that the assassination attempt upon the Pope was planned by the state of Bulgaria with the knowledge of the then KGB chief, Yuri Andropov.

Coincidentally, on the day of the Pope's assassination attempt the dramatic findings of the highly respected London based Institute of Strategic Studies were released. The Institute reported that the threats to the Soviet empire posed by unrest in Poland and the West-backed guerilla resistance in Afghanistan could soon lead to war with the West. The Institute said that securing its empire had become the Soviet Union's main preoccupation and that events in Poland threatened that domination. It reported that the Soviet leaders saw that time was running out and that solutions were hard to find. The assassination of the Polish Pope, John Paul, would have been a bitter moral blow to the Solidarity movement. A successful assassination attempt upon the Pope would, firstly, have stopped a papal-led resistance of the Polish people if Soviet troops had been sent into Poland and, secondly, would have prevented a papal-led rally of Western reaction to an invasion of Poland.

The Hungary and Poland uprisings in 1956 and the uprising in Czechoslovakia in 1968 would have been in the minds of Brezhnev and the other old guard Kremlin leaders. In those times the West bluffed and blustered how it would support uprisings in the Eastern Bloc countries. However, Soviet troops put down these uprisings in the face of Western rantings. The difference in the 1980s was that Poland had the support of a strong world leader in the West who would resist a Russian invasion. So it was only good fortune that saved us from a dark turn in world history.

The death of Brezhnev in 1982 did not see the end of the old guard's grip on power. Rather, Brezhnev was replaced by his protege, Yuri Andropov, who had been chief of the KGB for 15 years. The issue that followed the existing tensions between the East and West was the deployment of the Pershing missiles by the United States to Europe. These land-based missiles would give the Western Alliance an absolute first strike strategic advantage over the Soviets. The Kremlin, under Andropov, turned sharply contemptuous of the US Administration. The most vitriolic war of words in the history of East-West relations was launched. It was during this time, March 1983, that Reagan made his historic statement, describing the Soviet Union as an evil empire. Reagan warned that Soviet communism was `the focus of evil in the modern world'.

In September 1983 Andropov issued a personal statement that questioned the entire range of US-Soviet relations and accused the US of threatening peace and security around the globe. By November 1983 it was being widely reported by Moscow observers that we were closer to the nuclear brink than ever before. It was at this time that the Soviet Union began deploying near the coast of the US submarine-based nuclear missiles aimed at the US in response to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation's decision to deploy the medium range missiles in Western Europe aimed at the Soviet Union.

As world events were reaching a dangerous crescendo a series of events struck the Kremlin hierarchy and finished the old guard control. These events can probably be described as bad fortune for the Kremlin. The Kremlin lost two leaders within 12 months. Firstly, Yuri Andropov died in February 1984. Secondly, Konstantin Chernenko died in March 1985. Then the Kremlin lost two of its key military personnel. Firstly, the Chief of Staff, Defence Forces, Semyon Romanov died on 22 May 1984. Secondly, the Minister for Defence Service, Vice-Marshal Dimitrii Ustinov, died on 20 December 1984. The Kremlin suffered the destruction of two of its key military installations. Firstly, on 13 May 1984 in Severomorsk the munitions base of the Soviet Arctic fleet was destroyed. Secondly, in December 1984 a second unexplained explosion at a major munitions factory around Leninek Kugnerskiy occurred. All those events occurred in 1984.

Looking back it would be fair to say that the rise of Mikhail Gorbachev was more a product of a Russia in 1985 utterly lacking any other option whatsoever than of any wisdom by the Politburo in choosing a new guard reformer. Rule under Mikhail Gorbachev is now set on its path but the good fortune in March and May of 1981 has played a critical role in the historic and ever-changing events of today. How quickly we forget events of only a few years ago, yet those years made our future years. If we keep this in mind we can then always be alert to the fine line in history between one course of events and another course of events and then be alert to holding on to the great future the world now looks forward to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is actively promoting family planning, thus reducing women's need for termination of pregnancy services.

The Government is acutely aware of the incidence of unwanted pregnancies and abortions in Australia and is committed to promoting family planning as an important ameliorative measure.

The Government remains committed to promoting family planning to help women and families to plan their families, thereby reducing the need for termination of pregnancy.

SPEECH.PARA: Another argument advanced by those who defend continued government funding is that if a medical procedure is legally able to be performed then the Federal Government is somehow obligated to pay Medicare benefits for it. QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 31 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs are conducted by the department or other instrumentalities within the Minister's portfolio to promote cultural, artistic or academic exchanges with other countries or to provide assistance in such areas to other countries.
(2) What grants are made to other bodies for the conduct of such exchanges or to provide such assistance.
(3) What were the costs of such programs and/or grants in 1988-89.
(4) What are the estimates for such programs and/or grants for 1989-90.
(5) What role does the department play in co-ordinating the activities of the various government and non-government agencies involved in such activities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As a general rule the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and other instrumentalities within the Minister's portfolio do not run cultural exchange programs. They are, however, engaged in a number of programs and activities concerned with the promotion of cultural, artistic or academic exchanges with other countries in line with the Government's broader objectives. These include professional development; overseas study; international exchanges of personnel and grants to bodies across the range of Portfolio activities. Specific cultural, artistic and academic programs and activities are outlined below.

(5) Programs within the Portfolio are largely implemented by the various statutory and non-statutory bodies involved in the promotion of cultural, artistic and academic activities including exchanges. For example the Minister and the Department have placed a great deal of emphasis on the co-ordination of the activities of cultural bodies and the department provides policy co-ordination advice and secretariat services to the Minister. The Department co-ordinates meetings convened by the Minister from time to time with all cultural agencies in the Portfolio to discuss matters of common interest. These regular meetings include Chairpersons and Chief Executives of all agencies. The Department is included in the Cultural Ministers Council, a forum of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers with responsibility for cultural matters. The ongoing business of the Council is pursued through its secretariat which is accommodated within the Department. Changes in budgetary arrangements introduced by the Government have led to greater co-ordination by the Department. Decisions by the Government on budgetary matters are taken at a Portfolio level rather than at an agency level so that the Minister in deciding on priorities draws on advice from the Department. The Portfolio is also represented on the Cultural Relations Coordination Committee which is chaired by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and which seeks to promote greater cooperation in Australia's overseas cultural activities.

In its co-ordinating role the Department prepares instruments for appointment by the Governor-General and the Minister, to some 200 Board, Council and Advisory positions in respect of cultural agencies within the Portfolio. The Department also prepares policy advice for the Minister on matters of general cultural interest such as funding, taxation, education/training, copyright and international cultural activities.

Commonwealth Indemnification Scheme-the Department administers the Scheme and provides advice to the Minister for the Arts, the Minister for Finance and the Prime Minister on exhibitions deemed suitable for indemnity by the Government. The exhibitions may include those from overseas which are thought to be of cultural or diplomatic significance. The Department co-ordinates meetings between Government and non-Government agencies to discuss policy matters relating to the Commonwealth Indemnification Scheme.

National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia-The Department has responsibility for an initiative contained in the Agenda relating to cultural heritage. The strategy agreed is to establish a Consultative Committee with representatives of the three levels of government, including the Department, collecting institutions, ethnic community groups, folklife and aboriginal interests. The Committee will develop a plan for the future to co-ordinate efforts by collecting institutions to enhance their collections to reflect cultural diversity and to promote awareness of the multicultural nature of these collections both within this country and internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, without notice, on 7 September 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the serious, health-threatening problems of air pollution with silica dust at the Electrona plant? Is he aware that in Australia the allowable level of silica is presently 5000 micrograms per cubic metre but that, in recognition of the toxic nature of silica, the United States of America has recently reduced its allowable level to 200 micrograms per cubic metre, a reduction by a factor of 25. What, if any, overriding controls on occupational and environmental health does the Commonwealth possess and will these powers be invoked in this case to prevent the significant hazard to which workers at and residents near the Electrona plant are exposed?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The issue of standards for occupational exposures to silica is one for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission which has advised that it is currently investigating an appropriate exposure standard for silica fume (which is understood to be the form of silica which may arise in the Electrona plant). It is awaiting the scientific documentation to support a recommendation by the American Conference of Government Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH) for a threshold limit value of 200 micrograms per cubic metre.
The responsibility for application of these exposure standards lies with the relevant State/Territory regulatory agency.

As to public health issues, I am advised that the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning has indicated that the ambient particulate concentrations measured on a daily basis around the plant range from 20 to 60 micrograms per cubic metre. This compares with the National Health and Medical Research Council ambient air quality goal for total suspended particulates of 90 micrograms per cubic metre.
The Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning is, apparently, reviewing the data collected from Electrona and is to prepare a summary report when this review is completed.
